The topic is \"Pantabhiman\" (Sectarian Pride) and \"Dharmabhiman\" (Religious Pride), how terrifyingly obstructive they are on the path of ultimate truth an illuminating example of which comes from the 35th chapter, a leela Sectarian Pride. Meaning, when we wish to live the spiritual life, when we wish to walk the path of spirituality, then there should be no pride of religion or pride of sect. If a person possesses these two types of pride, then they cannot reach the ultimate truth. The journey to the Supreme Absolute, the Purna Parabrahma, is simply not possible for them, if they carry this sectarian pride and religious pride. So, there is a leela related to this, which Baba has presented in the 35th chapter. Today, we will try to unfold it. Before I come to the talk, there is an Ovi (verse) from this very chapter. No obstacle is harder to cross than this pride The very next Ovi. Baba placed this Ovi right as the chapter begins. Karu zata paramarth vichar, just as we begin to contemplate the ultimate truth , sectarian pride (Panthabhiman) becomes a terrifying barrier. And the pride of sect, you see, that places a huge roadblock on that person's path. (No obstacle is exceedingly difficult), and there is no obstacle more difficult than this, that comes on the path of the seeker of ultimate truth there is no greater obstacle than this. Greater than sectarian pride (Panthabhiman). Ya abhimanasam duje, there is no other obstacle greater than this pride. Sectarian pride is such a massive obstacle. Now, the question is, many people will wonder, what is sectarian pride? The pride of religion is easy to understand: we are Hindu, we are Muslim, we are Christian, we are Parsi. We are Jain, we are Buddhist. Everyone has pride in their own religion. On this point, Kabir Ji offers a very profound couplet Everyone takes pride in their own sect/lineage. The truth of Hari (God) is far away; no one recognizes it. Meaning, to preserve their own sect, their own religion, their own lineage, to prove their own religion is supreme, every person struggles 24/7. Apni apni saankh ki, sab hi leeni maan (Everyone takes pride in their own sect) and everyone has pride in their own sect That my sect is the most superior. My Guru is the most superior, my religion is the most superior. All others are inferior. This is the ideology of the majority of people. So, Kabir Ji, rebuking strongly, says: Everyone takes pride in their own sect/lineage. The truth of Hari (God) is far away; no one recognizes it.) And the original Hari (God) is not attained by anyone. The realization of the original soul-substance, the Supreme Absolute, no one is able to achieve. We do not believe in idol worship, etc. We do not believe in any person. We are directly connected with that quality-less, formless Supreme Being. . We do not need worship of form. Once, a friend of Kaka Mahajani accompanies Kaka Mahajani; this is a leela from the 35th chapter. And he always sees Kaka Mahajani going to Shirdi. And looking at the friend, He says, \"Ka Yaave Ji.\" This sounds very profound in Marathi. Meaning, as if, \"Where have you been all this time? Come brother, come, you are welcome.\" Baba says this to him. He says, \"Ka Yaave Ji.\" He says, \"Ka Yaave Ji.\" But the manner of speaking, Baba speaks in his father's voice. His father had passed away. Many years had probably passed since his death. But he has boundless love for his father. Once, a similar incident occurred in the life of Swami Vivekananda. I think he was staying as a guest in a palace in Mewar. The king was surrounded by great pundits and priests, and he believed that the worship of the quality-less, formless God is the truth, it is complete. What do you say to this?\" Vivekananda asks, \"Really, you absolutely don't believe?\"He replies, \"No, I absolutely don't. Look, there are no pictures in my house.\" There are no idols. There is no image of God. I don't believe. So Swami Vivekananda says, \"Come here for a moment.\" He gets him up from there. The king thinks, \"It feels strange. The man who is saying he doesn't believe in God with form. They go and stand him in front of it and say, \"Spit on him, just once.\" He is unable to spit. Vivekananda says, \"Look, speaking is one thing, living is another.\" Even those people who fully experience the quality-less, formless God, they too do not reject God with form. Because the entire world is in God with form, and they wish to take them to the formless God. Therefore, they too know its importance well. So don't assume that those who have experienced the formless God reject it. You haven't even had the experience, where do you stand? Only then does his mind settle down. So, this was one leela. What does it say? First, they sit in a tanga (horse-drawn carriage). They go from there to Kopargaon. That means it was a journey by land. Because it must have been the rainy season, the month of June-July, when they came. So, there is a flood. They have to cross a river from Kopargaon to reach the railway station. After that, at Kopargaon station, the train arrives, and it is said that they sit in the Agni Ratha (chariot of fire/train). So, the train came. It is called the Agni Ratha. Because it runs on the power of fire. So they sit in the Agni Ratha. In this way, they travel and reach Mumbai. So three things came here. When the tanga moved, it crossed the earth. When they sat in the boat, they crossed the water. When they sat in the Agni Ratha, they crossed the fire. Understand well. So Baba is clarifying in this leela who can reach the formless God. Alright, they crossed these three elements. And now they reach home. As soon as they open the door after reaching home, since they've been gone for two or three days. All the windows were closed when they left. They go, open the door. They open the windows. As soon as they open a window, a bird flies away with a whoosh from that window. They look and say, \"Oh my God, was this bird trapped inside the house for two or three days?\" And later, they look down, and see two dead birds. Now, the bird that flew away from the door, that is the element of air (Vayu) When we understand the knowledge of elements deeply and thoroughly. This pluralistic world, this entire expansion of the universe, as long as the element of space (Akash Tattva) and the element of air (Vayu Tattva) exist among the five great elements, up to that point, He is the quality-less, formless God. But as soon as descent begins from there, the creation of God with form begins from there. That is, from the element of fire. After that, upon reaching water, it becomes more solid, and upon reaching earth, then the entire universe... its expansion has no limits But, you see, crossing these three gross elements... look, the grossest is the earth element. More subtle than that is the water element. And the more subtle something is, the more pervasive it is. We must first accept this fact. It must be accepted. Water is more subtle than the earth element, so its pervasiveness is greater than the earth. More subtle than water is the fire element, and it is more pervasive than water. And more subtle than fire is the air element, and it is even more pervasive than fire. And that which penetrates the sky (space), then imagine what the pervasiveness of the Soul must be. And how subtle it must be. We can just imagine. So here, the person who crossed the earth, on the path of elemental knowledge, who overcame the earth element, reaches water. After reaching water, the earth cannot harm him. Because water is a higher element than earth. And after rising above water, into fire. That is why it is clearly written here that the train journey, as soon as they sat in the Agni Ratha... The rain continued, water poured down torrentially, but despite that, because they were safely seated in the Agni Ratha, they did not have to suffer any consequence. Meaning, it had no effect on them. So, the leela is trying to convey that when you enter a higher element, the lower elements cannot harm you. That is why Baba has shown so many leelas in Sai Satcharitra. Like, cooking meat in one place and feeding people. But stirring that meat with His hand, yet the fire does not burn His hand. The Khanda Yoga (Yoga of Fragmentation) where He fragments His body and scatters it.But then returns to His original, whole form. There are many such leelas. Like water cannot soak Him. The leela of Megha in the 28th chapter. So, Baba has repeatedly tried to convey that this is the elemental knowledge, and O man, every person must reach that elemental knowledge. So, in this leela too, He has shown that among the five great elements, the journey starts from earth and reaches the sky (space). And after that, one attains the element of ultimate truth. So, this leela has been brought out in a very excellent way. And moving forward It is very easy to speak of the formless God. But before that, you have to give the 17 rupees. If you give the 17 rupees, then you gain entry into the formless God. There are many such things, whose secrets are revealed by this leela. Now look, He says, those two birds... because I had closed the doors and windows, those three birds were inside. I had not seen them, but because they did not get food and water for two days, two birds died. And one, perhaps it was destined to live, death was not written in its fate, so it flew away. But those two were destined to die, so they died, as is said. Now, this leela also applies to those who speak of formless worship. That the day the connection to food and water is completely severed from your life, that day you may speak of the formless God. Not before that. He is saying this. This is also a very big aspect of this leela. That is why Baba takes the three-day samadhi (meditative absorption), where he takes no food, water, or air. But still, He rises after three days. So, only a person of that level is fit to speak of the formless God. Not people like us. He is stating this as well. So, meaning, those people who are caught up in food and water, those people for whom survival is impossible without consuming food and water to maintain their existence. Those people, they should not speak of this formless God. This is another aspect.     "Title": "Why is Goddess Lakshmi Saraswati given only one day but Goddess Durga gets nine days? | By Krishnaji",
    "URL": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P8h4XHBBoE4",
    "Transcript": "This is no ordinary book; it is a radiant counsel, His own autobiography in His own words. Om Sai Ram Today, we are in the city of Maa Shakti, nestled in the lap of Maa Kali. First of all, millions of salutations at her sacred feet. We pray that with her benevolent hand upon our heads, she may grace these three days of satsang, allowing her divine words to flow from our lips into our hearts, and immerse us all in the ocean of her wisdom. See, now that we have arrived in the abode of Maa Shakti, I wish to share a few words about her alone. Arun ji took us to Kali Ghat for darshan, and we had her darshan early this morning. Our scriptures declare, a profound description of the Tridevi, the three divine powers. The first is Mahakali, then Mahalakshmi, and finally Mahasaraswati. We all know this well. But have you ever pondered, why Maa Kali, Maa Shakti, or Maa Durga are worshiped for nine full days? In Navratri, nine days are dedicated to them, while Maa Lakshmi receives but one day, Laxmi Pujan and Maa Saraswati is honored on the day of Dussehra. Yet to Mahashakti, Maa Kali, nine days are offered. Have you ever wondered why? Why such immense importance to Maa Shakti? Nine days and nights of her upasana. And now, seated in her sacred city, I felt to offer these words at her lotus feet. Why nine days for her, while Maa Lakshmi and Maa Saraswati receive only one each? There is a profound secret here, a deep mystery - not without reason. Consider: If Maa Shakti were absent from our lives, for we address her with love as, \"Ya Devi sarvabhuteshu shakti rupena samsthita, namastasyai, namastasyai, namastasyai namo namah.\" O Mother, O Durga, you who abide in all beings as the form of Shakti, O Devi, present in every creature as the essence of power, \"Ya Devi sarvabhuteshu shakti rupena samsthita,\" I prostrate at your feet repeatedly. Have you ever imagined , what would happen if Maa Shakti withdrew her power from within us, stripping away our kriyashakti, our capacity to act? What could Maa Lakshmi or Maa Saraswati accomplish then? What could they do? There is an incident, the elder ones will grasp deeply: In Bombay, those great industrialists of an era - today their heirs are considered highly successful. I speak of Dhirubhai Ambani ji. He was paralyzed, and vast fortunes were spent on treatments across countries, but he could not recover from that stroke. Ultimately, he attained death. It is said that his wealth ranks among the top ten or twelve in the world such a titan of fortune. Yet, despite all that riches, he could not overcome illness, because Maa Shakti had withdrawn her hand. No matter how much Lakshmi or Saraswati one may have, no matter the knowledge, if Maa casts a grave affliction, squeezing out all vitality from within, then neither Saraswati nor Lakshmi can function. They thrive only when Maa Kali lays the foundation, bestowing full health and vigor. When health is robust, the mind blooms in joy. Only with true well-being can you savor the wealth you've earned. Only in vitality can you experience the knowledge you've gained, share it with others. But without that health, without that Shakti, if Maa, for some reason, deprives us through severe illness, then neither Lakshmi nor Saraswati avails. Thus, Maa Durga holds such paramount place, she is the very source of our energy, the bedrock of our existence. Upon her, the edifice of Maa Lakshmi or Maa Saraswati is raised. Yet, any grand palace endures only if the foundation is unshakeable. So too is Maa Kali our bedrock. If her compassion rests upon us, only then do Maa Lakshmi and Maa Saraswati hold true value in our lives. If Maa Shakti departs for any cause, all is void - everything attained becomes naught. Hence, such reverence for Maa Shakti. She is hailed as kriyashakti, the power of action. Even scriptures affirm: For the creation of progeny, her might is invoked only then does a child come into being. So profound is her creative force. If that Shakti vanishes from our lives, nothing remains. Thus, we ever pray at her feet: O Mother, first make me wholly empowered by your Shakti, render me potent. But even before that, purify my mind, for without purity, I would squander your bestowed power amiss. O Mother, bring sanctity foremost into my life. And if impurity lingers, if purity eludes, then at the hour of need, withdraw your Shakti, leave me powerless. But O Mother, I yearn first for purity in my being. Once that dawns, grant me your boundless strength, and I shall wield it solely for the good, never for harm. Thus, we all beseech Maa Shakti. In the same vein, if Maa Lakshmi graces our lives, let her come only after our minds are purified. If we dwell in impurity and she bestows compassion, piling riches upon us, we would misuse that wealth, squander it wrongly. Likewise with Maa Saraswati: If I amass knowledge from countless books, yet my heart remains unpurified, I would pervert even that wisdom. So, these three powers are truly interdependent, complementary - one sustains the other. May, all these three divine forces, enter our lives only when the mind is sanctified, the heart made pure. Upon attaining that chitta shuddhi, when these three Shaktis arrive, you shall uplift the world - misuse becomes inconceivable, even in dreams. These are kriyashakti, ichchashakti, and gyanashakti - the triad of Mahakali, Mahalakshmi, and Mahasaraswati. They must certainly manifest in our lives, in varying measures. Observe: In some, health abounds, yet they are paupers in wealth and wisdom. In others, riches overflow, but health and knowledge are barren. In yet others, knowledge flourishes, with moderate health and wealth. Remember, this creation is such: All three rarely converge in one soul, a bitter truth. Those in whom they do, we call stars their lives shine like stars. Witnessing such souls, we are profoundly inspired, though they are exceedingly rare. Yet these are the stars that pulse vibrantly among us those blessed with kriyashakti as the vital source, Maa Lakshmi's grace, and Maa Saraswati's favor. And often in this world, when I speak of Maa Saraswati, I mean spiritual wisdom, not worldly learning. The latter abounds everywhere; I speak not of it. But one with complete spiritual gnosis, fully graced by Maa Lakshmi, and empowered wholly in health by Maa Durga, Maa Kali - such a being is a rarity in this realm. Yet if we grasp their essence, their sanctity, and first seek chitta shuddhi from them, then beseech their boons, we tread the true path. But if these gifts flood our lives before purity, the peril of straying heightens. Whenever you bow before them, ever recall my words truly, when such a prayer rises, the three Devis dance in ecstasy, tears of bliss flowing. In this vast creation, at least one soul comprehends this depth, seeking purity before my grace. They'll rejoice. Whenever you stand before the Mother(Devi), let these words echo let this prayer spring from the heart: \"If you shower your graces upon me before chitta shuddhi, I shall surely falter, misuse your power.\" \"O Mother, if you truly wish to bless me, first sanctify my mind, purify my being, and then pour forth your boundless blessings.\" This was the glory of Trishakti. O Mind-Enchanting One, Remover of Curses and Suffering, Destroyer of Ignorance, Bestower of Liberation, The Supreme Giver of Auspiciousness, Embodiment of Truth, Consciousness, and Bliss, the Sacred Mother of countless embodiments of Sai. the True Form of Sai Himself Victory to the Divine Scripture: Shri Sai Satcharita.",
    "Description": "In this video, Krishnaji reveals the spiritual significance of the three goddesses—Maa Lakshmi, Maa Saraswati, and Maa Kali.     "Transcript": "This is no ordinary book; it is a radiant counsel, His own autobiography in His own words. Om Sai Ram The topic is: \"My Baba, my Sai, has given meaning to the word 'Guru'.\" The word \"Guru\" has been endowed with true significance by my Sai. Because when we say guru, saint, mahant, or an avatar, The true saints, gurus, sadgurus, They do not belong to any one individual, any one sect, or any one religion. Just as the sky belongs to all, the sun to all, Water is for everyone, air is for everyone. No one can claim exclusive rights over them. Similarly, if someone is a true saint, a true guru, a true prophet they cannot be confined to one caste, community, or religion. And if such divisions still exist within them, then they are neither a saint, nor a prophet. One whose base instincts have not yet fallen away, Whose sense of duality has not dissolved, cannot be a saint, prophet, abbot, or an incarnation of the Lord. Thus, Baba has given true meaning to the word \"Guru,\". Baba, throughout his entire life, Never aligned himself with any one sect. Never confined himself to any one religion. And only one who has attained the ultimate essence, the supreme reality, can live such a life. One who has realized the fundamental Parabrahma form, Once that is attained, nothing else remains to be divided or shared. Wherever he looks, he sees only his own Guru. As far as the eye can see, it is \"I am all, I alone exist.\" This is the experience of the supreme essence. After attaining that supreme reality, no other person or object remains to be apportioned. Thus, only one who has realized that ultimate truth, can live a life of tolerance toward all religions and sects, with equal love for all. Whenever a devotee from another sect approached Baba, he never claimed them for his own fold. First, He refined their flaws. He strengthened their faith. He removed whatever defects were within them, and then, multiplying their devotion infinitely, He reestablished them in their own guru's path, reconnecting them firmly, regardless of the sect they came from. This teaching- I do not believe that in the entire cosmos, anyone has embodied the guru essence with such a vast heart as my Sai has given it true meaning. Today, I take up a very important leela: Chapter 12, the story of Muley Shastri. Muley Shastri was from Nasik, a dedicated Brahmin, deeply inclined toward rituals and Agnihotra (Fire-offering). He always performed worship in pure, washed attire, studying the Vedas and scriptures diligently. But he was rigid in nature, believing rituals must be performed exactly so. This is necessary in the beginning. But as depth increases, such rigidity should fade. In the early stages, it's good. So, this is the story of that rigid Brahmin. Chapter 12: Muley Shastri. By the grace of karma and dharma, he somehow arrives in Shirdi. Upon reaching Shirdi, he enters Baba's court and sees people devotedly worshiping Baba. He is deeply impressed. Besides Vedic studies, he was proficient in astrology, Palmistry, physiognomy, and almanacs - he was an expert in all. By seeing Baba revered by so many, he thinks: If I could once hold his hand, I could read his palm lines and understand which lines have made him so adored today, as per samudrika shastra, the science of palmistry. If Baba's hand comes into mine, I'll examine his lines and gain insight - this line is why he is worshiped as divine. His thought is: I normally read the palms of worldly people. If Baba's hand comes to me, I'll study his lines as study material. And that too, of an avatar. If an avatar's hand comes to me, it would be invaluable study material. So, with this intention, he extends his hand toward Baba, but Baba doesn't give his hand. Instead, four bananas lying nearby are picked up and placed in his hand. Baba indirectly says: Foolish one, what will you read in the hand of one who holds the power to grant dharma, artha, kama, moksha? Take these four bananas, eat them, and sit peacefully. He gives him the four bananas, and after sitting there a while, he leaves and goes to Sathe Wada or Dixit Wada, as those were the places then. He goes to Sathe Wada, takes a bath, performs his evening prayers, thinking he'll decide later whether to return or not. He heads to Sathe Wada, and Baba rises for his morning ritual, which was to go to Lendi Bagh. As he leaves, he tells all the devotees: 'Bring saffron, we have to wear ochre robes today.' People are puzzled: Why is Baba suddenly asking for saffron today? And why will Baba wear ochre robes? But they think: Whatever comes from his mouth cannot be meaningless. There must be a reason. Baba goes, spends about an hour in Lendi Bagh performing his ritual, and returns to Dwarkamai before the midday aarti. The aarti is about to begin. People stand immersed in devotion, ready for the midday aarti. At that moment, Baba says: Someone go and tell that rigid Brahmin - Muley Shastri that I have asked for dakshina, and bring some dakshina. See, Baba says this. Bapusaheb Booty is also sitting there. So, he rises. The guru has commanded. Let's go to Muley Shastri and say \"Baba has asked for dakshina from you.\" Though, Bapusaheb Jog was also there in the Sathe Wada, along with Muley Shastri. He tells Muley Shastri: \"You too come for the midday aarti.\" At that time, Muley Shastri, after bathing, is preparing for his worship in specific attire - called \"sovala\" in Marathi, meaning pure, washed cloth. As an Agnihotri Brahmin, he is readying for his upasana. He says to Jog: \"No, no, you go for aarti. I'll complete my daily ritual and see later; I'll take darshan of your guru in the afternoon.\" He brushes it off, and here Baba insists: Go and bring dakshina from that rigid Brahmin. He didn't listen to Jog, so Jog returns to Dwarkamai with the aarti plate. but Baba plays his game: Go and bring dakshina from that rigid Brahmin. Who rises? Booty rises. Booty goes to the wada and says: Baba has asked for dakshina from you. As soon as he hears Baba has asked for dakshina from him, he thinks: By what right does your guru ask dakshina from me? He may be your guru, not mine. By what authority does he demand dakshina? I don't consider him my guru. I am a pure Brahmin, and he is an impure Yavana dwelling in a mosque. Am I surrendered at his feet? What right does he have to ask me for dakshina? He thinks this inwardly, not saying it to Booty. But then he thinks: Booty, a millionaire, has been sent. How can I refuse him? Baba plants the resolve in Booty's mind that he will go for dakshina. He can't say no to Booty now - a millionaire, after all. After all, wealth has its place. Baba is the master player. Baba knows whom to send so that he will quietly rise and come, leaving his work incomplete. Indeed, it happens so. He can't refuse Booty, the millionaire. He leaves his ongoing rituals midway, and comes along with Booty. And, dressed in his pure ritual attire - the specific clothes for worship he goes to Dwarkamai with Booty in those very clothes. Upon arriving, he doesn't climb up the steps of Dwarkamai, He stands in the sabha mandap below, thinking: Dressed in such pure attire, after such a sacred bath, as an Agnihotri Brahmin, if I enter the mosque, I'll become impure again. He saves himself: I won't go up in these clothes. In the morning, when I took darshan, I wasn't in pure attire - that was different. But now, as a rigid Brahmin, I've donned such sacred clothes. So, in these clothes, I won't climb the steps of Dwarkamai and enter. Baba perceives this. Fine? Stay in the sabha mandap. He stands there. After the aarti, Mantra pushpanjali is sung. Then flowers are showered. He too has flowers in hand and throws them. Since there's no devotion, I'll say \"throw,\" not \"offer.\" How can he say \"offer\", he throws the flowers. But as he throws the flowers toward Baba, Baba reveals his play. His departed guru, who had attained heaven a few years ago, Who had left the body only a few years prior - Guru Gholap Swami Appears in Baba's place. He is astonished. First, am I not asleep? Not dreaming? He pinches himself. He pinches and hurts himself. No, I'm awake. If awake, then how is Guru Gholap Swami here in Sai Baba's place? And that too, clad in full bhagwa attire, as his guru always was a saffron-robed sannyasi, Gholap Swami. Dressed exactly so, staff in hand, seated there. He becomes utterly overwhelmed with emotion. But while throwing flowers, he gets overwhelmed and can't stay in the sabha mandap anymore so he climbs the steps. In Sai Satcharita, there's a verse: Baba says, all who come to me, no matter their base tendencies, however lowly, They are like inert iron, and I am like a magnet, drawing them in. That inert iron - I am the lodestone. I have that magnetic power; no matter how inert the iron, Once it comes into my gaze, it is drawn. Attracted toward me. In the same way, while showering flowers, he beholds his guru and can't remain in the sabha mandap for even a moment. He quickly climbs the steps and prostrates directly at Baba's feet, at that moment, it's not Baba, but Guru Gholap Swami, he falls at His feet. Tears stream down profusely. The eight sattvic emotions surge within. His entire being is transformed. Just moments ago, minutes before, his mental state was entirely different- now completely changed. Immersed in the eight sattvic bhavas, he rolls at the feet, and when he opens his eyes, he sees Sai Baba. Sometimes Guru Gholap Swami appears, sometimes Sai Baba. But he realizes: My thinking was wrong. My ideology was flawed. This is no ordinary person. This is the incarnation of Parabrahma itself. Wherever your or my thoughts reach, Baba resides in that very form. Because he is seated at the pinnacle of perfection. Have you ever felt this?- When we live in our homes in the city, Suppose we step out - how far can our vision go? To the house in front. You can't tell what's beyond that house. That's our limitation, isn't it? But suppose there's a huge mountain nearby in your city, and you climb it. You reach the summit. From the summit, the entire city is visible. Visible, right? Similarly, one whose spiritual journey has reached the sahasrara sees the entire universe within himself, as his own form. For him, 'this guru is separate, that one is different; this religion is separate, that sect is different' - no. He has risen far above. These are our entanglements, our illusory antics. This \"mine-yours\" feeling, this duality, This my sect, my religion, my guru, your guru - all these ailments are below. But one who has reached the spiritual summit, such height, has no place in life for such rubbish. Their heart is so vast; the sadguru knows that where this poor soul stands, these ailments are inevitable. They will be there. But I am the sadguru. How can I coexist with that ailment? So, being at such height, Baba awakened everyone in his court. He drew Muley Shastri toward himself and reestablished him in his place bringing his departed guru, who had left the body years ago, back to life, And elevating his devotion to the ultimate abode. Baba deepened his guru bhakti in his own guru. This quality of Sai Baba - I don't think I've ever heard it anywhere. In all the scriptures I've read, all the people I've listened to, this quality is unheard of. Such vastness. Hence, the topic: \"My Sai has given meaning to the word 'Guru'.\" Original gurus are like this: If a disciple of another guru comes by, they don't think, \"Let me add him to my fold\". Baba never had such base feelings, and couldn't, because he had reached the ultimate state, seated at the pinnacle of knowledge. Such ill will cannot arise in that person's mind. Impossible And at the end of this leela, there are two verses: Baba says, what will you learn, from this leela of Muley Shastri? There are two verses- I'll take them. Verse number 176, Chapter 12. \"Jo jo jayacha guru asava, Tyachechi thayi drudh vishvas basava, Anyatra kothehi to nasava, mani thasava guhyarth ha\" What a verse! He says: \"Jo jo jayacha guru asava\" Whosoever has a guru, Definitely, in this world, people may have different gurus. Whosoever may be your Guru, Firm faith must reside in their feet alone. And such firm faith should not exist elsewhere for any other. \"Mani thasava guhyarth ha\" And this deep secret behind the leela, treasure it in your heart. Respect for all must be there. Faith only in one's own guru; respect for all, lest contempt arise in the mind for anyone. Respect is one thing; faith is another. But the problem is: To elevate our guru, we demean others. That is wrong. Respect all, but take pride in your own guru. Yet, do not view another guru or disciple with contempt. This is the intent. But firm faith in one's own guru. Hence, Baba says: \"Jagat sant amap apula bap to apula bap\" Chapter 45, Verse 119. \"Sant srushti maji umap, Apula baap to apula baap, sai mukhinche he karuna laap, kora swarhridaypatavari\" First, let me explain why this verse comes. Because we think we first visited Baba some years ago. That's our perception. But before we reach there, his work on us has already begun. He has already set us on the track. And guides us on that path. Hence, if you go elsewhere, the chance of wandering increases. It takes more time. We suffer, and so does he in cleansing us. That's why: Stay where you are. Because work on you has already started there. You think it's your first time going to their darshan - no, His gaze fell on you before that. Like tobacco for the chillum - it's processed beforehand. Then, by fortune, it reaches his hand. Later, he lightens it separately. But his eye was on you from before. He has already taken you in process. So, if you wander elsewhere, it takes Baba longer to cleanse you, and you longer to reach the destination. Hence, faith must be in one place. Your guru is yours. And further, verse 178 \"Konachi kirti kitihi aso, Apule guruchi mulihi naso, Pari swaguruthaich vishwas baso, hachi updesho yethila\" He clarifies outright: Let some other guru's glory be whatever, \"Konachi kirti kitihi aso,\" Our guru's may be less. Not so many followers, Not such glorification But let faith always remain in our guru's feet. This is the teaching of this leela, says Baba. So, Baba has truly given meaning to the word \"Guru.\" Original gurus are like this; true gurus are like this. He has given meaning to the word \"Guru.\" And presented it to the whole world. Otherwise, If a person is slipping from my hand, people go to extremes. So, when will this feeling come? When will such vastness arise in us? If a disciple of another guru comes to you, If you can, multiply his faith in his own guru infinitely. And if you lack that ability, then stay silent. But never extol your guru's glory before that disciple of another guru. This is Baba's message. A unique message. No guru in the world has given such a message to anyone. And he could give it because he is complete. Wherever He looks, He sees Himself. Nothing is separate from him - not Muley Shastri, not his guru Gholap Swami Baba says: In every form, I alone pulsate. One who has such realization, How can he descend to lower levels and act? Thus, \"My Sai has given meaning to the word 'Guru'\"- truly. He has placed the meaning of \"Guru\" before the whole world. Now, another story: Chapter 26, Bhakta Pant. Actually, he isn't Baba's devotee: he is a disciple of another guru. One day, traveling from Virar - near Mumbai he meets some people on the train. They say: \"We're going to Shirdi. Come with us.\" He has no interest. Where is Shirdi? Who lives there? He knows nothing. But he is fully surrendered at another guru's feet. So, he says: \"No, I have already have one guru. I'm completely satisfied.\" \"No need to wander here and there.\" But those people, out of love: \"Just join us, it'll be nice. Come, what difference does it make? All gurus are one.\" Perhaps they said such things. But his mind wavers a bit: \"They're inviting with such love. If I refuse, it hurts.\" But finally, he says: \"No, you go. I'll ask my guru for permission. If he allows, I'll catch the next train to Shirdi. You proceed.\" He goes to his guru and says: \"On the train, some of my relatives, met me. They were going to Shirdi and insisted, but I didn't go. But I'll go only after your permission.\" The guru says: \"Why need permission? Go, visit and return\" With a big heart. So, next day morning, he arrives, meets those people He reaches Dwarkamai, and sees the crowd around Baba, people applying perfumes, washing feet, applying sandalwood, the whole worship and outpouring of emotions. He, Bhakta Pant, is utterly delighted, climbs Dwarkamai's steps, takes Baba's darshan, and at that instant, faints, losing consciousness for a few moments. Baba says: \"No need to worry, sprinkle some water, he'll revive.\" Baba is the one who made him unconscious. They sprinkle water, and he opens his eyes and sits up. As he opens his eyes, Baba utters a statement. He says: \"Go wherever you must, But hold fast to your own guru. Even if you have to go anywhere in the world, go, But let your faith in your guru never waver.\" These words come after he rises. In that brief unconsciousness - what happens? Tell me, what happens in deep sleep? One thing: Our ego becomes zero. There, our sense of \"I\" vanishes completely. Taking support of that, Baba plants the seed he needed: \"I salute your faith in your guru\" - multiplying it infinitely toward his guru. That gap where ego was zero for moments- using that, he deepened his guru devotion infinitely. Such leelas are not heard elsewhere. Truly, how safe is this court. Whoever comes, of any religion, any sect, And even if their guru is a bit weak, Baba does what the guru should do, and sends them back to their guru's feet. What a unique way! Can you imagine? It may happen that the person's guru is weak, lacking capacity. Fine, no issue. Baba does the work himself, pours his full power into the devotee. But his guru devotion - making it profound, returns him to his guru's feet. Such uniqueness. How vast is His heart! Truely, I've heard nothing like this anywhere. If it happens anywhere, it's only in Sai's court. Hence, the topic: \"My Sai has given meaning to the word 'Guru'.\" Truly, if anyone has given true meaning to \"Guru,\" it's Baba. And if someone calls themselves a guru, only if they have these qualities are they true; otherwise, grabbing a stray person and adding to their fold. That means he is incomplete. Perfection hasn't been attained. Hence such actions. One who pervades every particle, Who has become the lord of the universe, alone can hold such heart's vastness. Because it makes no difference to him: \"This poor soul's weakness is seeing me and his guru separate, because he is yet far from the experience of 'I alone am.'.\" But the day he realizes, all these ailments will vanish on their own. So, for now, establish him in his guru and uplift him gradually. This compassion toward a stranger, a disciple of another guru- Original sadgurus are like this. Hence, Baba has given meaning to the word \"Guru.\" Now, one more leela: Chapter 38. Nana Saheb Chandorkar had been connected to Baba for years. Once, his wife's sister's husband, Biniwale, Says: Take me for darshan of your Baba. He takes him to Kopargaon. They bathe in the Godavari river nearby, and since he deeply reveres Datta, Biniwale, Nana Saheb Chandorkar's brother-in-law. He says: \"There's a Datta temple a short distance away. I always take his darshan. Come, let's first take his darshan, then go to Shirdi.\" But Nana Saheb Chandorkar says: \"You do it always. Come, first take darshan of my guru, let's go to Shirdi first.\" He doesn't allow him to take darshan of his adored deity Datta, and directly grabs his hand, bringing him to Shirdi. They reach Baba's court. As soon as they arrive, Baba asks Nana Saheb Chandorkar: How was the journey? He says: \"Yes, fine, Baba. But what happened - a big thorn pricked in Kopargaon.\" Baba says: \"Do you know why the thorn pricked?\" \"No, Baba.\" \"You didn't let Biniwale take darshan of his adored one - Datta, in whom he has profound love. He kept telling you: Let me take his darshan first, then we'll go to Shirdi. But you didn't allow him that, and forcibly dragged him here: Come to my guru first. That's why this time only a thorn pricked. Next time if you do such a thing, I'll hurl a trident.\" This is what He is saying? What teachings ! If one lacks such vastness of heart, he cannot be a guru. This is Sai Baba. Otherwise, people unnecessarily look at caste, sect, religion. But that essence is the supreme reality. If you truly understand that essence, it transcends all - having swallowed them to reach there. Yet if they still talk of this religion, that sect, then they are not original gurus, not original saints. Whoever speaks such things, know for sure the original essence hasn't touched them. Confirmed. He is neither original guru, nor original saint, Nor original prophet. And if the divine essence has been attained, he experiences: I alone reside in this entire universe. Nothing besides me. So why would such a person harbor ill-feelings toward anyone? Impossible This vastness can only be given by him. Those who haven't attained such supreme experience, remain entangled in these, yet call themselves gurus, saints, preachers. But the original hasn't been grasped. If the original is grasped, they too would fill with Baba's vastness. This was \"My Sai has given meaning to the word 'Guru'.\" If anyone has explained the essence of guru to the world, it's Baba. Today is Guru Purnima, and I believe this was a very important topic. What is the essence of guru (Guru-tatva) Like the sky is for all, the sun for all, the air for all. Similarly, if someone calls themselves guru, they belong to all religions, all sects, all paths- if He is an original guru. If not original, they'll spout nonsense and pass their life. So, this was \"My Sai has given meaning to the word 'Guru'.\" O Mind-Enchanting One, Remover of Curses and Suffering, Destroyer of Ignorance, Bestower of Liberation, The Supreme Giver of Auspiciousness, Embodiment of Truth, Consciousness, and Bliss, the Sacred Mother of countless embodiments of Sai. the True Form of Sai Himself Victory to the Divine Scripture: Shri Sai Satcharita.",
    "Description": "इस दिव्य प्रवचन में कृष्णाजी बताते हैं कि साईबाबा ने “गुरु” शब्द को किस प्रकार गहन और सजीव अर्थ प्रदान किया।\nगुरु किसी एक धर्म, जाति या पंथ के नहीं होते – जैसे सूर्य का प्रकाश और वायु सबके लिए समान है, वैसे ही सच्चे गुरु का आशीर्वाद भी सबके लिए होता है। \n\n*साईसच्चरित अध्याय १२* में वर्णित मुळेशास्त्री की लीला इसका अद्भुत उदाहरण है। संशयग्रस्त वृत्ति से उन्होंने बाबा के हाथों की रेखा देखने का प्रयास किया, किंतु बाबा ने उन्हें उनके दिवंगत गुरु के ही साक्षात्‌ दर्शन देकर यह सिद्ध किया कि सच्चा सद्गुरु अपने शिष्य की श्रद्धा को उसके ही गुरु पर दृढ़ करता है। \n\nसाईबाबा ने हर भक्त को अपने दरबार में स्थान दिया, परंतु कभी किसी को अपनी ओर खींचा नहीं। उन्होंने भक्तों की भक्ति को उनके ही गुरु के चरणों में स्थापित किया और यही उनकी अद्वितीय विशेषता है।\nसच्चे सद्गुरु में द्वैतभाव नहीं होता; वे केवल आत्मा को परमात्मा से जोड़ने का कार्य करते हैं। \n\nभक्त पंत को भी बाबा ने यही उपदेश दिया कि “जहाँ कहीं भी जाओ, पर अपने गुरु की ही अनन्य भक्ति करो।” \n\nसाईबाबा ने “गुरु” शब्द का सार इस प्रकार उजागर किया कि उनका जीवन ही गुरु-तत्व का सजीव स्वरूप बन गया। \n\n🪷🪷🪷 \n\nIn this divine discourse, Krishnaji explains how Sai Baba gave profound and living meaning to the sacred word *Guru*.\nA true Guru does not belong to any one religion, sect, or community – just as the sunlight, air, and water belong to all, the blessings of a Sadguru are universal. \n\nIn **Sai Satcharitra, Chapter 12**, the story of Muleshastri beautifully illustrates this truth. With a doubtful mind, he wished to examine Baba’s palm, being well-versed in palmistry. But Baba, instead of allowing this, granted him the vision of his *departed Guru*, thereby proving that a true Sadguru always strengthens the disciple’s faith in his own Guru, rather than drawing him away. \n\nSai Baba welcomed every devotee into His darbar, yet never sought to attract anyone to Himself. Rather, He rooted their devotion firmly in their own Guru, and in doing so, He displayed a rare quality that is seldom seen even among great saints.\n\nA real Sadguru is beyond duality; He is the bridge uniting the soul with the Supreme. \n\nTo devotee Pant too, Baba gave the same eternal teaching: “Wherever you may go in this world, hold on firmly to the exclusive devotion of your own Guru.” \n\nSai Baba thus revealed the very essence of the word Guru – His life itself became the living embodiment of the Guru principle. \n\n#SaiBaba #Sadguru #GuruTattva #SaiSatcharitra #SaiLeela #GuruBhakti #SpiritualWisdom #SaiTeachings #DivineGrace #PathOfGuru …...more\n...more\nShow less",

    "Title": "साईबाबा द्वारा नवविधा भक्ती की सच्ची व्याख्या - By Krishnaji",
