    "Transcript": "This is no ordinary book; it is luminous advice. It is the autobiography of the Divine, narrated in His own words. Om Sai Ram In the 21st chapter of the Sai Satcharitra, there is a beautiful description of Nav Vidha Bhakti - the ninefold path of devotion. So today, let us reflect upon this subject of Nav Vidha Bhakti. Saints, sages, and enlightened beings have spoken and written extensively on this topic. You must already be aware of this. But as it is said, every person perceives things through their own experiences. So, what my eyes have seen, and what I have experienced in my own life regarding Nav Vidha Bhakti, that is what I shall share with you today. And I hope it will touch your hearts. Before delving into Nav Vidha Bhakti, let us first understand what devotion truly means. In Baba's view, what is devotion? Let us illuminate that a bit. Baba says,- 'What is devotion?' Devotion certainly does not mean being completely immersed in worldly affairs, and then sparing just five or ten minutes to stand before the Divine or the Sadguru, offering a few prayers or services, only to return to being entangled in the world for the remaining 23 or 24 hours. Baba does not consider that as devotion. In the 10th chapter of Sai Satcharitra, while explaining devotion, Baba says that wherever your mind is attached in the world be it wealth, children, spouse, possessions, your own beauty, or the ego of your position Wherever your mind is attached - be it your child, spouse, wealth, honor, or any other snare at the mental level - first withdraw your mind from all those places. This is Baba's definition of devotion, Wherever you are entangled in the world, wherever your mind is attached first withdraw your mind from all those places. Then, gather that collected mind and pour it at the feet of the Sadguru, so that only devotion to the Sadguru remains, forgetting everything else. If you can achieve this, Baba says, that is true devotion. That means, Baba straightforwardly declares, \"I do not want your divided love, where you devote to me on one side while remaining fully occupied with worldly activities on the other. You are completely submerged in the world, and only if you get five or ten minutes do you chant Sai Baba's name.\" Baba says that is not devotion. So, wherever your mind is attached, wherever you are entangled, first detach your mind from there, and then fix that gathered mind at the feet of the Sadguru. That will be called exclusive devotion, selfless devotion, true devotion. So, before reaching Nav Vidha Bhakti, let us be clear on what devotion is. In the 10th chapter, Baba says, \"Premachi nahi jayache thayi. Aisa manav honechi nahi.\" Meaning, there cannot be a human without love in their heart. It's just that for some, love is directed toward offspring; for others, toward spouse; for some, toward position; for others, toward their own body or adornments. Who knows where people's love is immersed? Because a human without love is unimaginable. Every person has love, but the object of that love varies. Human love is divided. We are all entangled - some in one thing, some in another. This is the bitter truth; we must accept it. Baba isn't saying this in vain in the 10th chapter. And He says, \"I do not want your divided love.\" I want pure love. So, wherever your mind is stuck, withdraw it first. If it's stuck in wife or husband, withdraw it. If in office, withdraw it. If in wrongful pursuits, withdraw it first. If stuck in children, in attachment to them, withdraw that attachment first. If stuck in illusion, in wealth, withdraw it. Gather the mind withdrawn from everywhere and fix it at my feet; that devotion will be unwavering, exclusive, and true. Baba says, in my vision, that is devotion. Kabir Ji expresses the same in his words: 'Jab lag nata jagat ka, tab lag bhakti na hoi' As long as you are bound to the world, you live, die or long just for the world. So, for such people Kabir Ji says, 'Jab lag nata jagat ka, tab lag bhakti na hoi. Nata tode Hari bhaje, bhagat kahave soi.' Break ties with the world and connect with the Guru; Kabir Ji says, only then is one a true devotee. We all pass through three stages in devotion. All of us. The first stage: I want only the world. We do a bit of devotion to God, but our intention is that nothing should lack in the world. That's why we worship the Sadguru, God, or deity. In other words, we use the Divine or Sadguru as a ladder, climbing on their chest to attain perishable worldly things. Please understand this well. 'I want only the world. ' From there, a little progress happens, a bit of discernment awakens, humanity stirs a little, the mind purifies somewhat. We gain the company of good people, satsang begins. Then we reach the second stage: We want God along with the world. Earlier, we said only the world; now, world plus God. But as sadhana increases, remembrance grows, better company is found, superior satsang take place, and we realize that selfless devotion is everything. Baba says, you must break ties with the world to become my true devotee. That settles in our every vein, we detach from the world and merge completely in Baba. At that time, every pore of our being says, \"I want only Baba.\" So, that is devotion. That is the original and exclusive devotion. Kabir Ji clarifies: 'Jab lag nata jagat ka, tab lag bhakti na hoi. Nata tode Hari bhaje, bhagat kahave soi.' Baba says the same, Kabir Ji says the same, all saints say the same. A true saint is never entangled in worldly illusions. This land is of Thakur Ramakrishna Paramahansa Ji If one is to learn devotion, who better than him? Who better as a Guru? What a devotion! This land has given two such priceless gems: Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, the incarnation of devotion itself, and Ramakrishna Dev. What devotion! Calling out to 'Mother', he would faint in ecstasy. How else can one detach from the world? Such pinnacle of devotion that uttering \"Mother\" once would induce samadhi. Today, we sit in that same place discussing devotion. This is the land of those great souls who taught us the importance of devotion. If darshan was not granted, they would weep, wail, pick up a sword: \"If Mother doesn't appear, I'll slit my throat.\" What level of devotion! That's why I say, those who don't know the essence of devotion - truly, I say - they are paupers. There is no one more pitiable in this world than one unaware of the importance of devotion. First, devotion must be selfless; second, it must be toward the Vast. How long will we remain limited to Baba's idol? How long confined to the statue of any deity? True devotion is when we transcend that and see His form in the entire Universe (His vast form). Wherever we look, only He resides. In every form, my Baba dwells. How can I engage in serving that Vast? How to serve Him? With all my strength, serve the person before you. Start from home, I always say. In our family, give comfort, respect, love, caring nature to all members. Live for them, die for them, sacrifice your selfishness Then, truly, in a few years, you will become worthy of exclusive devotion. Begin at home; if successful there, then extend outward. Wherever you see, Baba is there. In whatever form a person appears, an animal, an insect - my Baba resides in countless forms. Bow at their feet, provide whatever comfort you can. That is devotion in its vast form, devotion to the Vast. Baba says, you must reach there. Do not limit yourself to my picture or Shirdi. I do not dwell only in Shirdi. This entire universe is my form, the animate and inanimate is my manifestation. Devote to my Vast. Bow before my Vast form. Live and die for it. That is my true devotion. So, first, clarify what devotion is. And one who receives the gift of devotion knows its bliss. What state of emotion it is. Words cannot describe it. Impossible. Even Vedas and scriptures are silent on it. It is a matter of experience. Until experienced, it won't be understood. If I ask, what is the purpose of your life? Your goal? Target? Aim? It should come in a second: \"We want exclusive devotion to our Sadguru. We live for it, die for it.\" If answering takes more than a second, truly, we are not awakened. We lack full awareness. If it takes more than a second, One who knows its essence won't take a second. \"Exclusive devotion is what I want. I live for it, die for it.\" That will be the answer. Now, coming to the story of Anantrao Patankar in the 21st chapter. Because until that leela unfolds, I cannot lead you into Nav Vidha Bhakti. In the 21st chapter of Sai Satcharitra, there is the story of Anantrao Patankar. Anantrao Patankar is a scholar of scriptures. He has studied six shastras, four Vedas, Puranas, deepest philosophical knowledge - all understood. But his mind has not a moment's peace. So restless, beyond limits. And even read a lot of things, that too beyond limits. Perhaps for such people, Kabir Ji says, \"Pothi padh padh jag mua, pandit bhaya na koi. Dhai akshar prem ka, padhe so pandit hoi.\" If that devotion, those two-and-a-half letters of love and devotion, haven't descended into your heart, Then you are neither a pandit nor a human. Anantrao Patankar is such a boundless scholar, having read all necessary texts. But not a moment's peace. He wanders everywhere for peace, but finds none. Finally, fortune awakens, good days arrive, he learns of Baba, reaches Shirdi, has darshan, And with folded hands, prays from the heart: \"O Sadguru, What kind of life is this? I have interest in spirituality. I want to earn only spirituality in life. Live for spirituality, die for it. But, nothing has come to me. I am a mere pauper.\" With tears in his eyes, he says, \"These simple, innocent devotees bowed at your feet, the peace in their pure-hearted, guileless devotion that I see I have wasted my entire life seeking that peace, but it eludes me despite reading so much, sifting through scriptures. Grant my mind a few moments of peace.\" He begs Baba. And Baba, being Baba, Says, \"I will tell you a story. If you understand it, peace is yours.\" He says, \"Yes, tell me, Baba.\" So, Baba says, \"There was a merchant. Before him, a mare dropped nine dung balls. The merchant, being thirsty, ran and gathered all nine dung balls, and thus attained peace. The treasure of peace descended into his heart.\" He gets astonished \"What story is this? Who is the merchant? What is the mare? The mare dropped nine dung balls. He gathered them and gained peace\" He doesn't understand. So, he asks one of Baba's intimate devotees: \"What is this riddle Baba spoke?\" The devotee says, \"As far as my intellect comprehends, The mare is God's grace, and the nine droppings are symbols of Nav Vidha Bhakti. If you adopt Nav Vidha Bhakti in your life, if the ninefold devotion descends, the treasure of peace and bliss will enter your heart.\" He understands and fully accepts: \"Truly, in my life, I used 100% brain. But not at all the heart. What are heart's sensitivities? What are feelings? What are noble sentiments? Never stood before God shedding tears. A true devotee knows the value of those tears. He must have thought, 'I never lived the eight sattvic emotions, I never experienced the trembling, the tears, the melting of the heart that are signs of true love for God. I never experienced such sattvic states.' I gathered knowledge. Sharpened my intellect. But left my heart utterly impoverished. I never paid attention to my heart, mind, intellect. What are noble sentiments? What are emotions? What are feelings? I don't know. Baba's words pierced the heart, 'Baba has pinpointed it. Truly, I labor 100% on the external, but inwardly, I am a pauper.' So, Baba is right: from today, I must fill myself with devotional emotions. Then peace and bliss will come to my life. He understands it. The next day, sitting in Dwarkamai before Baba, Baba asks, \"Have you gathered the nine balls?\" Anantrao Patankar replies, \"Baba, where is my capacity to gather them by my own strength? Only if you shower mercy and grace will Nav Vidha Bhakti descend into my life. I pray from the heart, Baba, instill Nav Vidha Bhakti in my life. Once it descends, no troubles will remain in life. No desires for anything. I will feel complete every moment. Incompleteness will vanish from life. With no incompleteness, where is room for negative emotions like unrest?\" He prays to Baba and departs with blessings. Now, I ask one question: Baba gave an example, it's the story of the mare's dung. The mare excretes dung, and gathering the nine dung balls purifies the mind and brings peace. That's what the story says. So, what is the essence of this leela? Baba could have referred to some other 9 things, like giving Rs. 9 to Lakshmibai Shinde at his last breath. But why the story of the mare's nine droppings? Baba wants to tell us all: If you want devotion in life, you must become very humble, lay yourself down, bring yourself very low. No room for ego to raise its head. Those who know the essence and importance of exclusive devotion, if today Baba stands embodied before us and a mare drops nine dung balls right there, If Baba says, \"If you pick them up and eat them, I will instill Nav Vidha Bhakti in your life,\" not a second should be wasted in consuming them. Because one who knows the depth of Nav Vidha Bhakti, its essence, won't delay a second. Picking up is far; if Baba says eat, not a second's delay in putting it in the mouth. Such humility, such art of laying down, such egolessness, such self-abnegation until they come into life, Until you see the Divine in every atom, lay down without seeing differences in beings. Every person is greater than me. Every creature is greater than me. Because my Baba dwells in them. Until such humility arrives, Nav Vidha Bhakti won't enter life. So, Baba conveyed this. That's why the example of the mare's dung as a symbol. Otherwise, why need to pick dung? One must lay down that much, be that humble, attain that egolessness. Then it becomes possible. Nav Vidha Bhakti, otherwise it's next to impossible. Now, we come to the nine types of Nav Vidha Bhakti. What are the nine? You know: Shravana, Kirtana, Vishnu Smarana, Charana Sevana, Archana, Vandana, Dasyam, Sakyam, Atma Nivedanam. These are the nine types of devotion. The first is Shravana Bhakti. Shravana Bhakti is very important; that's why it's placed first among the nine types of devotion. If Shravana enters your life, you learn to live. If listening is understood, you learn to live. Whom to listen to? Where to give time? Whom not to listen to? If this clarity comes, you have won half the battle. Half the war won, because in Nav Vidha Bhakti, the first is Shravana Bhakti - listening. But the question is, whom will you listen to? The market is full, Overflowing with speakers. Everyone seems right. If there, you use your eternal discrimination and start listening to the right person. If by fortune, a right person enters your life and you listen continuously, you have won half the war. Half the task done. Not a small thing. Such true people come by great fortune. Very rarely. By great fortune, such people come. Shravana Bhakti Now, see this body. The body has many parts, right? Eyes, ears, mouth, nose, skin, hands, feet. Countless parts. But among all, which is the most important? If I ask, it's the mouth. If food enters the mouth, that energy reaches all senses. If no food for eight days, eyes won't see, Nose won't smell, Ears won't hear. Nothing. You'll faint. Each sense will start failing. So, just as to keep all body parts strong, food must enter the mouth, Similarly, if you want to fully instill Nav Vidha Bhakti in life, Shravana Bhakti is like the mouth. As the mouth is principal among parts, Shravana is principal in Nav Vidha Bhakti. You must listen to the right person. Connect with the right person. If that clarity isn't in your life, then it's not Shravana. As mouth among body parts, Shravana in Nav Vidha Bhakti. And here, it's not about speaking, but listening. Often in life, we have a bad habit: we speak more, listen less. But Shravana Bhakti teaches: speak less, listen more. Truly, I say, one who is sparing in speech, Eliminates 70% of problems before they arise. 70% of problems. One who speaks less, Eliminates problems before they enter life, because speaks less. The more one speaks, the more entangled. This is the fact. And before whom to speak? Whom to listen to - this clarity must be. If the person before you is even slightly better, bow your head and listen. That is Shravana Bhakti. Not necessary only to listen to God's glories. It becomes mechanical. No doubt, glorifying Him is primary, but beyond that, wherever you meet someone better in life, Close eyes, bow head, listen to that person's words from the heart. Give respect, because illuminating words are coming. There's a saying: As the company, so the color. If listening comes well, living comes. Here today, how many mothers, parents are sitting. They always complain to me: our child doesn't study. No matter how much we say, doesn't study. Don't bother so much. Befriend the child with the smart one in school or class. In six months, he will automatically start studying. Don't chase. Provide company. Firstly, company of a good person comes by great fortune. But if found, you can't imagine how beautifully it works. So, as company, so the hue. This is the fact. Half the journey is covered. If Shravana Bhakti, listening ascends- whom to listen? You listen to four people. First, your eternal discrimination must work: who is right? This one is right, that one too. Who is most right? Choice Because time is limited. Time is short. We all have limited time. So, one must choose. Listen to the best of best. Don't waste life. Sometimes, to measure a person's depth, to know or test it. If a friend or acquaintance, just ask one thing: \"In your life, who is the person in contact whom you respect greatly. See with ideal eyes.\" If answering takes 5 minutes, 2-3 minutes, know that their mind isn't purified yet. And if answers in seconds, rattles off four names, \"These are very good. A crore times better than me. One in office, one neighbor, one classmate.\" Know that, this person's progress no one can stop in this world. No one can stop. So, Shravana means not only listening to God's glories. I'm explaining a bit broadly, Because, when it comes to listening God's glories, you go to satsang, katha, you'll be influenced for that time, then home returning back into the world. I’m not talking about that. I'm talking of practical spirituality. 24/7 your spirituality must be alive. That's what I'm saying. Wherever a superior person appears, Lay down That is Shravana Bhakti. Now, for us, many people are there, but for us, the biggest source of Shravana Bhakti is Sai Satcharita. This is our source for Shravana Bhakti. About Sai Satcharitra, there's a verse in this 21st chapter. Verse 126 'Agadh Sainathancha mahima, Agadh tayanchya katha parma, Agadh Saicharitrachi seema, Moort parabrahmavatar' What a verse! This granth is called the incarnation of Parabrahma, and that too living Parabrahma incarnation. He says about this granth: 'Agadh Sainathancha mahima' The glory of Sainath is unfathomable, infinite, inaccessible, imperceptible. Not easily understandable, that glory is unfathomable. 'Agadh Sainathancha mahima, Agadh tayanchya katha parma,' Each story, leela is inaccessible, imperceptible, unfathomable. Perhaps you can measure the ocean's depth, but maybe not the depth of those leelas - so deep. 'Agadh Sainathancha mahima, Agadh tayanchya katha parma, Agadh Saicharitrachi seema,' and its boundary, The depth and boundary of each leela makes ocean's depth pale, sky's expanse insufficient. So, unfathomable is its boundary. And further: ' Moort parabrahmavatar' This granth is the incarnation of Parabrahma, and 'moort' means living. Live Guru Not speaking of person, not Baba's body, not his form - 'moort Parabrahmavatar' Speaking of this granth. Living Parabrahma. So, if we listen to this granth, try to understand its depth, Baba is ever-ready to explain that depth to us. So, this was Shravana Bhakti, first type of devotion. Very important. I say again, in Nav Vidha Bhakti, the first Shravana Bhakti is very important. If you embrace it well, the other eight come automatically. It's the engine. The train's engine. The other eight types of devotion are compartments. Just attach to engine. Compartments automatically follow the path. So, I call Shravana Bhakti the engine. This is the essence of Shravana Bhakti. Now, we take the second: Kirtana Bhakti. Very important devotion. As soon as we say Kirtana, our mind flashes to bhajans, kirtan, gathering, musicians, music, tabla - all that. No doubt, that's one way of Kirtana. Kirtana means glorifying, singing praises, extolling glories, describing virtues. So that our heart melts. Singing of glory is Kirtana. But now, the question is: When someone sings Kirtana or listeners, if they drown only in music, if music compels swaying, that's mere beginning of Kirtana. The tune is so good, what music, compels you to sway, shake, dance. Nowadays, in bhajan evenings, it often happens. People enjoy a lot. It's not wrong. But a mere beginning. Because the depth of the sung Kirtana must touch our heart. The singer must, after singing, explain the depth to the audience. Then, from body to soul, the Kirtana will reach; otherwise, it dies at the body. Are you understanding what I'm saying? This body, is the Kirtana with musicians, music creates atmosphere. Good. People sway, dance, whirl. Let it be. But that's temporary enthusiasm. Mere body. Soul untouched yet. Soul is touched when each word of Kirtana is understood. Its depth understood. We dive in its depth. Because Baba has a verse in 15th Chapter. Let me read it fully. 'Na ghade jeneni malakshalan, tyate kaay mhanave saban, Na kare je avidya nirasan, te kaay shravan mhanave' If a soap cannot wash body dirt, do we call it soap? Similarly, if someone narrates, tells, but its depth doesn't touch your heart, can you call it Kirtana or Shravana? Absolutely not possible. So, Kirtana means, The singer, definitely sing in rhythm, melody, well, because it has its own importance. When sung in rhythm and melody, it reaches hearts. But still, that's only body; not the soul of Kirtana. From body, subtler mind. From mind, subtler intellect. From intellect, subtler soul. So, there is a long journey. Kirtana must go from body to soul. It will only when each word stirs your heart. Depth comes to understanding. Heart melts. Tears flow from eyes. Then it blossoms. And in praising, don't be stingy. Whoever comes before you, who is superior, praise from heart. It is the sign of mind purification. That is Kirtana. Original Kirtana in my view. Because often we refuse to accept that superiors exist right before us. Ego doesn't allow. So, this is original Kirtana. And as for Guru's Kirtana, if we don't do it, we aren't human. Be so immersed in Baba's devotion That unaware, my tongue utters only His praise. I mention only Him. Whoever comes, I babble about Baba, unaware. I can't sit a moment without speaking of Baba. Any topic I talk about is Baba. Like Baba gave Rs. 55 to Haji Siddique Falke. That's the 55th sutra of Naradiya Bhakti Sutra. It says, once that devotion is attained, he sees only the Divine, everywhere. Heart desires only to hear Him. Only talk about Him. Only contemplate Him. If you have reached that state, you truly live Kirtana Bhakti. So, this is second: Kirtana Bhakti. Now, third: Vishnu Smarana. Understand this well. Vishnu Smarana is said. Not Vishnu Ratan (cramming) There is heaven and earth difference. In rote repetition, tongue is involved. But in remembrance, along with tongue, mind is involved. Here, Baba said remembrance of Vishnu, not rote repetition of His name. Clear: when taking the name, it must fully settle in mind and brain. Not rote name. Name remembrance. Because mocking this, Kabir Ji says: \"Mala pherat yug bhaya, Mita na man ka pher. Karka manka chod de, Man ka manka pher.\" What a couplet! Clarifies. He says, turning mala, an age passed, not one life, an age. Mala runs in hand. Not one life, many lives make an age. Look at the choice of words, \"Mala pherat yug gaya, Mita na man ka pher\" But mind is unchanged, not purified, not attained that state. \"Mala pherat yug bhaya, Mita na man ka pher. Karka manka chod de, Man ka manka pher.\" Drop the mala from your hand, learn to take name from mind. Let mind engage in name. You engaged only tongue. Tongue alone won't work. Mind must engage. And for that to happen, wherever mind is unnecessarily attached, withdraw it. Then mind will fix on Baba. Otherwise, it is impossible. And in another couplet Kabir Ji says, \"Mala to kar mein phire, Jeebh phire mukh mahi, Manwa to chahu disi phire, Ye to sumiran nahi\" What a clarity! Mala turns in hand \"Mala to kar mein phire\" Tongue turns in mouth - 'Om Sai Ram....'. \"Jeebh phire mukh mahi\" But mind roams the universe. \"Manwa to chahu dishi phire, ye to sumiran nahi\" This isn't remembrance. You're trapped. Wasting time needlessly. Engage your mind in that Name. Don't do duplicate name remembrance. Do, the original remembrance. So, Vishnu Smarana. And one more couplet of Kabir Ji, Kabir Ji says, \"Bheekh fakiri seekhni, Paniharin se seekh, Baat kare sakhiyan se, Dhyan gagar ke beech\" If Begging of fakirism, Bliss of dispassion, bliss of devotion—if to learn its manner,learn from pariharan. Who go to distant places, fill four-five pots on head, bring home water called pariharan. Learn from pariharan if depth of devotion to learn, Kabir Ji says They go with friends. Come with friends. Talk worldly. What I didn't say in Shravana, they do all. All talks. Every kind. My mother-in-law this, sister-in-law that. This problem, that neighbor this, that one that. Heard about him? His problem. This one's affair, that one's. All talks. But not a moment's distraction from the pot. \"Baat kare sakhiyan se, dhyan gagar ke beech.\" Attention on pot midst. Similarly, perform all worldly duties. Go office, do work. Fulfill home responsibilities. Care for children. But while doing all, not forget Sadguru for a moment. That is original Smarana Bhakti. \"Nainan andar aao to\" \"Nayan jhap to lun\" \"Nainan andar aao to, nain jhap tohe lu, na main dekhun Auran ko na tohe dekhan doon\" What Kabir Ji! Like a beloved says to lover: \"Nainan andar aao to, once come settle in my eyes\" \"Nain jhap\" meaning close eyes after you settle. And absorb you inside. \"Nain jhapi mund kar tohe lun\" take you inside. \"Na main dekhun auran ko\" because eyes closed, I won't see world. \"Na tohe dekhan doon\" nor let you see anyone. Authoritative voice. This is Smarana. What beautiful scene. Majnu is. Wandering desert calling Laila Laila. So mad in Laila's love, remembers nothing. But in same desert, perhaps prayer time. Faces Kaaba, sits in prayer. And Laila passes before him. He shouts: O infidel, O atheist! Don't you know someone is praying here? How can you pass before me? Majnu says: I am so lost in my Laila's love that neither world nor your God remembers. I was just going Laila Laila. But you sit in worship of that God who made my Laila. From Him, my Laila a crore times less, directly you worship the Lord, how did you notice someone passed before you? Head in prostration, surrendered to Lord, and mind on world. If this is worship, if this is prayer, my love is a crore times better. So he says. So he says. Then finally says: Head in prostration, mind on worldly thoughts. If such worship, brother, my love better than your worship. Words pierce the maulana, accepts: No, your love taught me worship. So, Vishnu Smarana not Ratana. Often, a person fully engrossed in Sadguru's memory.Completely immersed. But name not on tongue. It will do. Even if name not on tongue, but fully in contemplation. But name not on tongue, 100% fine. But name on tongue, if Baba not in mind, won't do. Name Smarana people take very technically. If you take name long time, it goes to ajapa state. Doesn't prove remembrance. You habituated tongue. So climbs tongue effortlessly. But mind engagement essential. That's why I say, even if their memory, remembrance, contemplation unbroken but name not on tongue, 100% fine. But name on tongue, singing bhajans, kirtan. But if not in unbroken contemplation of Sadguru, useless. But in unbroken contemplation of Sadguru even if name not on tongue, 100% fine. Ok? Meaning that's why not said name ratan. Said name smarana. Difference understood. Ok? Now fourth devotion. Three done: Shravana, Kirtana, Vishnu Smarana. Charana Sevana. For Charana Sevana, in 39th chapter, Baba gave long satsang on a Bhagavad Gita shloka, recorded in two chapters. Tad viddhi Pranipatena, pariprashnenaSevaya upadekshyanti te Gyanam , gyaninas Tattva darshinah . In that, Who has right to ask questions? Lord Krishna tells Arjuna, explains. One fully surrendered before me, laid down, humble, thirsty in mind to know. No ill intent to know. Not to test if this one knows. No right to ask with that intent. Ask with thirst, yearning to know. And then says, right to ask comes when you have pleased them by long service. Then you have right to ask. Today if such conditions imposed, neither speaker nor listener left. But Krishna says such deep thing. And Baba tells Nana Saheb Chandorkar: Service doesn't mean today my mind good, in mood, serve well. Today entangled in worldly troubles, in pain, skip. Not called service. My birth itself for Sadguru's service. One with such firm conviction understands fourth devotion: Charana Sevana. I play a video. Please watch carefully. From Ramayana. What is service? Understand well. Once I tell the context so you connect. Context: Kaikeyi asked two boons. Rama and Sita's exile fixed. Sita says I too go. Take her along. Younger brother Lakshmana comes. Insists: No brother, where you are, I am. Like shadow always behind you. Can't sit in palace. I too go. Then Sumitra Ji comes. Rama says: You insist on going to forest but what will mother Sumitra say? Then Sumitra Ji says what will Sumitra say? Where Rama is, there Lakshmana. You go means and you serve them unbroken. Teaching service dharma, mother Sumitra's advice to Lakshmana truly deep. \"You are going, son, but remember — the most difficult duty in the world is service.\" Wholeheartedly, its not that easy. Stay with them like shadow. Not leave them alone even a moment. Second If they have eaten, if something left, then eat. If they sleep, guard. And thorns on their path, pick with your eyelashes. Now, picking with eyelashes means what? So she says: crises coming in brother and sister-in-law's life, anticipate beforehand Keep intellect so sharp, understand crisis before it comes. This impending crisis tomorrow may trouble my brother and sister-in-law this way. So eliminate before reaching them. Be that alert. And that is service. And I want to say emphatically. Serving Baba's vast rather than idol worship, idol pooja—they will dance. Wherever see, only He. So this is Charana Seva, fourth devotion. In Guru Charitra second chapter, Deepak Akhyan. Superb story. No better example for service. Once disciple deeply connected to Guru. One day Guru tells Deepak: O Deepak Now I feel like going to Kashi. But you know why I go to Kashi? My sins are piled high. And those sins will wash only in Kashi. Kashi's Vishwanath will bedridden me for 21 years Make me ill, strike paralysis. I'll be paralyzed 21 years. Will you serve me? Deepak says: By your grace, definitely Guru Dev. Then come. 21 years, not one or two days And truly as said, body victim of paralysis. Struck lame. Bedridden, excrete in place, he cleans, bathes, dresses Grind flour, cook, feed Every service, and if not to Guru's mind, scolds Such is service. If no service, leave. But doesn't leave. Finally Shiva sees what service. Rushes down Stands before Deepak: I am so pleased with your Guru devotion. Ask what you want. Says: I want nothing. If truly you want to give, I want you heal my Guru Dev. Then thinks: Guru said came to Kashi to atone sins. Is his wish to heal or not, must ask. Tells Shiva Ji: Wait a minute, I ask my Guru Dev. Goes asks Guru Dev: Shiva Ji came. Gave darshan. Standing outside. Says ask boon. My wish: ask your health. Fool, if no service, leave. You'll destroy my merit. What I told? Must suffer 21 years. Want to escape my karmas. If no service, leave. But tell Shiva Ji leave. Poor one fears, goes pranams: Shiva Ji my Guru not agreeing, you go. Resumes service, same abuses, rejections but continues. Then after some years Vishnu Ji comes. Vishnu Ji says: Very pleased with your Guru devotion, ask what. Says: Last time Shiva came. Ate big scoldings. I want nothing. My Guru keeps me as is. Besides I can't ask even about my Guru. Now that's clear too, please go. No no, came so will give something. Ask something. Then Deepak says: Ok want to give? Today with what devotion faith I serve my Guru, give a crore times more devotion faith in Guru's feet so I serve crore times more. Just that said, Vishnu vanishes. Inner Guru stands . manifest: You passed the test. This is service. And service not mental, body too scorched. It's not that easy so this is Charana Seva. Not easy As Sumitra Ji tells Lakshmana, toughest dharma is service dharma. Fifth devotion: Archana Bhakti. See, Archana Bhakti is symbol of total surrender. Where everything offered to Divine, nothing left—that is Archana Bhakti. Because in others, one body part involved. In Smarana, mind; Shravana, ears; Kirtana, mouth. But in Archana, mind must concentrate. Body too, mind too, service happening, pooja happening. Imagine an idol worship is taking place, so you are bathing them, you are performing abhishek (ritualistic pouring of liquids) you are adorning them with clothes and ornaments, you are applying tilak, applying sandalwood paste with musk. So whatever it is, it must be done with complete devotion, with the mind, and you must completely immerse your body. So, in a way, Archana Bhakti (worship through offering) is complete devotion. The body is involved, the mind is involved, and wealth is also involved. What is called Sarvasva Sharanagati (complete surrender) comes under Archana Bhakti. Now, I'm just remembering an incident from some years ago. Some years ago, there were some people in our group who are connected to me. They were very intellectual. I won't take their names. They were highly intellectual, meaning their intellect worked very well. Their heart was also good, but they didn't have the habit of performing such rituals and worship. So, I called all three of them and told them that they would go to Shirdi, bring back Baba's padukas , and worship them every day. How much they are doing it, I don't know. But keeping their nature in mind, I told them this so that their body would also engage in the service of the Guru. This means, the devotion where body, mind, and wealth are completely engaged, that is Archana Bhakti. Complete. So, Archana Bhakti is not that easy. The worship of the deity's idol is not that easy. Everything gets involved in it. Now, look, I'll give an example. There is a producer who produces a film, who makes a film by investing crores of rupees. He has a story in his mind. So, he goes to the director. Then he tells the director that this is the story, \"I want to make a film. This is the subject.\" So the director says, \"Okay, it's a very good story. I'll take it.\" Then he selects the writers, he selects the actors, he selects the musicians, he selects the screenplay writers. So, after bringing all these people, he then narrates the story to the actor, saying, \"This is the story.\" He implants all the nuances into the actors, and in the end, he takes the performance from the actor. So, from the writer to the musician, from the producer to the director, where do all those people descend? They descend into the actor Because he has heard everything. He has absorbed everything \"The producer wants this, the director wants this, the cameraman wants this, the writer wants this. But when he internalizes everything and then gives the performance, that becomes the focal point/essence (Archan). It means all those things have come into the actor. Similarly, when all the goodness, all the emotions,knowledge, and devotion all descend into the body and flow out as the power of action (Kriya Shakti) at the feet of the Sadguru, that is Archana Bhakti. Complete devotion. So, after reaching that point, the next devotion is Vandana Bhakti (worship through salutation). Look, another meaning of Vandan is Naman (bowing). Bowing is Vandana Bhakti. We call bowing Vandan. But if we take Naman and split the word it is Na+Man. Meaning, not my mind, not my will. Your will. The day you begin to understand the will of the Sadguru, and start living according to it, even if you have to suppress your own mind, then you have entered Vandana Bhakti. Vandana Bhakti absolutely doesn't mean standing with folded hands or falling at the feet. No, that is very easy. It is very easy to drop your body like a log at the feet of the Sadguru. But to live by holding his will supreme, that is the original Vandana Bhakti. I hope I am able to explain it to you well. Na Man – not my mind, (1:14:18) not my will, Your will. The day this comes, consider that Vandana Bhakti has entered your life. And if you are living by holding his will supreme, then you are in Vandana Bhakti 24/7. Bowing for one moment is very easy, but you are performing Vandan 24/7,because you are living your life according to his will. And Dasya Bhakti (devotion as a servant). Kabir ji says about Das Bhakti (servitude) \"It is difficult to be called a Das (servant), I am the servant of servants. Now I have become like the grass under the feet.\" It is difficult to be called a servant, saying \"servant\" is truly difficult. I am the servant of even the servants. Now I have become so humble, like the grass under the feet.\" I have achieved such humility that I have become like a blade of grass which the world crushes as it walks over it. The whole world tramples over me. I have become that humble. That is Dasya Bhakti. It means Kabir ji is directly saying that even before becoming the servant of my Baba, I should become the servant of the servant of my Baba. I don't have the right to become Baba's servant directly. But the intimate devotee of my Baba, who is very closely connected to my Baba, I will become his servant. Then my Baba will be more happy. He will be more pleased. Just like, if you go to serve him directly, Baba turns you away. But if you go to serve his servant, he is overjoyed and starts dancing. The proof of this is the 11th chapter. Whenever any devotee had to go to Baba, they never went to Baba directly. They would first seek a recommendation from Shyama ji. They would make Shyama an intermediary, and only when they went with Shyama's support did Baba allow them inside . He would give permission So, in Dasya Bhakti, Baba is telling us that you won't be able to reach me directly. Those who are very close to me, who are among my very intimate devotees, you surrender to them. You will reach me very quickly. Let that humility enter within you. \"Now I have become like the grass under the feet.\" Let that much humility come inside you. You will see, I will be overjoyed and your work will be done quickly. But it is not easy to bring that much humility. That is also true. It is not that easy to bring that much humility. But if it comes, then the work will be done in a snap. So this is Dasya Bhakti. Now look, this was the seventh devotion. These seven types of the nine forms of devotion illustrate the effort of the devotee. Up to this point, it explains how the devotee must keep his mind and perform devotion. Up to these seven forms of devotion. Now, if a person has reached this far, the next two devotions that the Sadguru gives are the Sadguru's gift (prasad). It is the grace of the Sadguru. It is the reward from the Sadguru. This devotee has followed these first seven devotionsso well. So, as a result, the Sadguru is now giving a reward from his side, saying that this person has performed such high devotion as I wished. He has lived as I wished, he has done devotion as I wished. So, as a result, now I will honor him with two more devotions. And those are Sakhya Bhakti (devotion as a friend) and Atma Nivedanam Bhakti (self-surrender). This is a gift from the Sadguru. So the Sadguru says, \"From today onwards, you are not my servant, not my devotee, not my disciple, but I make you my friend (Sakha).\" He lifts the person who has fallen at his feet and embraces him. And says, \"From this moment, you are my friend. You are my friend.\" And who is saying this? God is saying it. Can you imagine? What is the meaning of being called a friend? If God Himself makes a devotee his friend, what is the significance of that? It means he lifts the person who was lying at his feet and embraces him, and says, \"Until today, you were striving, you were meditating on me, but from today onwards, I will meditate on you because you are my friend. And you have incurred a debt on me by performing those seven kinds of devotion again and again. You have put such a debt on me that now if I have to be free from that debt, there is only one way: O devotee, from today, I consider you my friend, and from today onwards, I will meditate on you.\" That is what being a Sakha is Je Je Animesh Chintit Sai, Prachiti paha chi Navlai, Svayam Sai tayasi dhyai Utarai, Tayachi This is the verse from the 37th chapter. It says, those who continuously meditate on the Sadguru, those who never forget the Sadguru even for a moment, I take the devotion of such people upon my head as a debt. And until I also meditate on you with the same continuous intensity, I cannot be free from my debt. This is the word of the Sadguru. And if he starts meditating on us like that, then we have become a friend. Now, why will he meditate like that? To make us like himself, to make us as complete as himself, to establish us in the form of Satchidananda like himself, he makes us a friend. \"From today onwards, my form is your form. My knowledge is your knowledge. My detachment is your detachment. My devotion is your devotion. Now there will be no difference between the two of us.\" Look at the couplet: Kabira maan nirmal bhaya, jaise Ganga neer. Piche piche Hari phire, kahat Kabir, Kabir. This is the Sakha. This is the true devotion. It means that by performing these seven kinds of devotion for years and years, the devotee has become so pure, so untainted, that now Hari (God) runs after me, calling \"Kabir, Kabir,\", he is remembering me. So this is Sakhya Bhakti. Now, why does he meditate on the disciple or the devotee? To give his completeness. So that there is no difference between the two. To establish non-duality (Advaita), to eliminate duality, that \"I and you are not separate. We are both one. I who am the complete Supreme Brahman, that is what you are. From today onwards, I give you the Soham Diksha (initiation into 'I am He'). So you keep experiencing that.\" So after that, he gives all his power and makes the devotee like himself. Making him like himself means that just as the Supreme Being is complete, he makes the devotee equally complete. And that is Atma Nivedanam Bhakti (devotion of self-surrender), the final devotion. Where the devotee and God are no longer separate. The disciple and the Guru are no longer separate. They become one. In the third chapter, there is a verse that says: Kitki se hi bhramar dhyan tene tilave bhramar ban (Just as the small insect meditating on the bumblebee, becomes a bumblebee itself) It means, the small insect meditating on the bumblebee, by humming along, flies away as a bumblebee itself. Similarly, the Sadguru, by meditating on the disciple, makes him a Sadguru. Makes him the lord of the universe. So that is Atma Nivedanam So, in a way, if you look at it, these nine forms of devotion include devotion, action, and knowledge; it is complete. If one can live it with great depth, then there are nine forms of devotion, but it includes action, knowledge, yoga, everything. But if we can live it with the same subtlety as it has been explained, then this is the Navavidha Bhakti. Sai Satcharitra Jaykara(cheering) Manohari, Shap-tap nivarani, Agnan nashini, Moksha dayini, Param kalyankari, Sachidanand pradayini, anant koti Sainathon ki janani, sakshat Sai swarupini, Victory to the supreme and divine text, Shri Sai Satcharitra, the mother of infinite Sai Nathas, the one who is the form of Sai Himself",

    "Transcript": "This is no ordinary book; it is luminous advice. Their own autobiography in their own words. Om Sai Ram Today we shall reflect upon one topic: 'Liberation for the garbed renunciate.' The story of the ascetic Vijayanand from the 31st chapter of Sai Satcharit - we have all read it. He set out from Madras. with the desire to undertake the pilgrimage to Manasarovar. He donned the garb of renunciation, but the true essence of renunciation was unknown to him. Such cases are common- many merely wear the ochre robe, while the essence of renunciation eludes them. Outwardly he had adorned the attire of a monk and embarked upon the journey to Manasarovar. This pilgrimage is exceedingly arduous- many who attempt it never return, losing their lives midway. At first, he was filled with zeal, but as soon as the journey begins, he gathers information about Mansarovar from people. They describe the various hardships along the path in detail, and his resolve weakens. He lacked the firmness of resolve. People intimidate him, saying the locals in Bhutan cooperate if you are native, but outsiders face great troubles. Languages change every fifty kilometers or so. Making the path to Mansarovar, extremely tough. \"Where are you heading?\" they ask, shaking him a bit, and the poor soul gets frightened. On his way, he heard the glory of Sai Baba that in Shirdi resided a great Saint of infinite compassion. He decides to seek Baba's darshan instead. Midway, he alights at Manmad and reaches Shirdi. Remember, whether a man is a householder or a renunciate, once a noble resolve is undertaken, it must be pursued with unshakable determination. Even if storms arise, obstacles abound, and hardships multiply, a vow must be honored at any cost. It should not be that a noble sentiment arose, a pure intention emerged in a moment of mood, but later, with some difficulties, it fades away. \"I will complete a saptah parayan\"-three days done, but on the fourth, problems arise, the resolve breaks. Many do this. It should not happen. A resolve is a vow, an austerity. And whenever such holy resolves are made, Maya will surely exert its influence. It will for sure, but one must not give up. Whether storms or tempests come, if the resolve is pure, for spiritual elevation, it must be fulfilled at any cost. This Sanyasi, though clad in the ochre robes, lacked the firmness in resolve.. A little discouragement from people and he wavers, forgetting the journey altogether.. Now, look- many still undertake the Mansarovar pilgrimage. The Kailash Mansarovar journey, from a gross perspective, is physically demanding even in that view. Excellent health is required, utmost fitness, unyielding determination. One must endure whatever physical hardships arise. Expenses must be borne, sleepless nights endured. Only then do you physically reach that lake. That is the gross journey. Now, Mansarovar also holds a spiritual meaning. Always remember, Mansarovar is at a great height, atop the peak. Like the Himalayas, where it is said sages and saints dwell on the summits, or Shiva resides on Kailash. These are all symbols, inner allegories. When our consciousness begins to ascend upward within us, it encounters various obstacles, struggles repeatedly, and reaches the Sahasrara. It is said that upon reaching the Sahasrara, there is a lake of nectar that drips drop by drop into your being, 24 hours a day. And it never ceases. Even if the universe is utterly destroyed, that nectar's taste is eternally savored. Those who attain that supreme state, becoming heirs to bliss. That is the true Mansarovar - the inner one. If you can undertake that long inner journey, that lake's nectar is yours. So, this is the original Mansarovar. When he (Sanyasi Vijayanand) arrives in Shirdi, he enters Baba's court. He spends some time there, witnessing the crowds of people, their devotional fervor toward Baba. He becomes enchanted by Baba, and his mind begins to immerse in Him. After a few days, he receives a telegram. It states that his mother was gravely ill and on her deathbed. Though, the story seems almost unreal, that the person about to go towards Mansarovar, alights midway and reaches Shirdi and he would have written home: \"I did not go to Mansarovar; I am at Sai Baba's court in Shirdi. This is my address.\" It seems fabricated, but the story is worth considering. The narrative in the 31st chapter of Sai Satcharitra states that he receives a telegram: his mother is critically ill. He falls back into attachment to his mother. However, by now, he has sensed that, everyone who comes to Baba's court seeks permission before leaving. He does not depart directly but thinks to ask Baba's consent. He goes to Dwarakamai and requests: \"Baba, a telegram has come - my mother is very ill, counting her final breaths. She must be remembering me every moment.\" \"Perhaps her last breaths are held back because of me. Please grant me permission to leave.\" Baba retorts sharply: \"You have stained this saffron garb. You have blemished the sanctity of the saffron robes. If you were so gripped by attachment and affection, why did you don this attire? Such attachment does not befit those in saffron robes. You should have remained a householder. Why don this garb? Why wear saffron? Why take renunciation?\" As soon as Baba sees him, He discerns: He speaks of his mother's final breaths, but he himself is heading in that direction. His life force could depart anytime. So, Baba instructs: \"Do one thing. Find a secluded spot in the wada(mansion) and recite the Bhagavat for three weeks.\" Baba does not permit him to go and adds: \"There are many thieves in the wada.\" If you read that Chapter attentively. \"There are many thieves in the wada, keep windows and doors closed, and then perform the Bhagavat recitation.\" Now, was he the only one staying in the wada? At that time, it was Sathe Wada, the only place for all devotees coming for Baba's darshan to stay. Did he have his own room? That he will keep all windows and doors closed, and will Baba grant him such permission. Baba simply has to say: \"O disguised one, until now you have given free rein to your senses, but heed my words. For these three weeks, close your senses - the windows and doors. Here, doors mean the mouth and genitals, taste and lust - these are two doors; and sound, touch, and smell - these three windows. Shut them all. Then, immerse yourself in the Bhagavat for three weeks, so that when your life force departs, you remain absorbed in Bhagavat contemplation.\" The man is unaware, but Baba has planned this for him: \"From today onward...\" And if Baba speaks with resolve, He will ensure those three weeks are fulfilled. Since these words issue from His lips, it becomes His resolve: \"I will not let him wander outside; I will restrain his senses from straying; I will turn him inward.\" Definitely, Baba accomplished this. For two weeks, he manages somehow, but in the third week, his body fails him. And around the 17th or 18th day, he departs his mortal coil. Yet, his final breaths must have ceased while immersed in Bhagavat reflection, we must assume so. But the question is about the words said by Baba: \"You have defiled the saffron attire; you have stained its pure hem.\" This is why people, in haste and enthusiasm, commit such acts but later regret profoundly. Kabir Ji says: 'Tan ko jogi sab kare, Man ko kare na koi, Sahaj sab siddhi paeye, Jo man jogi hoye' Clearly, he states: No need to flee the world; stay where you are and strive to make the mind a renunciate. Learn the art of detached enjoyment from Baba, as the maidservant of Kaka Saheb Dixit possessed that skill. 'Tan ko jogi sab kare, Man ko kare na koi, Sahaj sab siddhi paeye, Jo man jogi hoye' In another doha, rebuking false ascetics, Kabir Ji says: \"Becoming a sadhu is arduous, like the date palm tree.\" The date palm is tall; climbing it is immensely difficult. 'Sadhu kahavan kathin hai, Jaise ped khajur, Chadhe toh chakhe prem ras, Gire toh chaknachur' If one climbs up, by mastering the senses, subduing the mind, reaching somehow to the Sahasrara. Then he can taste the nectar of love. That is the soul's essence, the Mansarovar's nectar. He starts drinking it and that nectar drips 24X7. The entire universe may perish, but the dripping ceases not. That is the true nectar. If he ascends then he tastes the nectar of love, but if he falls he is shattered into pieces. Hence, do not toy becoming a sadhu. If you err as a householder, I may forgive you. But after donning the robes, no mercy for mistakes, for seeing your attire, countless souls surrender themselves to you. Thus, your errors become unforgivable. If you fall you are shattered into pieces. If you err while being a householder, perhaps I may forgive you. But if you err while in ochre robes, then you shall be shattered. In yet another doha: 'Prem bhaav ek chahiye, Bhesh aneek bajay' People adopt various forms - shave heads, grow beards, mustaches, don saffron robes. What is needed for? Let unwavering devotion to God settle within; that is required. No need for such attires. One needs singular love-devotion; unwavering bhakti is essential. What need to fashion diverse garbs? And if unwavering devotion descends into the heart, what difference if you dwell at home or in the forest? Whether living as a householder or wandering as a renunciate. But one thing must be common in both, that is unwavering devotion. If unwavering devotion has entered the heart, then even amidst the world, you create an inner forest. You are detached from all, non-attached, capable of detached enjoyment the Lord grants you that state. Then, it matters not if you are a householder among family and society, or have renounced the world. In both cases, you are richly blessed, for the true inner essence, the soul's reality, is in your grasp. That unwavering devotion is attained - what is most vital. If it is absent, if you are not inwardly enriched, then donning external garb of renunciation is futile; remaining a householder is also futile. Inward enrichment is essential. Kabir Ji conveys this through the doha: \"One needs singular love-devotion; unwavering bhakti is crucial.\" That is paramount, and unwavering bhakti means: Besides Your devotion, nothing else appeals to me. Then comes the verse from Naradiya Bhakti Sutra. 'tat prāpya tad evāvalokayati tad eva śṛṇoti tad eva bhāṣayati tad eva cintayati' Wherever I look, I see You, alone. Words from my tongue speak only of You. The mind, if contemplating, contemplates You alone. And if desiring to hear, it yearns only for Your glories. Beyond this, no relish remains in life. If you have attained that state, what difference if at home or in the forest? And if not attained that state, then both are futile. Household life and renunciation both are worthless. For the authentic essence eludes you. But this story: 'Liberation for the garbed renunciate' That means despite his flaws, this ascetic had assumed a showy renunciation. Yet, a Sadguru's compassion showers upon him; despite everything, in his final days, Baba proves supportive, adorning his end. But here is a slight exaggeration, that \"He attains liberation.\" I would not term it 'liberation'; I call it 'Noble progression' Liberation is a profound term. For one who realizes the soul, attains liberation. But sadgati (noble progression) is granted, definitely the next birth will dawn in light, without wandering. Some virtues must have been seen,. One more verse is there in the same chapter, Anyway, he was an ascetic, so the power of worship backed him. Baba engages him in worship: \"For three weeks, listen to the Bhagavat.\" And remember, if Baba declares, \"From today, you will do this,\" He invests His full power to make it happen. Mere words from His lips suffice- \"Krishna, you will do this\" Then we do not act; He compels. Because it is His resolve: \"I will accomplish this.\" Experience it in life - even in dreams, if Baba says, \"You will go there and do this,\" 101%. He ensure that it is done. You do not act; His resolve stands as strength behind you. So, if He told him, \"Stay in the wada and recite Bhagavat for three weeks,\" He would have orchestrated it excellently. No doubt. Mere issuance from His lips, the command fulfills, for it is His resolve. Just as the ascetic Vijayanand lacked seriousness, in his Mansarovar resolve. But a Sadguru's resolve is not like that. If something issues from a Sadguru's lips, it will manifest; He ensures it. So, this was the story of a garbed renunciate Baba touches upon such untouched facets through him, granting us profound illumination. The ascetic Vijayanand then departs his body, and his final rites occur in Shirdi, before Baba Himself. A proverb prevails: Whoever departs their prana before a Sadguru attains liberation. See, in this very chapter, a far superior character appears- Balaram Mankar. He must have attained liberation- 101%, for he had conquered the senses and even subdued the mind. Baba immerses him in deep meditative states, and death follows. Thus, liberation is his right - no doubt. But for the ascetic Vijayanand, 101% if not liberation, Baba certainly granted a noble progression. The next birth will be far better; the journey resumes from where it halted. He will be born with devotion, that is sadgati, the auspicious path. The supreme, pure momentum. I term it sadgati. So, this was the story of the garbed renunciate, Vijayanand. O Mind-Enchanting One, Remover of Curses and Suffering, Destroyer of Ignorance, Bestower of Liberation, The Supreme Giver of Auspiciousness, Embodiment of Truth, Consciousness, and Bliss, the Sacred Mother of countless embodiments of Sai. the True Form of Sai Himself Victory to the Divine Scripture: Shri Sai Satcharita.",
