    "Title": "साई से बढ़कर सद्गुरू कौन ! - By Krishnaji",
    "URL": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wSaVdS67CKc",
    "Transcript": "This is no ordinary book; it is luminous advice. Their own autobiography in their own words. Om Sai Ram 'Who could be a greater Sadguru than Sai?' While everyone proclaims, Sai Baba as \"Sadguru\" 'Sachchidanand Sadguru Sainath Maharaj ki Jai' But, in reality, only a rare few among millions truly bestow upon Baba the exalted status of Sadguru. They can be counted on the fingers. Because the privilege to call Baba our Sadguru is granted only when His heart unfolds before us, when we truly comprehend His divine will. The moment we are permitted entry into His sacred heart, He becomes our authentic Sadguru, and we transform into His devoted disciples. Until that access to His heart is attained, until His intentions are fully grasped, He remains not our Sadguru; we are neither true devotees nor genuine disciples We merely utter hollow praises: 'Sachchidanand Sadguru Sainath Maharaj ki Jai.' Yet, we fail to grasp it's profound essence. It is vital to understand His heart, to sense the deep longing within it, to discern His sacred will. Otherwise, an immense divide persists. We just declare verbally that He is Sachchidanand Sadguru, but to be completely forthright, He has not yet become our Sadguru. Mere utterance is one matter; genuine inner resonance is another. Countless, millions chant the slogan: 'Sachchidanand Sadguru Sainath Maharaj ki Jai.' But in truth, is He truly our Sadguru? To be very honest, He is merely a nomadic seeker. For we pursue devotion according to our own desires, without any inclination to understand His will. As long as we engage in worship driven by our personal whims, He remains a wanderer, not a Sadguru. Consider chapter thirty-two - without it, Guru Purnima remains incomplete. Baba narrates: I, accompanied by three fellow aspirants, ventured forth in pursuit of Brahma Jnana. Though, that this is a profound allegory Why would Baba, the very embodiment of Parabrahma, need to seek Brahma Jnana? Nevertheless, to enlighten us, He often descends to our humble level, crafting parables to illuminate our path. Thus, Baba recounts: I set out on the quest for Brahma Jnana, accompanied by my three companions. We sought to achieve it solely through our own prowess. We were steeped in conceit, convinced that we required no guidance. We had delved into the scriptures on our own terms. One extolled karma as supreme, another yoga, yet another pure knowledge. But Baba discerned otherwise: Bookish wisdom alone yields no fruit without an enlightened Guru, at whose lotus feet we offer total surrender. Only then can He unveil the authentic nature of Brahma Jnana. Hence, Baba yearned for such a Guru to whom He could fully surrender, while the other three roamed aimlessly, armed only with textual erudition. They wandered relentlessly into a forest - so impenetrable, confined, and enveloped in thick vegetation that not even a single beam of sunlight could pierce through. This forest represents the cosmos itself, this worldly realm, where even a solitary ray from the Sadguru's heart eludes us. We, too, are adrift in this dense forest, untouched by the Sadguru's radiant grace. At last, mercy awakens in a nomad. Witnessing the four lost souls, the nomad inquires: Where are you bound? The three companions deem it irrelevant: What concern is our profound quest to this nomad? He lacks a stable home, drifting from place to place - why disclose to him? They brush aside the query, affording him no reverence. They declare: \"We embark on such a lofty pursuit; what could this nomad comprehend of Brahma Jnana? He is a restless wanderer of forests, unsteady - why reveal our intent?\" They withhold the truth, depart, and resume their wandering. Yet, they circle endlessly, like one trapped in a loop, inevitably returning to the origin. Those who tread the spiritual path without a Guru exert tremendous effort- they toil, perspire, struggle, and immerse themselves fully - yet their journey doesn't progress. Baba illustrates this as meandering within the forest, in circles: Despite exhaustive labor, they arrive back at the starting point. The nomad remains steadfast and advises: Has discernment now arisen? The trail you follow is so constricted, riddled with deceptions, illusions- this maya-laden world, akin to an impenetrable thicket. Without a pathfinder as companion, the voyage is unattainable. Accept my counsel now. Behold, the sun scorches overhead; I possess scant provisions - a simple dry bread and chutney. Partake of a few morsels and continue onward. The three companions, Baba's fellow seekers, grow even more indignant: Not only does the path evade us, but this nomad persistently obstructs, afflicting us in novel ways. Yet, his entreaty flows from pure, selfless affection: Surely hunger and thirst assail you - accept the humble sustenance I offer, quench your thirst with my water. Still, the three refuse and depart. Baba ponders: What ulterior motive could this soul harbor toward me, that he perceives my hunger, my thirst, and tenderly offers his own provisions with love? Where selfless love cascades freely, where an individual bestows affection without any expectation, that verily is the sanctuary of the Guru. Baba humbly prostrates before the nomad. The nomad presents a quarter portion of the bread - regarded as one-fourth - and Baba accepts it. This quarter symbolizes: The aspirant's yearning for Brahma Jnana is so profound that all worldly allurements and sensual pursuits equate to mere fragments, like a quarter bread. One dwells in the material realm only nominally, with complete orientation toward the divine. Consuming a quarter bread signifies: This soul eats solely to sustain life, not living merely to indulge in eating. He partakes of the quarter bread and sips the water. The parable unfolds: Behold the metaphor, the exquisite craftsmanship of Sai Satcharitra! No sooner does He honor the nomad's guidance, consume the quarter bread, and drink the water, than the Gurudev reveals Himself. What a sublime allegory, what a masterful conveyance! The Gurudev manifests. In the narrative, at the chapter's inception, they affirm: We possess no Guru; we venture to attain Brahma Jnana through our own might. Evidently, all four, Baba included, aspired to realize it independently. Yet abruptly, the Guru appears - not in imaginings, not in visions, unbound to any form. How so? The tale articulates plainly: While they disregarded the nomad's counsel, he remained a mere nomad; but the instant his will was enshrined upon their crowns, the nomad transcended into the Guru. The individual unaltered, the appearance unchanged, the essence immutable- yet the disciple's heart undergoes metamorphosis. From an ordinary wayfarer to a sanctified disciple, for he begins to intuit the Sadguru's will and dissolves his own into it, offering complete oblation. In that sacred juncture, the ordinary devotee elevates to a true disciple; thus, the nomad ascends to Sadguru, and the humble seeker becomes the illumined one. Because, he understands His will, and everything was surrendered in accordance with that will. In this era, multitudes flock to Shirdi's Samadhi Mandir for Baba's divine darshan. For 99.999% of them, Sai Baba is not the Sadguru but a mere nomad. I utter a harsh verity: For 99.999%, Sai Baba is a nomad, not the Sadguru. Those who truly know Baba's heart, who feel the profound yearning pulsating within it, who perceive His divine intent - and harbor the fortitude to reshape themselves in harmony with it, no matter the tribulation - resolve: From this day forth, even if I must vanquish my ego at every breath, subdue my desires moment by moment, I shall align with Your will. The instant such capability dawns in the soul, that very moment the individual becomes a true disciple, and Baba, who until then appeared as a nomad, reveals Himself as the Sadguru, the Sovereign of the Cosmos. This is a profoundly layered parable, and Guru Purnima attains fulfillment only through immersing in the depths of chapter thirty-two. We are all familiar with this narrative, and even if I were to expound upon it until my final breath, it would still seem insufficient. It imparts timeless wisdom. Whenever we enter the Samadhi Mandir, may the illumination from this satsang inspire introspection: In truth, is Baba a mere nomad to me, or my Sadguru? If His will is unveiling itself, if the longing of His heart resonates within me, then undoubtedly He is the Sadguru; otherwise, a profound chasm endures between us - a barrier in communication. It is akin to a South Indian conversing with a Chinese counterpart: Each speaks in their native language, dialogue ensues, yet mutual understanding eludes them entirely. They could converse lifelong without comprehension. Such is our connection with Baba Neither does the language of the world penetrate His realm, nor does His divine expression reach us. Consequently, Baba is compelled to declare: \"I dwell in none of them.\" Chapter 25 Until our hearts converge as one, how can the principle of non-duality be established? Vedanta expounds the supreme non-duality: I am the Absolute Whole. Without the Sadguru's heart revealing itself, such realization remains unattainable. It's impossible. To forge the sacred bond between Guru and disciple, it is indispensable to fathom the Sadguru's will. Absent that, Sai Baba lingers as a nomad. Presenting such unyielding truths, such poignant realities, often offends many - they withdraw from us. Indeed, countless individuals, invoking Baba's name, proclaim: It is through you that we offer prayers to Baba; we intercede with Baba for your afflictions. They deliver uplifting discourses and produce videos incessantly, asserting: Today, Baba has instructed me to convey this to you; this is Baba's directive that I share. Baba discloses everything to them - save the profound depths of Sai Satcharitra. While He claims: I am the very essence of Sai Satcharitra; beyond that, all else is revealed. Hence, I reiterate: Baba's spiritual profundity must illuminate the world; otherwise, this charade perpetuates. Until the genuine currency circulates, counterfeit coins dominate the market. Someone must hoist this banner. I recognize the immense adversity involved - the profound trials one must endure. Having embraced this mission today, I am acutely aware of the multifaceted pressures that arise. Yet, truth remains truth - it must be proclaimed. Though it may irk many eyes, it demands expression; how else shall clarity dawn? Baba affirms: I have woven the entire profundity of Vedanta into Sai Satcharitra. If Vedanta upholds non-duality - 'O living soul, you are Shiva; O individual self, you are the Supreme- Sai Satcharitra, through its windings and turns, guides us to that zenith. Sai Satcharitra imparts that exalted truth, yet we crave no such elevation. We seek fleeting remedies. First and foremost, a profound chasm exists between a saint and a Sadguru- a distinction the world may never fully embrace; I know not when. Between an ordinary saint and a Sadguru spans the expanse of earth to heaven, a stark reality the world may long resist. For the world attains only the vantage of a common saint, comprehends only a saint's depths- but a Sadguru soars immeasurably higher. Thus, myriad questions emerge. Behold Kabir's doha, how it clarifies with crystalline precision: 'Teerath gaye te ek phal, Sant mile phal chaar,' 'Sadguru mile anant phal, Kahat Kabir vichaar' Kabir elucidates unequivocally: The Sadguru confers boundless blessings, a realm far, transcending saints. A saint, having experientially realized the soul, can attest: I traversed this path to attain that realization; if you follow likewise, you too may arrive. Such clarity he imparts, provided he himself has attained soul-realization. The minimal requisite for sainthood is, the direct experience of the soul. I am not this body, I am the eternal self; this illumination, coupled with a purified consciousness. If these attributes reside within, that soul is a saint. Yet, as Kabir proclaims: Sadguru yields infinite fruits, reflects Kabir. The Sadguru is He who has encompassed the entire creation within Himself, who permeates every atom - omniscient, omnipresent, omnipotent. A saint transcends maya; a Sadguru subjugates it, wielding it under His command. I delineate the distinction: A saint is one whom maya, in mercy, releases- vowing henceforth to ensnare him no more. But He who conquers maya, mastering it utterly - that is the Sadguru. Until this is internalized, inquiries will persist. Kabir voiced a doha, and those attuned to saints - whose reach extended to saintly hearts but faltered at the Sadguru's essence - grew resentful toward Saint Kabir. The provocation? He declared: 'Sur nar muni jan devata, Brahma vishnu mahesh,' 'Uncha mahal Kabir ka, par na paave shesh.' These celestial beings, mortals, sages, deities - Brahma, Vishnu, Mahesh - diminished, while Kabir asserts: My palace towers beyond all, inaccessible even to Shesha. This is the utterance of a Sadguru. Such profound declarations elude ordinary grasp. They branded Kabir egotistical, yet he had ascended to that sublime state- mere mortals could not perceive it. Kabir's palace towers; Shesha finds no passage - that is the Sadguru's exalted domain, vastly surpassing sainthood. We can apprehend saints, their dispassion, devotion, wisdom, inner purity resonate with our souls. But a Sadguru's demeanor is so extraordinary that our intellect falters, transcending its boundaries. Hence, doubts proliferate. Nonetheless, Sai Baba is the Sadguru, not a mere saint. Returning to the core theme: Sai as the quintessential Sadguru. 'What are the hallmarks of a Sadguru?' From Sai Satcharitra, chapter forty-eight. [Marathi Verse] A seeker inquires whether Sai Baba is an ordinary Guru or the Sadguru. Ensuing qualities unfold. Therein, it is stated: One proficient in studying the Vedas, masterful in the four Vedas or the six Shastras- The six Shastras encompass: Nyaya, the art of logical reasoning to discern truths; Vaisheshika, profound inquiry into the material universe as atomic essence; Sankhya, the science of self-realization - as exemplified in the Bhagavad Gita's second chapter, Sankhya Yoga, overflowing with soul-wisdom; if its approximately seventy-two verses truly permeate the heart, the remaining eighteen chapters become superfluous; Then, Yoga, mastery over the mind; Mimamsa, elucidation of ritualistic actions and their fruits - performing such karma yields corresponding outcomes; and Vedanta, the distilled nectar of the Vedas, embodying the Upanishad's depths, focused exclusively on the soul, the Supreme, and Omkar - self-knowledge and ultimate reality. Nyaya, Vaisheshika, Sankhya, Yoga, Mimamsa, Vedanta- These are the six Shastras One who imparts this scriptural wisdom verbally is not deemed Sadguru. Even one who elucidates Vedanta through intellectual grasp, devoid of personal realization- wise ones do not call him Sadguru. [Marathi Verse] Some cultivate pranayama, retaining breath for hours, wise ones do not call him Sadguru. Others endure scorching seals upon their forms - imprinting heated copper emblems as austerity, a debased practice of that age - knowledgeable souls deny them as Sadguru. Those who used to endure scorching seals. Those reciting verses on Brahman, bestowing transient delights, enlightened ones do not recognize them as Sadguru. [Marathi Verse] Initiators who bestow scriptural mantras like 'Om Namah Shivaya', prescribing japa methods, yet ignorant of fruition's timeline - neither master nor disciple knows; such illusions enlightened ones call them not even Guru. [Marathi Verse] One who discourses on ultimate truth with eloquent fluency, yet whose verbal wisdom lacks assurance faltering, uncertain, bereft of experiential depth even in the slightest, mere superficial oration, akin to a barren drought in realization and experience. Verbal husk alone. It is just verbal husk, devoid of experience. [Marathi Verse] Here, it is unequivocally clarified: To embody Sadguru, two attributes are essential, comprehensive mastery of scriptures and Vedanta, capable of resolving any query instantaneously, even at midnight; versed in every sacred text. Complete knowledge and profound lived experience. Solely He who excels in both, is a Sadguru and holds the authority to awaken disciples. So, these two qualities must be present, A consummate verbal scholar, enriched by experiential wisdom, not mere rhetoric, but embodied truth. Command over the six Shastras, Vedanta in totality, graced by Saraswati for eloquent expression, and empowered to transmit direct experience. Such a one clasps the hand, guiding with resolute force along the path - that potency defines Sadguru. A saint merely indicates: I attained this pinnacle via this route; traverse it thus, and you may reach my station. But the Sadguru seizes the collar, propelling forward, an abyss of difference. This is the fundamental distinction. [Marathi Verse] What lines, these verses stirred the spiritual realm It does not happen that way; in reality, the truth is something else. For reality diverges; Baba articulates otherwise. One lacking personal realization - what enlightenment can he confer upon disciples? To bestow ten rupees, one must first possess them. He remains destitute; how can he enrich others? Devoid of experience, barren of that inner unveiling - what will I offer to the world? What will such a person give to his devotees, He himself is destitute, how will he enrich others? Furthermore: Sans the direct realization of 'I alone pervade the entire cosmos'- how can He elevate devotees to that sublime state? One imparts only what one holds; if he doesn't have it, from where will he give. Observe this verse. [Marathi Verse] No service is sought from disciples, not even in dreams. be it physical, mental, financial, adulation, or acclaim. If accepted, purely for the recipient's upliftment. Baba drew funds compellingly, yet solely for devotees' spiritual welfare, channeling them aptly - never for personal need. It is clearly written, No anticipations from disciples, not even in reverie financial aid, bodily labor, intellectual service, flattery. Worship, hymns, not even in slumber does He crave such. Conversely, the Sadguru, in return, consecrates His entirety to the disciples - body, mind, wealth. When exigency demands, He sacrifices His very life to consummate their existence, as Baba did for Tatya Patil. That is Sadguru. These hallmarks must course through our being like vital essence upon invoking 'Sadguru' These verses should flow through our bloodstreams- it is the definition of Sadguru. Unequivocally it is said: No service anticipated from disciples, not in dreams - not even commendation. Instead: How may I dissolve myself for the disciple's sake? How merge day into night in their service? He is the Sadguru [Marathi Verse] A Sadguru is the one who harbours no such ego as, \"The disciple is insignificant, ignorant, and foolish, and I am the pinnacle of wisdom.\" Rather: This being is as perfect as I am; veiled only by illusion. Should I lift that shroud, we are unified. One with such luminous insight, and the capacity to bestow it - that is Sadguru. Never, even fleetingly, viewing the disciple as inferior, ignorant, debased, fallen- such contemptuous notions absent from His consciousness. Instead, discerning the Absolute Brahman in every entity, igniting rays of hope: With proper guidance, this soul shall awaken. Extending unwavering trust to disciples, dispelling maya's veil - they too are as whole as I am. The one with such clarity is the Sadguru. [Marathi Verse] Thus perceiving, He nurtures paternal affection toward disciples - No, I affirm, billions-fold intensified. Expecting no sustenance from them, not even in dreams - for His upkeep, no aid solicited. Such a Sadguru is the zenith of excellence in the universe. When do these virtues manifest? Contemplate: If the disciple embodies selfless service, Nishkama Karma Yoga- performing every deed with detachment and purity - then, upon attaining Sadguru-hood, these qualities arise innately. For the seed of selflessness is planted during discipleship. So, when he becomes the Sadguru he will behold this level. Hence, I emphasize repeatedly: Nishkama Karma Yoga, propels spiritual ascent with meteoric velocity Absent this seed in the disciple, whence in the Sadguru? The same essence evolves into Sadguru; if the odyssey is rooted in selfless action, only such sublime Sadguru emerges - lesser is inconceivable. It's impossible. [Marathi Verse] The Sadguru, supreme in creation, exalted across the cosmos. Among myriad Sadgurus, this one reigns preeminent. Yet, for such attributes to bloom: As disciple - prior to Sadguru attainment the aspirant must recognize the universe as the Guru's expansive manifestation. Revering every footfall, serving all beings as His cosmic form. If sadhana is imbued with such sanctity, then upon becoming Sadguru, this exalted stature is attained. Because, A neem seed yields a neem tree, not mango. Similarly, if selfless karma was embodied in discipleship, sublime Sadguru results - otherwise, unattainable. Yes, one concluding verse: [Marathi Verse] He whose heart eternally abides in supreme tranquility, untainted by pride in erudition, wisdom, or realization. Regarding even the humblest creature with enduring hope: \"This too is as perfect as I am, merely ensnared in maya's web; if I liberate it, equality prevails\" The one who perpetually indwells such sentiments- is the Sadguru. Hemadpant declares: These principal traits of the Sadguru, which profoundly touched my soul, I placed before you - from chapter forty-eight, verses one to fourteen. Extraordinary verses that elegantly define Sadguru. What occasion surpasses Guru Purnima for absorbing these sacred utterances? There is a vast gulf between an ordinary saint and a Sadguru. We are immensely blessed to have encountered such a Sadguru. The regrettable irony: We prove unworthy of being a true disciple. We evade comprehending His will, dissipating our entire existence in superficial, fake emotions. Merely marking presence: Baba, I have arrived What now? It is but fervent impulse, blind enthusiasm. If the yearning of His heart evades our grasp, we remain leagues apart. I invoke Baba ceaselessly, yet eons distant from Him. Behold the poignant paradox: A lifetime devoted to chanting Baba, yet eternally separated. Baba laments: I expended My utmost to unveil My will, yet you never attuned to it, persisting in your self-willed devotion. It is acceptable, not erroneous - but neither is it authentic. If true devotion exists, it demands perceiving My will. Every verse in Sai Satcharitra embodies My intent, affirms Baba. Until you immerse in it with that reverence, enshrine it in your heart, and evolve accordingly- you shall not attain Me. An immense void will endure between us perpetually. Now, additional hallmarks of the Sadguru, gleaned from various chapters of Sai Satcharitra- I have curated a few to elucidate further. I'll take some verses, to provide the clarity on 'What is the yearning of a Sadguru?' Chapter 13, Verse 73 [Marathi Verse] Recently, we had released a short on this. Immersed ceaselessly in tribulations, submerged neck-deep in the ocean of immense sorrow. Whosoever ascends the steps of Dwarakamai shall assuredly ascend the throne of eternal bliss. He yearns to bestow upon us the ultimate wisdom, yet first seeks to extricate us from prolonged agonies, to elevate us from abysmal suffering. Where else might one find such a compassionate Sadguru? For He knows: However profound the Vedanta I aspire to infuse, it is presently unfeasible- this soul is mired in afflictions, ensnared by maya's grip. First, I must liberate it from those chains, alleviate its worldly burdens. Only then can I, pour forth Vedanta's depths. Who embodies greater Sadguru than He who harbors such tender mercy? Another verse from chapter ten, number fifty-eight: [Marathi Verse] Beholding His disciples entangled in worldly fetters, His heart overflows with profound compassion, When shall this one transcend corporeality? How shall I guide it beyond bodily identification? When shall I acquaint it with its true essence? This concern engrosses Him day and night. Such is the hallmark of the Sadguru. He resides not to gratify mundane cravings - initially, He may offer enticements like sweets, yet not eternally. If He dispenses confections lifelong, He cannot be the Sadguru. Clarify this first. If He fulfills every whim, legitimate or otherwise - every demand - He forfeits Sadguru stature. Then it's maya. But even maya refrains; sometimes granting, sometimes withholding - thus entrapping. Then how could the Sadguru do so? At times Maya bestows happiness and at times sorrow. If Maya doesn't grant all your wishes then how will Sadguru? It's impossible Observing the disciple ensnared in earthly bonds - familial ties, lustful impulses, vices, sensory indulgences- His heart dissolves in anguish. We languish in ignorance; Baba endures the torment. This is the hallmark of Sadguru. We languish in ignorance; Baba endures the torment. Another verse, perhaps from chapter twelve: As butter liquefies in flame's warmth, But Sadguru is that butter who melts not from personal trials, but from witnessing others' plight. Such a declaration emerges. Here, we wallow in ignorance, cloaked in desires, perishing amid vices, shackled by worldly attachments- yet Baba suffers. 'Immersed in contemplation for His devotees' welfare' When shall liberation dawn for them? When moksha? When shall they too experience My wholeness? Twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week, absorbed in this vigil. What greater attribute for a Sadguru? Blessed with such an unparalleled paragon, the crown jewel among saints and Gurus- yet if salvation eludes us in Sai Baba's presence, no soul in the universe is more ill-fated. A third verse from chapter five, number nineteen-three: [Marathi Verse] Our inner arrogance, all latent desires, diverse inclinations - unique to each soul. No two minds mirror identical dispositions; some tendencies predominate in one, others in another. Baba declares: Transforming those manifold inclinations into sacrificial offerings, like kindling for the blaze. [Marathi Verse] Worldly propensities as complete holocaust, ignited with discerning application. 'Yukti prayukti' - such masterful terminology. Not every transformation is feasible at once; gauging the moment: Presently, this much can be purged from within. Seizing the opportune context: Now, I can enact this divine play; now, administer this measure of refinement. The ego has reached a nadir - I may intensify the rigor. Or, excess severity now might cause flight. Such acuity: Yukti prayukti, an exquisite expression. Even in kindling, He employs profound artistry administering precisely the treatment sustainable, lest excess prompts abandonment. How much heat can be endured? Precisely that - neither excessive nor deficient. 'Yukti prayukti.' Why Sadguru ceaselessly endeavors 24x7 on our behalf? What will He attain? We can only envision In the vast cosmos, if a Sadguru exists, He must embody such boundless compassion. [Marathi Verse] If a mother were to rebuke her child, casting it aside with disdain; if the ocean repudiated the rivers, returning them whence they came - though both are impossibilities. A mother could never spurn her offspring, nor the ocean reject its tributaries. Yet, if such improbabilities occurred, only then could I distance Myself from you, only then inflict harm upon you. Explicitly: Your transgressions are not so grievous that My blessings cannot encompass them. You are incapable of committing sins beyond the reach of My grace. However vast your faults, My compassion surpasses them infinitely. Through this verse, Baba reassures us: Your transgressions are not so grievous that My blessings cannot encompass them. You cannot arrive at a realm where My mercy falters. No such domain has been fashioned by the Divine. Wherever you stray, even in the gravest iniquity, My compassion shall manifest. If a mother spurns her child, if the ocean repels the rivers - then alone shall I forsake you, then alone cause you detriment. As those dual impossibilities cannot transpire, so too am I incapable of abandoning you. No matter the magnitude of your sins, in My sanctuary - forgiveness awaits, and embrace you, renewed faith: This soul shall redeem itself. Indirectly conveyed. Such attributes: Overflowing with mercy, meriting the Sadguru mantle. Another verse: [Marathi verse] Baba, in His embodied form, addressed devotees prior to departing the physical realm. Harbor no anxiety that one day I shall vanish from your midst, departing this world - entertain no such notion. My corporeal frame may dissolve, though My body perishes, My eternal spirit shall forever remain vigilant for your welfare. Beyond that: My bones, even if interred and merged with the earth, If My body perishes, My soul will not, I am an the eternal soul. I manifested in this body on my will, and will leave it in the same way. but My true form is present now and will be present even after. It will not perish. My bones, even if interred and merged with the earth, shall lament, yearn, and immerse in your concerns. Not merely I - My very bones shall articulate words for your upliftment, emanating from the samadhi. A deeply resonant verse, unveiling the Sadguru's profound yearning toward devotees, our well-being consumes Him. If we disregard these truths, persisting in arbitrary devotion- then our souls never united nor will they ever. So, these verses explain the yearning of a Sadguru for His devotees and their welfare. He exists not solely to satiate desires, the world regards Baba as an emergency rescuer. Afflictions strike, hasten to Shirdi. As if He idles otherwise, poised to fulfill every justified or unjust plea - predominantly the latter, frivolous. If genuine, perhaps mercy grants; unjust - how possibly? Should He concede the unjust, He ceases to be Sadguru. For that instance leave Sadguru. Consider a child afflicted with gastric infection - taken to the physician. The doctor admonishes the parents foremost: You indulged endless chocolates. He is a small kid anaware of what to eat and what not. He demanded for it and you gave him, now an infection is ensued. Now medications and austere diet for six months is required to restore his health. After that, Awakened parents, if the child demands chocolate, respond with firm denial - perhaps a gentle rebuke. If an ordinary parent discerns what to grant or withhold. Would the Sadguru not know? Will He fulfill all our wishes? A common guardian recognizes excess imperils life, Then for a Sadguru it is impossible to fulfill every unjust entreaty. If truly essential, perhaps conceded - but He foresees: This fulfillment ignites further cravings. Sadguru comprehends: One desire unchecked spawns a cascade - next visit bears an extended ledger. Now, He has to work on it too. One desire unchecked spawns a cascade - next visit bears an extended ledger. Yet, He also perceives: Denial precludes approach to My threshold, hearing My words, attuning to My heart's rhythm. Thus, compelled, He descends to our plane initially, granting few wishes to draw us near, place Sai Satcharitra in hand, cultivate receptivity. Gradually, insight emerges: Baba fulfills not every baseless plea. Maturity blossoms - or one lingers infantile at eighty. Some remain perpetual children - abundant indeed. Explicitly: Anxiety not that I depart; body absent henceforth in tangible form. Inter Me - My bones shall melt for you, eternally anxious for your sake. As I labored in embodiment, an even deeper pledge. What could describe Sadguru better than this? Such yearning selfless - what recompense? We proffer naught. He is laboring to uplift us to the state of the Supreme, What could we give Him in return? Nothing Mere alignment with His command contents Him. The dilemma: We shun His intent. Devotion per our caprice, exalted as paramount. Each harbors personal whims - for 'Jaya mani jaisa bhava' evokes billions of sentiments. Comforting - sacrifice naught, persist unchanged. But utter 'Your will, not mine' - all must yield; terror ensues. That verse soothes: Per my sentiment, Baba conforms - myriad manifestations. Yet His will is singular, not legion. Seize that one. Dispositions vary - billions emerge. Rudimentary: Undoubtedly, He responds per sentiments - initially, fostering faith. His compulsion. But not the ultimate verity. A provisional utterance, born of necessity: 'Jaya mani jaisa bhava taya taisa anubhav.' Descending to our stature. Yoga scriptures delineate seven chakras: From Muladhara to Sahasrara. My abode: Muladhara - incapable of ascent. From there: Per sentiment, the experience. Reluctant to elevate. In compassion: Very well, from Sahasrara I descend to Muladhara, uniting with you. Communion occurs - but imperfect; He stoops. If the Sadguru decrees: I shift not an iota; exert righteous effort, ascend to Me- But is it complete. He had to come down to my level. But if He asks, to do purusharth and refuses to come down. And reach the level where I am but I'll be in your support. Attuning to His heart, discerning His will - full purushartha deployed, ascending: Sovereign of existence. Discern the disparity. Clutching collar, dragging downward - invoking 'Jaya mani...' Yet hauling Him from heights to our depths. My assertion: Comprehend His will - He immovable at the apex; we must climb via endeavor. Tribulations abound, torments, dissolution - earth to heaven variance. This encapsulates His torment for us. Only a Sadguru can do such things. the supreme Sadguru's - boundless yearning for our salvation, beyond mortal capacity. After such profound yearning, He seeks reciprocity: I torment thus for you, perishing in your cause grant Me one solemn vow: Chapter twenty-five, verse one hundred eight. [Marathi Verse] Through the previous verses, the yearning of the Sadguru is clear. But after so much of efforts put in, He too expects one thing, Simply remember Me, enshrine Me in your consciousness, forget Me not. This is what Baba wants. Remember Me with unwavering faith and love. Not superficially As in chapter three it is mentioned: A covetous soul buries amassed wealth covertly. Wherever he roams, his mind fixates there - supreme avarice. Likewise, amid worldly engagements, if attention centers on Me: The work is accomplished. Baba affirms: With that intensity of love - fulfilling all duties: Office with integrity, household with fidelity. Subordinate self-interest, elevate kin's welfare - comfort, affection, honor. Master these fundamentals, and triumph ensues. Amidst, let Me not fade from remembrance even momentarily. [Marathi Verse] Devotion selfless - stipulation Nishkam, devoid of worldly yearnings, even in reverie. Shame Me not with petitions; necessities I discern unaided. An innocent infant clasps the mother's hem without voicing hunger; she intuits. The paramount Sadguru - why articulate needs? He perceives all. Baba inquires: Why demean with demands? If a guileless child vocalizes to the mother, it shames her. Similarly, in the Sadguru's court: My wish this-dishonors Him. Essentials - bestowed unsolicited. I reiterate: Essentials - unsolicited. No need to shame Him by asking for it. [Marathi Verse] Explicitly: Nishkam bhakti ensures supreme welfare. If it is whole-heartedly. The world exploits Baba as a mere stepping stone: Ascend His chest to grasp ephemeral illusions. Eternal as ladder, trampled for transient gains. 99.99% adherents thus: Baba the means, not the end. Ascend His chest, making Him the stepping stone. Crush Him under our foot. And then crave for some illusion. Baba as a mere stepping stone for us, not the destination. Inverse required: Trample illusion, attain the Eternal. Correct opposite Baba the everlasting - crushed underfoot for fleeting pursuits. Agony when conceding: He knows infusion of venomous desires. Look at it from His perspective. Whenever, He grants us petty wish, how much suffering He takes up. Because we are not awaken, but He is. How much pain and suffering He faces. From His vantage: Granting this petty wish - later neutralize its toxin. Labor doubled. The disciple abstaining from demands: How He rejoices - burden lightened. Envision. His yearning: Bestow transcendence, labors immense - limitless. Ours: Eradicate ignorance ceaselessly, elevate to divinity. Effort boundless, compassion infinite. In exchange: Selfless adoration—relinquish pleas; I oversee. I fathom your toxins, how to purge vices, ego, propensities, attachments. My odyssey spans eons - yet masterful. From you: Merely this entreaty - selfless devotion; I manage the rest. Kabir Ji has couplet on selfless devotion, with which we should end this topic. Kabir Ji says, 'Phal kaaran seva kare, Kare na man se kaam, Kahe Kabir sevak nahi, Jo mange chau guna daam' He is not a servant who demands something in recompense As Baba says in Chapter 39, on a Shloka. Serve the Sadguru, then earn the right to question. Service thus: This form bestowed solely for Sadguru's ministry - no alternate obligation. Not capricious: Serve when inclined, vanish for years. My essence exists for Thy service. With such sanctity, serve sans fruit - verily service. 'Phal kaaran seva kare, Kare na man se kaam, Kahe Kabir sevak nahi, Jo mange chau guna daam' But those who demand for something in return, Serve a little and then give orders. Just the way of given order is different. They say, 'Please..' But it is an order. The way of saying is very gentle. We are humans so we know how to trick. 'Phal kaaran seva kare, Kare na man se kaam, Kahe Kabir sevak nahi, Jo mange chau guna daam' In another Kabir Ji says, 'Bhaj dina kahu aur hi, Tan sadhu ke sang' Invocation another's - body with sages, yet mind on cravings. But the body is set for Sadguru's service. 'Bhaj dina kahu aur hi, Tan sadhu ke sang, Kahe Kabir kaari gazi, Kaise laage rang' Black garb from crown to sole: Devours colors. Blackened weave - how imbibe tint? If you put any color it will not catch that color. 'Kahe Kabir kaari gazi, Kaise laage rang' The body is engaged into the service of the Sadguru but during the service, mind is engrossed in desires. So, such a person is like a black cloth, even if the Sadguru wishes to imbibe the colors of His love, knowledge and endless devotion, He won't success. Because selfishness has taken the form of black cloth, it won't take up any dye. Attire must be pristine - selfless devotion. Then, suffused in saffron renunciation. Bring the saffron, Chapter 12. For dyeing: Purity essential. He colors as willed. Black-robed in court: He, despite yearning, cannot infuse - helpless. Thus concludes today's discourse: 'Who could be a greater Sadguru than Sai?'     "Description": "इस वीडियो में कृष्णाजी बताते हैं कि साई से बढ़कर सद्गुरु कौन है और सद्गुरु का वास्तविक स्वरूप क्या है। एक संत वह है जो माया से मुक्त हो चुका है, किंतु सद्गुरु वह है जो माया पर विजय प्राप्त कर चुका है। सद्गुरु वही है जो शिष्य को न केवल सांसारिक बंधनों से मुक्त करता है बल्कि उसे आत्मिक उन्नति के मार्ग पर भी ले जाता है।\n\nसाई बाबा को सद्गुरु कहने का अधिकार हमें तभी मिलता है जब हम उनके हृदय में प्रवेश पा लें, उनकी मर्ज़ी को समझ सकें और उनके अनुग्रह का अनुभव करें। जब तक यह नहीं होता, तब तक न हम सच्चे शिष्य हैं, न सच्चे भक्त—सिर्फ नाम लेने से भक्ति पूर्ण नहीं होती।\n\nइस दिव्य विडिओ में साईसच्चरित्र की पावन लीलाओं और कबीर के दोहों के माध्यम से यह गहन सत्य प्रकट होता है कि केवल एक परम सद्गुरु ही अपने शिष्य के उद्धार के लिए इतनी तड़प सकता है। साधारण इंसान के बस की बात नहीं कि वह किसी की आत्मा को मोक्ष तक पहुँचा सके।\n\nयदि बाबा के सान्निध्य में रहकर भी हमारा उद्धार नहीं हो पाया, तो हमसे बड़ा दुर्भाग्यशाली इस ब्रह्मांड में कोई नहीं।\n\nसच्चिदानंद सद्गुरु साईनाथ महाराज की जय!\n\n🪷🪷🪷\n\nIn this video, Krishnaji explains who can truly be called a Sadguru and reveals the deeper essence of Sai Baba's divine state.     "Transcript": "This is no ordinary book; it is divine guidance, radiant with light. It is the autobiography of the Divine, narrated in His own words. Om Sai Ram Today I am taking a very important topic from the Sai Satcharita: Sai’s Nishkama Karma Yoga (selfless action). See, unless the Guru lives and demonstrates it, how can we live it ourselves? Whenever a Divine incarnation descends into this world, Their purpose is to elevate us all to the spiritual pinnacle where they reside. That is why They incarnate. They don't come merely to fulfill our petty desires. But they do fulfill those petty desires too, so that our faith in them grows, and we strive to understand their heart. And if we can do that - if we reach their heart and begin transforming ourselves accordingly - then one day, we will attain the seat of completeness where they sit, the fullness they embody. In his life, Baba showed how actions should be performed, the depth and grace of performing Karma. Through one leela, he lived and demonstrated selfless action. Today, we will explore that leela and try to understand its profound importance in life. As in the Bhagavad Gita, there is a verse: 'karmaṇy-evādhikāras te mā phaleṣhu kadāchana mā karma-phala-hetur bhūr mā te saṅgo ’stvakarmaṇi' We all know this verse from the Bhagavad Gita. Baba embodied this verse in his own life and showed it to us. There's a short story, a leela, almost like a parable Baba says, \"When I was very young...\" See, Baba appeared in Shirdi at the age of 16. So, this leela that Baba is narrating happened before he appeared in Shirdi. \"When I was very young,\" meaning perhaps 8, 10, or 12 years old Whether it actually happened or not is a deeper matter, but through this leela, he wants to teach us something profound. Baba says, \"When I was very young, I tied a cloth around my waist and set out in search of livelihood.\" In a verse Baba says: 'Ekda mi lahan asta, Phadka bandhun potabhavta, Dhanda milava nirvahapurta, Aanuni chitta nighalo.' \"I just need a job to sustain myself.\" This word 'Nirvahapurta' is very important, Meaning only enough for basic sustenance. \"With that intention, I left home to earn through some effort and hard work.\" He says, 'Chalta chalta beedgava, Aalo tethe ghetla visava, Fakiracha majhya nyarach kaava, Anand jeeva vaatala.' \"And so, wandering, in search of work, I reached Beed village\" \"And there, I found work in zari (gold thread embroidery)..\" To earn money, one must do some work. \"So, I got zari work and started doing it.\" Baba says, \"Mihi khaplo avishram,\" and I immersed myself fully in that work with utmost diligence. Now, we too say this often, “We have so many responsibilities in life. How can we find time for devotion to Baba amid all that?” Normally we ask this question. In a way, Baba is answering it. Baba says, \"Even though I came as the Lord of the universe, as an avatar, it doesn't mean I did nothing in my life. I too worked hard.\" \"And when I worked in this world, how did I do it?\" He's explaining that. He says that, 'Tikde milale jariche kaam' - There I got zari work, 'Mihi khaplo avishram' - \"I kept immersing myself, dedicating fully to the work..\" 'Phalale te majhe sakal shram, Paha parakram fakiracha' \"And my hard work bore fruit; see what the fakir did.\" Baba says, 'Majhya aadhich lavilele, Hushar hushar navajlele, Char poranhi te kaam kele, Tehi mapile te samayi' \"There were three other boys with me doing the zari work; I wasn't alone.\" \"And they too received daily wages..\" \"One did work worth 50 rupees, the second boy's worth 100 rupees, the third's 150 rupees, . and mine was the highest - double, 300 rupees.\" All four were probably working the same eight hours. Please understand this well. They worked only eight hours, but the one who worked harder got higher pay. So, one got 50 rupees - he must have been lazy, working carelessly. So, \"This is all you did; take 50 and go.\" Another worked a bit harder in those eight hours and got 100 rupees. In the same eight hours, one did even more and got 150 rupees. And Baba himself did the most, worth 300 rupees. \"Now, seeing this, my master was so pleased that he honoured Me with a zari turban and a shawl. honored me immensely, without limit, because \"This boy is diligent; wherever he goes in life, he will achieve something\".\" But Baba says further, that \"The zari turban, shawl he gave, the honor - I set all that aside.\" \"And thought in my mind that 'What I received is perishable. What my Lord, my Sadguru, will give me - that will be eternal..’ This is perishable; it may be given today but gone tomorrow. If I indulge in it, I will be left empty. I'll have to work hard again. What my master gave me in exchange for my labor, is perishable.\" But Baba says, \"I came into this world to earn the eternal, not the perishable.\" Here, Baba is teaching: First, when you work in this world, how should you do it? Work so hard, use your talent so fully, immerse yourself so completely. If the Lord has given you talent, skill, art - If you can earn millions in a month, then earn fully. Baba is teaching this. If you have talent, skill, passion for hard work, then work limitlessly. If you can earn one million in a month, earn one million. If five millions, earn five millions. But what he says next: \"I didn't use it on myself. I set the money aside as it was.\" 'Set it aside as it was' - meaning \"I gave it to charity, used it for public welfare. I didn't indulge in the glamour, show, pleasure, or enjoyment of it.\" 'If I earn more, I'll enjoy higher luxuries.'- That's what happens in our lives. We want to earn more to enjoy higher levels of indulgence. And that's the problem. Through this story, Baba is teaching us: \"Work fully. If you have the capacity to earn one million, earn it. But if your monthly expenses are just 5 to 10 thousand, use only that much and give the rest to charity. That's what he's teaching. So, what will happen? Try to understand carefully. The Supreme has created this universe, right? If He is the Master who created it, then the responsibility and right to nurture and adorn it is on us. Because this creation is His. When I use my earned money not for self-indulgence, not for personal expenses, not for sensual pleasures, but fully for public welfare, then I become the gardener protecting His garden. Just as God does. Indirectly, I become the God. Please try to understand well. It seems like a small leela, but it's not; Baba is saying something very deep. Just as the Lord runs this world selflessly, that's why He runs it so beautifully, making this garden bloom and fragrant. Similarly, Baba says, \"I spent minimally on myself - just enough for basic sustenance - and used the rest for charity.\" What a teaching! This is selfless action (Nishkama Karma Yoga). Now, many people do this: I have, eight-hour duty, household responsibilities, kitchen, this and that - where to find time? People often say this. But I say, first, why do you separate your office work from spiritual service? Why not turn it into spiritual service? As Baba is saying. If you're a doctor, immerse yourself fully - where others do one operation, do three; pour your soul into saving the patient at any cost, ensuring their peace and health. Don't look at how much money you're getting. If you're a teacher with 100 students, focus on the weakest one - how to uplift them; expend your energy there. The Lord is watching; that's selfless action. When you convert your field of work itself into spiritual service, then the Sadguru will dance with joy. What do we do? We keep spiritual service separate, and daily duties separate - that's where we get stuck. And as I'm saying, work those eight hours in the office with full honesty and dedication. Even if you sit before Baba for half an hour in the evening, samadhi will descend. Because you have practiced selfless action for those eight hours. Don't think the boss will be pleased, or you'll get an increment, bonus, or be praised, and earn respect from others. That's what Baba is saying: \"I received appreciation, but I didn't get trapped in it.\" \"I set it aside.\" In the same way, our workplace can become a worship place. If we work with such intention, This is what Baba is saying. We often make this mistake: Finish the work quickly, get rid of it, then sit with Baba's scripture. No, you won't be able to sit. If one has been dishonest at work, has shirked responsibilities there, and hasn't given 100% effort, then how can one truly enter the depths of the scripture in the evening? Think about it - is it possible? If in the evening you feel samadhi should descend in the scripture, in contemplation of Baba, then you must give those eight hours with utmost honesty at your workplace. That's why I named the topic \"Sai's Nishkama Karma Yoga.\" What a leela! For us, such things don't appeal. Miracles appeal more. Miracles, miracles, miracles.... Grabbing someone, seating them in front of a camera: \"Yes, share your experience.\" What nonsense? How long will this go on? We should feel ashamed. Stop somewhere. How long will you do this? And because of this, Baba has been defamed today. Because Baba's spiritual light hasn't come before the world. That's why so much negative propaganda against Baba - you all know at what level it's happening. And those raising questions - no one has answers; that's the problem. \"Your Sai Baba, in the first chapter, is abusing women. Are saints like that?\" Done. Blown away. You have no answer. \"Your Sai Baba ate and fed meat. How can he be a saint?\" You have no answer. \"Your Sai Baba was an addict, smoking chillum 24/7. How can he be a Sadguru?\" You have no answer. Because you haven't reached Baba's heart. And on top of that, what do we do? Complain that they did this or that. Will complaints fix it? We need to spread Baba's wisdom. The spiritual treasure Baba has filled in this scripture. Baba says in the 32nd chapter: \"My treasure is full. Bring bullock carts and dig it out, fill and take it.\" But only a true devotee will be able to fill it. That's the condition too. Not everyone can. But no one talks about this treasure. Just miracles,.... What a deep lesson this is - selfless karma yoga, what a beautiful leela. Baba has presented the entire karma yoga of the Bhagavad Gita in just 10 lines so beautifully. The whole third chapter of Bhagavad Gita is covered in this. He worked fully, more than the other four, but didn't use even a bit on himself; used the money for public welfare, set it aside without indulging. But our problem is, if we have a salary of 10-20 thousand, how to make it 50 so I can enjoy better? Our entire tendency is toward indulgence: Enjoy life. Even when we get less, we don’t learn to live within our means, we just keep thinking of doubling it. You'll only earn the perishable, not the eternal. Baba says: No matter how much this perishable my master, my boss gives, it's perishable. It won't last forever. My entire effort is to earn the eternal. The perishable doesn't excite me. It doesn't attract me. So, this Sai's selfless action is a very beautiful topic. If we miss such things from Baba's teachings, what remains? And this is the foundation. Karma yoga is the base. Upon this, the grand edifice of devotion and knowledge will stand. The stronger the foundation, the higher the edifice of devotion and knowledge will rise. If the foundation is weak, how will you build the edifice of devotion, knowledge, and yoga? It will wobble. It won't stand. There's one verse from this chapter. Verse 168 Baba says: \"Jo jo jaise jaise karil, to to taise taise bharil, dhyanat thevi jo majhe bol, saukhya amol pavel to.\" Whatever one does, one reaps accordingly. If you worked for 50 rupees, you'll get only 50 - whether in the worldly or spiritual realm. The same law applies in the spiritual world too. There, too, the more effort you put in spirituality, the more selfless service, devotion, and embodiment of knowledge, the more it expands. So, effort is needed in both realms. Conversely, in the 19th chapter, Baba says: If in this world you sit lazily, saying, \"Let the Lord feed me while I sit.\" Baba says, perhaps at some point I might even do that - feed you while you sit. But if you apply that to spirituality - \"Let my spirituality flourish while I sit\" then I don't know about that. For spirituality, you'll have to work very hard. You'll have to turn your blood into water, break your bones like dry wood. Only then will spirituality slowly, slowly bear fruit. The problem is, we don't want to hear or know such things. And today, countless channels don't want to tell them either. They just want miracles. Or there are some other kind of people. See, 80% of the channels on Baba today, that people run, they talk about miracles. Their channels run on that - just miracles. 15% of the channels give information. They have a vast repository of information. They pull it from scriptures, from magazines, and boldly present it to people. But no one wants to touch Baba's original spiritual wisdom. Even if they include scriptures, it’s only as information. If they talk about Sai Satcharitra, again, it’s just information. The original spiritual mystery cannot be grasped that way. Now, the question will always arise in your minds: Why don't we understand these things? Because it requires a different vision. First, selfless devotion must descend into your life. If your devotion is selfless, if you've gone through selfless action, only then can you unlock these gems, reveal these mysteries. If your devotion is filled with desires, if it is selfish, then I swear on Baba's feet: Even after millions of births in devotion to Baba, not a single leela will unfold to you. You must become selfless. And the fruit of selfless devotion is that, you won't ask anything from Sai Baba; you'll ask for Sai Baba himself. Selfless devotion gives you that power. You won't ask for perishable things from Baba; you'll ask for Baba himself. That's the power in selfless devotion. So, today, the meaning is clear: If Baba stands and asks everyone, \"Do you want something from me, or do you want me?\" 99% will say, \"Baba, what will I do with you? We have kept you at high pedestal in our lives. So that we can fulfill all our desires through you.\" Truly, if Baba says: \"Either I fulfill all your desires, or set them all aside and I myself come into your life.\" \"No, no, Baba, stay where you are. You look better there in the samadhi mandir. Don't come into my heart. Just keep solving all my life's problems.\" That's our intention. That's our understanding. That's our discernment and dispassion. That's our maturity. How will any leela unfold to us? Because the Sadguru is selfless. See, if you want to meet the Sadguru - imagine Baba is still in Shirdi in physical form, not as an idol. If you want to bring Baba into your life, you'll have to reach Baba. You'll have to go to Shirdi. You'll need to take entry into the village where Baba is there. Right? Only then can you have his darshan. So, what is Baba's village? Selfless action - that's Baba's village. Without becoming selfless yourself, how will you enter that village? On a superficial, peripheral level, we keep saying ‘Baba, Baba,… and the purpose behind it is: Since we do so much devotion to you, you must fulfill every desire. Every wish must be granted. Whether justified or not, whatever it is, you must fulfill it. And if one day Baba doesn't seem to do it: \"Nowadays, Sai Baba has no power. There's a new temple; let's go there. Heard a lot about it.\" Our devotion is so hollow. Then, when will we understand Shraddha and Saburi? Those two words are Baba's core mantra. Neither is our faith that firm in life, nor patience. Then it is impossible. So, this is Sai's selfless action - a very important topic. Because without understanding this leela, without immersing ourselves in selfless action, Baba's heart will not unfold. I'm being very straightforward. Often, I'm asked: How do you reach these truths? How can you say this? I say, if our devotion is pure, selfless, without expectations, then entry into Baba's heart is granted. Because I don't want anything from Baba. I want Baba. If I truly want Baba, why wouldn't Baba grant entry into his heart? And if I want things from Baba, then I'm very far. I'll keep begging from afar: \"Baba, do this; Baba, do that.\" Well, those are perishable. Even after getting them, do they give eternal peace? Or Eternal joy? Never. Whatever you get will either leave you, or you'll leave it. It's not eternal. Nothing obtained from Baba will stay permanent - not even children. Who knows, today it is, tomorrow it may not be: and sometimes, while you remain, it departs, or while it remain, you depart. This is transient. The world is perishable. That's why, live amid all, practice selfless action right from home. If four or five people live in the home, your way of living should be so different that you live for those four, die for those four. Keep no self-interest at all. Truly, if you do this for just two years, Baba's heart will unfold. Give as much comfort, respect, love and care as you can, to those four people. And you must not expect anything in return. If you live this way just for two years, you will get entry into Baba's heart. I'm not even talking about selfless action outside - start from home. And if you live like that, your mind purifies very quickly. In which the Lord of the universe can one day reside. And to be very honest, without passing through such selfless karma yoga, you cannot reach the Purna Brahman. It's impossible. Just with superficial devotion, you can't reach there. You can't reach the experience of Purna Brahman, means the realization: “I alone pervade the entire universe; all that exists is but Me.” Its foundation is selfless action. Because if you bring selfless action into life, only then will your devotion deepen, your knowledge expand. You'll attain yoga, and journey to the Purna Brahman. So, this Sai's Nishkama Karma Yoga. O Mind-Enchanting One, Remover of Curses and Suffering, Destroyer of Ignorance, Bestower of Liberation, The Supreme Giver of Auspiciousness, Embodiment of Truth, Consciousness, and Bliss, the Sacred Mother of countless embodiments of Sai. the True Form of Sai Himself Victory to the Divine Scripture: Shri Sai Satcharita.",

    "Transcript": "This is no ordinary book; it is divine guidance, radiant with light. It is the autobiography of the Divine, narrated in His own words. Om Sai Ram. The significance of Vishnu Sahasranama, in the practice of devotion to Sai,. This is the topic. Before delving into the discourse on Vishnu Sahasranama. I first share a personal experience of Baba Himself. Thereafter, we shall enter this subject. Once, Baba felt a surge of compassion and mercy in His heart for Shyama. He perceived Shyama as a simple and innocent soul. Thus, Baba deemed that the Vishnu Sahasranama should descend into Shyama’s life. There was a devotee of Ramdas, reciting the Vishnu Sahasranama, With divine ingenuity, He took the sacred text and handed over to Shyama, Instructing him to begin chanting it daily, even if just one syllable at a time, but with proper pronunciation. Baba then shared a personal experience with Shyama, saying, “Once, my heart trembled with a ceaseless flutter, as though my very life-breath was about to depart. At that critical juncture, I placed the Vishnu Sahasranama upon my heart, And it was as if Allah Himself descended into my being.” Behold the divine manner in which Baba expresses this! While speaking of the Vishnu Sahasranama, He says, “It was as if Allah Himself descended into my being.” What a profound way of teaching! Baba repeatedly emphasized that Allah and Vishnu are one and the same. We call upon the Divine by different names, But let no doubt arise in the heart. Baba further narrated, “As soon as I began chanting the sacred names, The life force that was about to depart was preserved. It was as if I was granted a new life through the Vishnu Sahasranama. To convey the glory of these divine names to our hearts, Baba declared, ‘My life was saved because of chanting these names; Otherwise, that day, my death was certain.’” This is the direct and profound meaning of His words. The purpose behind sharing such a divine miracle is, to encourage devotees to begin the practice of chanting these sacred names. Simple. We shall delve into the deeper essence later. Simply put, start this practice of chanting from today itself. The Vishnu Sahasranama, In the tenth chapter of the Bhagavad Gita, known as Vibhuti Yoga. In this chapter, Lord Krishna reveals His countless divine manifestations, saying, “Among demons, I am Prahlada; Among mountains, I am Meru; Among months, I am Margashirsha; Among animals, I am the lion.” In essence, He tells about His divine manifestations He declares that whatever is exalted and great in this world Exists by His divine power alone. In a similar manner, Baba instructs Shyama, saying, “O Shyama, begin chanting the Vishnu Sahasranama. Your speech is not yet clear. Practice pronouncing each word properly and correctly. Start this practice daily, chanting one name at a time. First, let you pronunciation be perfect, through practice, And then strive to understand the meaning and divine glory hidden in each name.” For instance, consider the names: 'Om vishvam vishnu rvashatkaro bhoota-bhavya bhavat-prabhuh Bhoota-krut bhoota-bhrud-bhavo bhootatma bhoota-bhavanah' If you can comprehend the meaning of each word - Vishvam, Vishnu, Vashatkaro and assimilate it within your soul, If the essence of all thousand names permeates your being, Then the entire wisdom of Vedanta will dawn within you. Because, this is the divine method of Sage Vyasa, That He embedded the mysteries of Vedanta within the Vishnu Sahasranama. Thus, Baba indirectly guides Shyama, saying, “Take one name daily, but understand its meaning as well. Do not recite mechanically. Recitation is easy. Initially, you can practice and focus on pure pronunciation, ensuring clarity. But thereafter, it is said, 'Ojhe ojhe naam gheyi' Meaning, chant each name slowly while understanding its meaning. If you chant ‘Sai’ without knowing its meaning, Without grasping the depth hidden within the word ‘Sai,’ If you cannot pour the entire essence of Life, the depth of Sai Satcharitra into the name 'Sai', How can you infuse love into that name? Then it will become mechanical, 'Sai, Sai,.........', like a parrot’s repetition. Nothing of true worth shall be accomplished Thus, Baba advises, “First, refine your pronunciation, And then, chant each name with understanding.\" And He says, \"Even if you take just one Name daily, it is enough\" Baba does not indulge in superficiality. He always imparts the essence of truth. Why did Baba emphasize chanting one name daily? What is its meaning? Was it merely for recitation? No, it was to understand the meaning of each name. Even if you grasp the meaning of just one name each day, that is sufficient. In a thousand days, the thousand names will be complete. Thereafter, continue the practice. In Chapter 27, Verse 78 of the Sai Satcharitra, This entire divine incident is narrated, How Baba's heart trembled with a ceaseless flutter, How His life-breath was about to depart, and at that moment He placed the Vishnu Sahasranama on His heart, And His breath was stabilized. It was as if the Divine Himself became Baba’s life force, saving Him from certain death. This is the miracle of Vishnu Sahasranama. Indirectly, Baba’s purpose in sharing this profound incident is clear: “O devotee, begin chanting the divine names today itself. Do not waste the precious time granted in this human form. Make full use of this sacred opportunity.” - this is what Baba had to say. For, as it is said, if you chant the name without understanding its meaning, Without clarity, how long can you sustain such chanting? Would you chant for a long time? It becomes a mechanical process, and you may grow weary, and leave it. But when the depth of meaning dawns upon you, The joy of chanting increases gradually, and it will keep increasing each day. Where you once chanted for ten minutes, You will chant for twenty; Where twenty, you will chant for two hours; And where two hours, the chanting will continue all day long. For the joy is increasing day by day. With full awareness and heartfelt understanding, You immerse yourself in the divine name. There are four stages to chanting the divine name: Vaikhari, Madhyama, Pashyanti, and Para Vaikhari refers to chanting aloud with the tongue, in a manner that can be heard by the ears. For instance, reciting, ‘Om Shri Sainathaya Namah.’ This is Vaikhari. Madhyama, on the other hand, is when the tongue moves silently within, without any outward sound. None outside can hear it, for the chanting resounds only within, audible solely to your own inner being. This is Madhyama. Pashyanti means, the tongue is not moving, yet the Divine Name resounds within the heart, and the ears can still perceive it. And Para is when that remembrance of the Name has permeated every fibre of your being where, in truth, it is the Supreme Himself who is chanting within you, while you sit in stillness. That is Para. 'Peeche peeche Hari phire, kahat Kabir Kabir' Meaning, Kabir has now taken the Name so ceaselessly, that now even in sleep, Hari is chanting from within. That too He is chanting 'Kabir, Kabir'. Which means you reach to that state, which is known as 'Para Vani'. So, we have to reach there. But the Lord will take up that Name within you only when you show such intensity, such sincerity, and such earnest effort. Ensuring not a single moment passes without the Divine’s name. When your practice is steadfast, Then one day, the Divine Himself begins chanting within you, And that is Para Vani, the ultimate goal. The purpose is to reach there. Now, consider the importance of these thousand names. If someone wants to chant these names, First of all, to chant all thousand names may take 20 to 30 minutes. So, you dedicated these 30 minutes to Upasana, and trained yourself to sit at one place for 30 minutes and engage in chanting. So, now you are able to sit at one place for 30 minutes. Initially, this was impossible. Because the resolve to complete the thousand names anchors you. Your posture becomes steady. Now, you can sit at one place and chant for 30 minutes. This is the first stage. Then the second stage, one may realize that, 'I am reciting the names mechanically, but I do not know the meaning.' But Krishna Ji advises, it is essential to understand the meaning of each name. So, you begin to read the meaning of each name alongside the chant. This may take about an hour and a quarter. Now, this comes into practice. Is that clear? I am explaining these stages: Do not merely chant mechanically and leave it at that. In the beginning, mechanical chanting is acceptable, but in the second stage, you must understand the meaning of each name. By imbibing the depth and grandeur of each name, its divine potency (vibhuti), into your heart, devotion and heartfelt emotion will arise. Then, you will chant those names with profound devotion. This is the second stage. Now, what does Baba say further? The thousand divine potencies (vibhutis) of Vishnu reside within the Guru. Hence, it is said: “Gurur Brahma, Gurur Vishnu, Gurur Devo Maheshwara, Gurur Sakshat Parabrahma, Tasmai Shri Gurave Namah.” So, the thousand names of Vishnu are encapsulated in the single name of the Sadguru. After fully assimilating the depth of these thousand names into your heart, realize this truth: If these thousand divine potencies exist anywhere, they reside in the name of my Sadguru. With this conviction, set aside the Vishnu Sahasranama and begin chanting Baba’s name as, “Samrath Sai”. Believing that the profundity of those thousand names is inherent in Baba’s name. Let me clarify why I say this. I will first present a verse from the Sai Satcharitra, so no doubts linger in your mind. Kabir Ji has also said: 'Guru Govind dono khade' On one side there is vishnu with His thousand names 'Guru govind dono khade, Kaake lagu paaye' 'Balihari guru aapne, Govind diyo bataye' O Gurudev! If not for You, even in countless births, the depth of Govind could never be understood. It is Your grace alone that gives me clarity of Govind/ Vishnu Without you there would be no way to understand Govind. Kabir Ji further says, 'Kabira te nar andh hai' 'Kabira te nar andh hai, Guru ko kehte aur' Vishnu and Guru are not one, Guru is someone else. Guru is lesser than Vishnu. Those who say this are blind. Blind is the one who considers the Guru lesser than Vishnu 'Kabira te nar andh hai, Guru ko kehte aur, Hari ruthe..' If Hari is displeased, 'Guru thor hai' - the Guru can protect. But if the Guru is displeased, Then in all three worlds there is none to save you. 'Guru ruthe nahi thor' This truth is affirmed in Chapter 49, Verse 16 of the Sai Satcharitra, A very important verse. I am explaining why, after internalizing the depth of the Vishnu Sahasranama, one must transition to chanting Sai’s name. Chapter 49, Verse 16: 'Tirth, Vrat, Yagn, Daan..' Please listen attentively 'Tirth, vrat, yagna, daan, yahuni thor tapacharan' Pilgrimages, vows, sacrifices, and charity - ascetic practices (tapacharan) surpass these 'Tyahuni adhik haribhajan' Yet, greater than asceticism is the chanting of Hari’s name. The recitation of Vishnu’s thousand names. 'Nijguru dhyan sarvadhik' Clear What is said: 'Nijguru dhyan sarvadhik' And even above Hari, the meditation on the Sadguru is supreme. This means there is a long journey before one arrives at chanting Baba’s name. Now, when you chant Baba’s name, it embodies the glory of Vishnu’s thousand names. With their meanings, those thousand names are inherent in Sai’s name. All that profundity is encapsulated within it. With this understanding, imagine how much devotion, how much faith, how much depth you will bring to chanting that name. The journey begins with the thousand names of Vishnu and culminates in the single name of Sai. Thus, one who chants Vishnu’s thousand names is like a student in nursery. But if they fully embrace the depth of those names, pour them into Baba’s name, and become wholly absorbed in chanting Baba’s name, then the thousand names of Vishnu are contained within that one name. In essence, the practice of Nama smaran begins with a rudimentary process. But if your samadhi is attained in Baba’s single name, that is the ultimate destination. I am not speaking from my own imagination; I am presenting the profundity of the Sai Satcharitra. Consider further verses to affirm this truth. The first and second verses of Chapter 27: 'Drudh dharilya Shri Sadguru charan, ghade Brahmadi traymurti daman' If you surrender yourself completely at the feet of the Sadguru, if you take refuge in those sacred feet, if you hold onto Guru's feet, you automatically pay homage to Brahma, Vishnu, and Mahesh. Is that clear? You offer salutations to the Supreme Brahman for the Guru is the embodiment of Parabrahma. 'Swananda ghana suprakt…' You become entitled to boundless bliss, for you are entwined at the feet of the Supreme Brahman. It continues: 'Marita eka sagari budi…' If you dive into the ocean, 'Sadati sakal tirtha parvadi…' you honor all the sacred rivers and pilgrimage sites of the world. For the final abode of all rivers is the ocean; all rivers flow and merge into it. The waters of all rivers are already within the ocean. Thus, by paying homage to the ocean, you honor all rivers. Similarly, by completely surrendering to the Sadguru, the 33 crore deities reside at His sacred feet. Thus, Baba instructs: First, understand the depth and meaning of each of Vishnu’s names. Then, assimilate them into your heart. And pour that entire radiance into the feet of Sadguru Sai. With full awareness of the glory of those thousand names, begin chanting that one name with profound depth. The day you attain samadhi in that name, it will be that profound. 'Sadati sakal tirtha parvadi, Baista gurupadi deuni dadi, Aatudti budi sakal dev' All 33 crore deities reside at the Guru’s feet. The journey begins with Baba’s instruction to Shyama: Chant the Vishnu Sahasranama- a mechanical process at first. Start with proper pronunciation, with clarity, and then understand the depth of each word, the meaning of each name. The day those thousand names are fully imprinted in your heart, take the essence of those thousand names and pour it at the feet of the Sadguru. Then, begin chanting Sai’s name. If, for two hours, you chant with unwavering devotion, forgetting the world and yourself, and only the name remains, then truly, your practice of chanting is complete. In my view, the Vishnu Sahasranama begins with Vishnu’s thousand names and culminates in the single name of the Sadguru. I know I have presented a unique topic. But for those who have faith in the Guru, Firstly, the verse I cited, from the Sai Satcharitra, should leave no doubts if understood clearly. The 16th verse of Chapter 49. 'Tirtha, vrata, yajna, dana…' Ascetic practices surpass - pilgrimages, vows, sacrifices, and charity Yet, chanting Hari’s name surpasses asceticism. And above all, meditation on the Sadguru is supreme. This is stated clearly. If, despite this, questions arise, I leave you with your questions.
