    "Transcript": "You cannot experience only good moments alone. Bad experiences will inevitably come along too. So many people are seated here. Can anyone claim that- \"No, Krishna Ji, you are wrong. We have only enjoyed joy in life.\" No such person exists in the entire cosmos. So, this song is telling us, O mortal, if you have come into this universe taking a body, you are entangled in dualities. This mill of duality grinds relentlessly. And you are being ground like grain in it, pulverized. The song conveys exactly that. One basket is filled with flowers. One basket with thorns. And what is the reason? The very creation of this world is a mixture. So, Baba is here to lift us above these dualities and pour the ocean of bliss within us. \"I must rise above my body and intellect to attain my true essence.\"- This should be clear. This is no ordinary book; it is a luminous advice. Their own autobiography in their own words. Om Sai Ram There is a couplet of Kabir Ji. Most of you have probably heard it. 'Chalti chakki dekh ke, Diya Kabira roye,' 'Chalti chakki dekh ke, Diya Kabira roye, Do pathan ke beech mein, Sabut bacha na koye' What does he mean? Many people interpret this in their own ways. That's fine, I won't delve into that. But this couplet fits perfectly with this song. The two grinding stones represent duality These are the stones of duality. And the mill that turns is time itself. The wheel of time. In the wheel of time, everyone gets caught between dualities. Everyone gets ground down. Sometimes we get joy, sometimes sorrow. Sometimes good experiences arrive, sometimes bad ones. Sometimes the mind stays pure, sometimes it becomes utterly impure. Meaning, a person's behavior is never consistent because they are trapped in dualities. This world is filled with dualities. Look at how the world is created. Please understand this well. There is sunlight, and there is shade. There is day, and there is night. Isn't it? There is white, and there is black. There is light, and there is darkness. There is joy, and there is sorrow. There are virtues, and there are vices. There is beauty, and there is ugliness. There is life, and there is death. The Lord has crafted this entire cosmos, this entire universe, from polarities. Yet, you may wish to exist within this cosmos And yearn for only day, never night, Only joy, never sorrow, Only peace, never unrest. It's impossible. Because, the Lord has created this world with two opposing poles. Why is there such duality? Duality means two opposing poles. Have you ever noticed, that the Lord created this universe from the five great elements? We all know that. Earth, water, fire, air, ether (space). Have you ever observed that these five elements oppose each other? Like Earth is there. Earth is so dense. So heavy, upon which the entire universe rests. And on the other side, air is so light. Does it have any weight? So, one side so heavy, and air so light. One side water so cool, and on the other, fire so hot. Have you ever pondered this? The universe is created from opposing poles, so you must face these opposing poles until your last breath. You must face them. You cannot enjoy only happiness. You cannot enjoy only peace. You cannot experience only good moments. Bad experiences will inevitably come along too. So many people are seated here. Can anyone claim that- \"No, Krishna Ji, you are wrong. We have only enjoyed joy after joy in life.\" No one. No one in the whole cosmos. Not just this assembly - perhaps 300 or 400 people here today. But I say, show me one such person in the entire cosmos who can say they have only experienced good things. Only a saint or the Divine has the right to say that, one who has transcended these dualities. Risen above them. Reached the state beyond duality. They can say it. But they won't speak of joy or sorrow. They will say, I am pure bliss. Because bliss has no opposite. Bliss. Ananda. If you dwell amidst dualities, you must endure both. Then you might say, no, I want to experience only one in life. To suppress the other is impossible. You have to face both things. If you rise above both - \"I neither want joy nor sorrow.\" Both are relative. Both are dangerous. The very desire for joy plunges me into sorrow. I want neither joy nor sorrow. Rising above both, I want to seek my true essence of Sat-Chit-Ananda. And when you become a partaker of bliss, both fall away. So, this song is telling us, O mortal, if you have come into this universe taking a body, then you are entangled in dualities. This mill of duality grinds relentlessly. And you are being ground like grain in it, pulverized. Sometimes happiness comes, sometimes grief. Sometimes good experiences, sometimes bad. Sometimes the body stays healthy, sometimes it falls ill. Sometimes honor comes, sometimes dishonor. Sometimes it feels good inside, sometimes you become so despairing. So depressed that you wonder, why this life? That means, you never get a consistent experience. The song conveys exactly that. 'One basket filled with flowers. One basket with thorns, there must be some reason.' And the reason is that the very creation of this world is a mixture. You must accept this reality, this bitter truth. Have you ever thought - a person buys a ticket, boards a bus, heads to Tirupati. A sacred place, a holy pilgrimage site. But the bus carrying 60 people climbs up, reaches the summit, then tumbles down, and all 60 perish. What sin did they commit? Another sets out for Vaishno Devi pilgrimage. Climbing the mountain, an accident happens. Everyone in the vehicle dies. What sin did they commit? We read about this every day - they set out for good deeds, so why the tragedy? Baba says, there must be some reason, and falls silent. The reason is that this world is made of dualities. These things will keep happening, child, until your last breath; you will be ground in dualities. The only way is, to transcend them, rise above. Rise above the body consciousness. As long as you believe \"I am the body,\" you will be ground in dualities. This is the soul of the song. Is what I'm saying making sense? As long as you consider yourself the body, you are in duality. And in duality, you won't get just positive experience till your last breath. You must endure both. If you're enjoying joy, endure sorrow too. If you enjoy respect, you must also bear the pain of insult. So, this universe is made of dualities. Its very creation is a mixture. The Lord crafted the Universe from two opposing poles. So, these opposing poles will be present in your life 24/7. You can't avoid any of it. That's why Baba says you must rise above it. Drop the dualities. Drop joy too. Joy is the root of sorrow. From the womb of joy, sorrow is born. If you drop the desire for joy, sorrow falls away automatically, and you become entitled to bliss. And remember, bliss is an ocean; joy is merely a drop. So, Baba wants to lift us above dualities and pour that ocean of bliss within us through this song. But if you say, no, I want to stay in the world, consider myself the body, and still enjoy only joy - impossible. You must drop the body-ego. Then you don't become entitled to joy. Yes. But let me tell you - you become entitled to bliss. Joy falls away too. Joy starts seeming trivial. Receiving respect brings fleeting happiness; eating desired food brings fleeting happiness; indulging in sensual pleasures brings fleeting happiness; sexual gratification brings fleeting happiness. These are all gutter-level joys. If you've come as a human, it's not to indulge in gutter-level joys. The Lord sent you as human to experience bliss in this world. That is your birthright. You are not here for gutter-level joys, For within joy's womb, sorrow exists as a seed. Suppose today someone honors you greatly. For example, I came here today. Normally, I say this because I have no status that you would honor me. But suppose I enjoy that honor. Then, when dishonor comes in my life, I won't be able to bear it. Because in the womb of honor hides the pain of dishonor. If I enjoy honor today, I won't endure dishonor. It's duality. That's why, drop the attachment to good experiences first. Drop all those desires. And embrace your true essence beyond joy and sorrow - bliss. Yes. Then this doesn't apply to you: One basket filled with flowers. One basket with thorns, there must be some reason. What do you care? You've risen above it. There's a Marathi song. You might have heard it or not. 'Vitthala tu veda kumbhar..' There's a Marathi song: Vitthala, you are a mad potter. 'Phirtya chaka varti desi, maati la aakra, Vitthala tu veda kumbhar' He says, a potter places clay on the wheel and shapes various pots. You are like that, a mad potter. What do you do? You take clay, mix it with water. Fine? Then let air touch it. Give it the sun's heat so it becomes a pot. You create a vessel from four opposing elements. And you are the mad potter. You create this creation. You destroy this creation. You build it. You devastate it. Your ways are truly wondrous. So, this song explains that beautifully. Yesterday, someone asked about the accident in Pahalgam. Was it their karma, their fate, or nature's decree? It was both. Because nature's decree is such - I don't know when what will happen to me. Why talk of others? Tomorrow, such an accident could happen to me too. We must learn from them that tomorrow, such an incident could befall my life too. Because this world is made of dualities. Anything can happen anytime. It could happen to me too. Before such an accident occurs, I must rise above body-consciousness. Drop body-ego and immerse in my soul essence. That's the way. If you keep raising these questions, there's no answer. So, He is that mad potter. Nature's decree will continue. Somewhere floods come, entire villages collapse. Tsunamis arrives, sweeping away thousands. Now, what questions will you raise to nature? If clouds rain evenly, life flourishes. If just the right amount of rain falls on fields and gardens, grains grow well. Countless people live. But if that same water rains excessively in one place, floods come, taking away so many. So, this is nature. And there's no answer for it. It is just like this. There's no answer for it. The only way is to rise above this nature. But if you say, no, I want to remain part of nature. But let only happiness abound in life. Impossible. Is what I'm saying sinking in? So, this song is profoundly deep. There's a bhajan by Meera Ji. You might have heard it. I'll take a few lines. Did you understand this song? 'Karm ki gati nyari santo' Meera Ji says the outline of karma - you can't fathom it. It's very difficult to comprehend You can't catch it. Your intellect will tire searching for reasons. The only way is to rise above body-consciousness. Otherwise, you won't find the answer. So, she says, the ways of karma are mysterious, O saints. The path of karma is wondrous. Very strange. Not easily understood, that why something happens to someone. You'll spend your life searching for answers but won't find them. Because, Meera Ji says the path is very mysterious. 'Bade bade nayan die miragan ko, ban ban phirat udhaari..' Now, the deer, the stag. The Lord gave it large eyes. But those large eyes bring equal unrest. In truth, musk resides in its own navel. But it wanders the forests chasing that fragrance, thinking it's coming from somewhere else. It wanders and dies. Similarly, O human, why are you trapped in dualities? Within you is the treasure of bliss. An ocean surges inside. Turn inward and behold that bliss. Why wander like the deer? Large eyes given, but unrest increases too. It roams outward, goes to corners, and finally tires and dies. Next she says, 'Ujjval varan deenhi bagalan ko, koyal kar deenhi kaari..' Have you heard the heron's voice? It's harsh. There is no sweetness in its voice. But the color you gave it is pure white. And the cuckoo, you made black. Gave it a crow-like color. But filled its voice with boundless sweetness. Hearing its sweet coo, one enters meditation. But why do you do this? No answer. The heron with harsh voice, you gave it pure white color, and black color to the cuckoo, but such sweetness in its voice. So, this diversity, this opposition, Why did you create it? What to ask? Impurity is interlaced within its very creation. Further she says, 'Auran deepan jal nirmal kinhi, samundar kar deenhi khaari..' You made river water sweet - a small stream flowing, benefiting only those nearby. Not the whole universe. And you made the vast ocean, salty. What is this? Meera Ji asks the Divine, what way is this of creating the universe? 'auran deepan jal nirmal kinhi,' So, you made the river water pure and sweet. And the ocean is immense, filled with water, but you made it salty. But if that salty water wants to become pure and sweet, it must endure the sun's heat. It evaporates, rises as vapor, converts to clouds, and when clouds rain, that salty water falls as sweet. But to become sweet, salty water must pass through great austerity. Similarly, every body is an ocean of salty water. All these bodies are oceans of salty water. But if they endure austerity, burn in Baba's divine 'Dhuni', they can become sweet. They can transcend dualities. Rise above dualities. Attain their true Sat-Chit-Ananda essence. And next, she says, 'moorkh ko tum raaj deeyat ho, pandit phirat bhikhaari..' A fool, illiterate or a senseless person, you make him the king. and one with knowledge, you make him beg door to door. What is this universe of yours? So much contradiction. Finally, she says, the ways of karma are mysterious, O saints. And leaves it here. Meaning, don't go searching; answers won't come. It remains mysterious. The only thing you can do is: I don't want to live in this duality-filled creation with body-ego. After realizing this. If the creation's decree is such - anything can happen anytime - if this is true, then I no longer trust it. I must rise above body-ego to attain my true essence. This clarity is essential. That's why such songs are created. In the last, she says, 'Meera ke prbhu giridhar naagun raaja ji ko kaun bichaari..' The Purna Parabrahma incarnation, the full Divine, who placed all these dualities in life, in nature, but no one devotes to Him. They grind away in dualities and die, but no one strives through devotion to rise above. Saying this, the song ends: 'Karam ki gati nyaari Santo' Now, another example: Lord Rama. In Rama Ji's life, there is so much righteousness, ethics, purity, sacrifice, surrender. But what did Rama Ji gain except sorrow? What did he gain? Lifelong sorrow. In childhood, before eight, he underwent upanayana and was sent to Gurukul, there He was tested in all the ways. After, returning from Gurukul, He got married, He spent barely three nights before departing for 14 years of exile Pain upon pain. And on the other side, Ravana, so unrighteous. Indulgent in vices, full of desires. But enjoying luxuries. Living in golden Lanka. Enjoyments upon enjoyments. So, countless examples. Nature is like this. Don't ponder it too much. Instead of wasting energy on it. \"Nature's decree is just this. I must rise above it.\" Work diligently on that, and it will succeed. Now, let's come to the main song. 'ek jholi me phool bhare hai ek jholi me kaante, koi kaaran hoga' So. its first stanza is: 'pahale banati hai takadeere phir banate hai shareer,' 'ye sai ki kaareegari hai tu hai kyon gambhir', Remember, before your body arrived, your karmas were accounted for. \"Their karmas are so lowly, so good, so bad.\" Accordingly, birth is granted here. Meaning, it's predetermined. Destiny is shaped first, then the body follows. Hence, some are born millionaires, in millionaire homes from childhood, and some born beggars in poverty. It's already decided. It is predetermined. Destiny is shaped first, then the body follows. You have no control over it. Neither birth is in your hands, nor life. Do you know when death will come? Where? That's not in your hands either. Yet, 24/7, people say, I do this, I do that. What do you do? What can you do? You didn't take birth on your own, The Lord tossed you into the womb, so you came. Life too, lived by His grace. He gave breaths, so they continue. And you won't even choose death. Can anyone here claim, \"No, I know my death; I'll decide it?' Death is unknown when, how - no one knows. But in between, \"I am doing, I am doing.\" What are you doing? You can't do anything. 'Pahale banati hai takadeere phir banate hai shareer, ye sai ki kaareegari hai tu hai kyon gambhir' Meaning, from past lives' karmas, destiny forms, Prarabdha forms, and body is given accordingly. This is clarified. Good karmas bring joy, bad bring sorrow - you all know. But if joy comes, you'll get attached to it. And if you get excessive joy, and get entangles in it, you'll err unknowingly. It's not that after joy, no mistakes happen. Conversely, in joy, mistakes increase, because you're unconscious then. Not alert. Conversely, in pain, troubles, wrong actions decrease. Because the whip is already falling. What wrong will you do? But when life is going smoothly, mistakes multiply. So, joy is also dangerous - it leads to mistakes, then suffering. I say, joy is more dangerous than sorrow. One who understands this is wise. I repeat: Joy is more dangerous than sorrow. One who grasps this becomes a spiritual seeker. A movie line comes to mind, recent movie: If sorrow is written in fate, a reason forms anyway. If sorrow is written in fate, reason arises. If accident is meant to happen, it will happen. If you are meant to be bedridden for two months, you will. You can't escape it. If a fall or fracture is fated, it will happen. That is why, when life is going well, spend those moments in spiritual practice, in devotion. Then, when difficult times come, your mind will already be above body-consciousness - and you will not feel the pain in the same way. But our problem is, we remember God when in trouble. When life flows in comfort and pleasure, what do we do with God then? Everything is passing smoothly. But truly, that's the deception. For it is in times of ease that we commit mistakes, and according to those mistakes, suffering is bound to come. It will come - 100%. Thus, joy is more dangerous than sorrow. Do you know what the real problem is? When hardships befall us, we rush to the temples, we run to the Guru, crying - “Save me from this trouble!” But the Guru thinks, “This fellow comes to me every time, always bringing his troubles. Not once has he come before me saying, ‘Master, I have committed these wrongs. And because of them, I now suffer these pains. So first, whatever sorrow You wish me to endure, I will. But purify my tendencies, cleanse my polluted mind. If that is cleansed, sorrow will never again enter my life.’ But such a thought never arises in him. He only comes again and again saying, ‘Remove this problem, remove that problem.’ But why that problem came in your life? He never works on the cause. He does not wish to wash the filth of his mind. He only wants the outer effects corrected. He pleads - “No Baba, first take me out of this crisis.” And Baba says, “If I rescue you from this trouble today, you will commit an even greater mistake tomorrow.\" Therefore, purify your mind. Sanctify your mind. If there is no inner filth, then wrong actions will not arise. But how many go to God or Guru with this prayer? Tell me - how many truly approach the Sadguru saying, “I have come only to be cleansed. My mind is so impure, Baba, wash me clean.” How many go with such a feeling? Kabir Ji has said in a couplet: “Dil ka marham na mila, jo mila so garzi. “Dil ka marham na mila, jo mila so garzi. Kahe Kabir aasmaan phata, kahaan tak seeve darzi.” Our hearts remain wounded, filled with inner filth, yet we never reflect upon our own mind. We never come to God with that feeling. Whoever comes, comes with his own selfish desires, his own wants and demands. Kabir Ji says, I searched the cosmos, but didn't found solace for my heart Not one comes to the Divine saying: erase my mind's dirt. No, erase my problems. Erase my troubles. What is this? This is like watering a tree's roots, but only cutting branches from above. What will happen? “Dil ka marham na mila, jo mila so garzi. Kahe Kabir aasmaan phata, kahaan tak seeve darzi.” The Sadguru is saying, your mind is as vast as the sky, but it is torn and rent apart. How far can I mend it? You do such selfish devotion, and due to that, committing acts out of selfishness, you have torn your fabric so much; even if I stitch it, how far will I? But if, If your deeds are righteous, if your mind is pure, if your heart is sanctified, would you commit wrong actions? Would you fall into misery? But no one works on this, They only want a temporary solution. A sincere man would say, “No Baba, these sufferings have come to me because of my own deeds. I see how filthy my mind is. Give me whatever pain You wish, but first, purify my mind.\" Such is the prayer of an honest seeker. But the prayer of the dishonest is: “Leave my mind as it is, but remove all my problems.” Such is the prayer of the ignorant. And in the next stanza he says, 'naag bhi das le to mil jaaye kisi ko jeevan daan, chinti se bhi mit sakata hai kisi ka naamo nishaan,' Sometimes, even if bitten by a serpent (Kaalsarp), one survives. This is not an ordinary book rather an enlightening heritage His Biography in His own words The topic is: The Importance of Sai Stavan Manjari in Sai Sadhana. What is “Manjari”? It refers to a bouquet of flowers. In a bouquet, many flowers are collected and tied together — that gathered group is called “Manjari”. Before coming to Sai Stavan Manjari, I’ll first take two important verses from Sai Satcharitra. Because only after those two verses, the meaning of Sai Stavan Manjari will open up. Not at all That this man will bring from Pandharpur. That’s not possible. I wanted to shower them with precious gems. So come and cover my mortal body with flowers — that bouquet is the Stavan Manjari. Remember this — those aren’t physical flowers Baba has nothing to do with the roses on his body. He’s not asking for such superficial gestures But anyone who reads that line would probably think — “Yes, he’s asking to be covered with flowers.” No! What he’s really saying is this: All of Shirdi — these selfish devotees their selfishness has now dried up. They now believe that I am dead. But there is you — just you. Not a single line in this Manjari has come out of your heart with selfish intent. Every word is a true prayer. A selfless prayer. That’s why I want you to come. It was written 33 days ago. It was written on the 9th of September, 1918. And Baba took samadhi next month. On the 15th of October 1918 — exactly 37 days later — Baba took Samadhi. Baba is saying: “What you composed, on the banks of the Narmada, in Omkareshwar… that Stavan Manjari, which you created — now come and recite it to the world for the first time. This Stavan Manjari is the prayer of a true devotee, One who approaches Baba not with selfish desires, Not someone full of worldly wishes, But one whose heart is ruined by the filth of his own mind — This is the cry of that soul. Sai-na-Stavan Manjari is for the one who looks within and sees his impurities. Just like the verse in the 39th chapter of Sai Satcharitra: \"tadviddhi praṇipātena paripraśnena sevayā…\" The one who becomes conscious of his ignorance. Who sees clearly the filth within his mind. But You — You are the paris the divine alchemist. If You touch me, I too can become gold. Just once — with compassion — touch me. Make me Your own. O Lord, if You hold us close to Your heart, the dark night of our ignorance will fade away. We shall dwell in bliss, bathed in Your light — and what more could we ever need? I too will be called pure. Please, with the glance of Your mercy — run to me. Cleanse me. That is this servant’s only prayer. You are the paris. Demons or a person with vile qualities were killed for their hatred towards God Not a single saint has ever killed anyone. It’s not like demons didn’t appear before saints — perhaps millions of them stood face-to-face. But the saints struck at their vices, not the person. but instead transformed the demonic into the divine. They turned beasts into beings — raised the fallen to great spiritual heights. And so, Das Ganu Maharaj declares: \"In my eyes, saints are even greater than God.\" This is what Das Ganu’s Stavan Manjiri is about. Beyond poetic praise, he reveals that true stavan is not merely sung—it is lived through virtue, compassion, humility, and surrender.\n\nDrawing from Sai Baba’s grace, Krishnaji shows how praise matures into manasik puja, purification of mind, and steady remembrance of the Divine. The real Stavan Manjiri is the transformation of the heart, where every thought, word, and action becomes a garland at the Lord’s feet.\n\nFor seekers of Sai Baba’s path and lovers of devotional poetry, this talk is a guide from outer recitation to inner realization.\n\n\n\n\n\n\"सच्चा स्तवन मंजरी वह नहीं जो होंटो से गाया जाए, बल्कि वह है जो जीवन बनकर जिया जाए।\"\n\n\nसच्चा ‘स्तवन मंजरी’ क्या है? \nदास गनू महाराज की रचना का वास्तविक रहस्य – कृष्णाजी के शब्दों में\n\nइस गहन प्रवचन में कृष्णाजी, दासगणू महाराज द्वारा रचित स्तवन मंजरी का गूढ़ अर्थ उजागर करते हैं। वे बताते हैं कि सच्चा स्तवन केवल गाया नहीं जाता, बल्कि उसे जिया जाता है—सद्गुण, करुणा, विनम्रता और पूर्ण समर्पण के साथ।\n\nसाई बाबा की कृपा के आलोक में, कृष्णाजी समझाते हैं कि कैसे स्तवन क्रमशः मानसिक पूजा, चित्तशुद्धि, और ईश्वर का अखंड स्मरण बन जाता है। वास्तविक स्तवन मंजिरी हृदय का रूपांतरण है—जहाँ प्रत्येक विचार, वचन और कर्म भगवान के चरणों में अर्पित माला बन जाता है।\n\nसाई मार्ग के साधकों और भक्ति काव्य के प्रेमियों के लिए यह प्रवचन, बाहरी पाठ से आंतरिक अनुभूति की ओर एक सशक्त मार्गदर्शक है। …...more\n...more\nShow less",

One leela (divine story), comes from chapter 29, Captain Hate, one day Captain Hart is in Gwalior. He sees a dream where Baba is standing before him. Upon seeing Baba, he falls at Baba’s feet, and Baba says to him, “Why did you forget?” Look, the question is very important. Baba is asking Captain Hate, “Why did you forget?” So Captain Hate, as soon as the question is asked, falls at his feet and says, “Baba, if a child forgets his mother, how will he survive?” Then they leave from there. They buys Valpapdi, meaning beans, He goes to the garden and pick those beans, the vegetable that grows like a money plant. Once it grows, it spreads. From there, they pick the pods and also keep some money, ten rupees, and rice, ghee, lentils, raw grains, what we call provisions, and sends it to Shirdi. This story seems very simple to look at. means that there are some people, like us, who worship Baba for a short time, but then forget him for a long time. This story is for such people. Baba says that your bond of debt toward me is not strong enough, which is why you easily forget me. So Baba asks for raw grains, saying, “Give me provisions.” So the beans, raw grains, and ten rupees, they keep and sell in Shirdi. Baba says, even if you don’t perform the nine forms of devotion or anything else, it’s okay. But the food you make three times a day at home, before eating, if you set aside a morsel in my name and feed it to the world, I will be forever indebted to you. And even if you forget me, I won’t let you forget me. This story explains that. Please listen to this story carefully; this leela is not ordinary. It’s for beginners. Baba says, perhaps you cannot perform that level of worship. Baba says, perhaps the nine forms of devotion are not possible for you. Baba says, perhaps Karma Yoga, Bhakti Yoga, Jnana Yoga, or Dhyana Yoga are not possible for you. No matter, it’s okay if none of these are possible, but at least the food you make three or four times, before eating, take out a few morsels and offer them in my name to a cow, a dog, or someone else. Just do this much, and I will be bound by your debt, and that debt I can only repay when I uplift you. That debt will remain until I uplift you. Wonderful Leela That’s why the topic is: How to make Sai indebted to you. So, at the minimum in your life, whether you do anything else or not, whether you worship or not, every housewife should do this at the minimum level. Baba says, if you feed me like this, I will be bound by your debt, and I can only be free from that debt when I uplift you and take your soul to the divine. If they give such a great promise for such a small service, Baba takes a huge responsibility upon himself. So, please remember from today onwards, no matter what happens, after preparing food, we won’t eat at home without offering it to Baba. And this way, we will bind Baba in our debt. For example, I’ll give you the best example. Baija Maa, when Baba wasn’t so famous, in those days, Baba stayed in villages very little. He wandered in the forests. In those days, Baija Maa would search for Baba in the forests, crossing thorns and stones, searching where Baba was sitting, while Baba engrossed in meditation and she would feed Baba. And Baba repaid her by giving his life. Meaning, when it was time for Tatya Patil to go, Baba himself went but kept Tatya Patil alive. So, don’t take this leela lightly. The pieces of bread that Baija Maa gave, Baba always remembered that debt in his life. In the end, he sacrificed his life, but saved Tatya Patil. So, giving food to Baba is truly not a small thing. With good intentions, at the minimum level, every Sai devotee should definitely do this. Baba says, I get bound by your debt, and then I start worrying about you. Then, gradually, step by step, I can take you to progressive stages. That’s my responsibility, but at the minimum level, do this much. Sir, another incident comes to mind about offering to Baba. I’ll tell you, Hemant Pant’s chaana(grams) leela. In the driver leela, he comes back from somewhere and from his sleeves some grams fall. Baba mocks and says this man doesn’t give food to anyone and eats alone. So Hemadpant, like an ordinary person, says, “Baba, what are you saying? If there’s no one in front of me, So Hemant Kumar, like an ordinary person, says, “Baba, what are you saying? If there’s no one in front of me, “If there’s no one, am I not with you? When it’s time to eat, if you offer it to me, have you remembered me? Are you truly alone?” So remember, whenever you eat, offer it to me, remember me, and then eat. That’s absolutely right, absolutely right. What a great thing, what a great thing. If we do this much, we bind Baba in our debt. And Baba says, you feed my perishable body to keep it alive, but in return, I keep your eternal soul alive forever. That’s a huge promise. So, at the minimum level, do this sincerely. And if one family member forgets, another should remind them. It’s everyone’s responsibility. If you build this habit for two or three years, I guarantee your life will change completely. Try it and see. In a way, Baba takes the perishable and gives the eternal. One leela comes from the ninth chapter. In Tarkad’s house, the son says, “Papa, I’m going to Shirdi, but as always, you’ll offer the naivedya (offering).” But one day, they forget to offer the naivedya. So Baba, in Shirdi, tells Mrs. Tarkad, “As always, naivedya was offered at your house, and I stayed hungry waiting for it. When it didn’t come, I went to your house in Bandra, Bombay. Your doors were closed, but who can stop me? Because the game of debt between you and me is such. The depth of our bond is so great that even though the doors were closed, I entered, but I saw there was no naivedya for me. Baba says, the depth of our bond is so great. So those who always offer food to Baba, it’s a small thing, but a very deep thing. All spiritual practices are on one side, and this is on another. Remember, even if other things are missed, never miss offering a morsel to Baba before putting food in your mouth. Because this one thing makes Baba indebted to us, and Baba says, I will be free from that debt only when I uplift you, taking your soul to the divine. So, no matter what happens, make this a rule in your life: never put anything in your mouth without offering naivedya to Baba. Close your eyes and imagine putting a morsel in Baba’s mouth, and then Baba spits out some, and you mix that leftover with your food and eat it, so that the food becomes sacred for you. Keep this feeling always. It’s a small thing, but the benefits are beyond imagination. Your imagination cannot even reach there. We offer everything we make to Baba daily, but we never give food to others. I’m not saying you should go out and search, but when the opportunity arises, don’t miss it. For example, if an animal comes, or a bird comes, whether we should start offering Baba or we should go out in search of needy to offer with? Every time it’s not possible, I’m not saying go out deliberately and search. But when such an opportunity comes, don’t miss it. If a poor person comes, or someone unexpected, or a guest comes at mealtime, even if you have to stay hungry, let yourself stay hungry, but ensure the guest doesn’t leave hungry. And remember, if you stay hungry one day because a guest came suddenly and there was only enough food for you, and you gave that food to the guest, then know that those who fast on Shivratri, a hundred such fasts pale in comparison. So, have this clarity that no matter what, a guest will not leave my house hungry. These are the basics. But we don’t follow this. We keep strict fasts for Shivratri, but these basics we don’t hold onto. So, I’m not saying go out every day and search, but with ease, when such an opportunity arises, let it be ingrained in our consciousness that I will first satisfy the hunger of the one in front of me, and then put food in my stomach. Because Baba tells Tarkad, always do this throughout your life. In the ninth chapter, she feeds a dog, and Baba says, “I’m very pleased today. I ate to my fill today; my hunger is satisfied, my thirst is quenched, my hunger is gone. Today you fed me to my fill, and always do this: feed the hungry first, and if anything is left, then eat yourself.” This is Baba’s firm promise. So, Baba says, this way you bind me in the bonds of your debt. That’s why Baba asks Captain Hate, “Why did you forget?” He’s saying, if you keep feeding me, offering to me, and make me indebted to you, I won’t let you forget me, even if you try. That’s why I say, whenever you eat, remember me, offer to me mentally. Baba may not be physically present, but mentally offer a morsel to Baba, and imagine Baba eats some and spits out the rest. Mix that leftover in your food and eat it, so it becomes prasad This is a small leela, but its depth is great. And look, if we give bread to Baba in reality, does he really need to eat bread? He is consciousness; he has no body. But for now, we have to offer to him as if he has a body. We give him the perishable; in return, he gives us the eternal. We give him fake rupees, and in return, he fills us with diamonds, pearls, and jewels. So, it’s a strange deal. And who is a greater merchant than Baba, who takes the fake and gives the real? Okay, does anyone have questions related to this topic? when we make something, we take out a portion for prasad. Then we mix it with all the food we eat. Is that wrong? No, absolutely not. It’s perfectly fine. You’ve mixed Baba’s leftovers with everyone’s food. That’s a great thing. You can definitely do that. And always do this, but even if other spiritual practices are possible or not, don’t miss this. Just remember that. It’s not just a story that you don’t progress further. I want you to progress in further practices, but if for some reason that’s not happening, this is compulsory. And for animals like dogs or cows, what’s better? I say, build a habit. For example, on Thursdays, at least go and feed a cow, or after going out, feed the first animal you see. If you keep this intention on Thursdays, it builds that consciousness and habit. If you do it, it’s great. At least once a week. The first bread we make, we set aside for the cow, and the prasad we make, we offer a little to Baba, then mix it with all the food. That’s how we do it. But I’m saying, personally, on Thursdays, go out and feed a cow or a dog, or the first animal you see, even if it’s a pig. It’s Baba himself. This will expand the vastness of our heart. These small things, if we develop them slowly, our vastness will grow. We will see Baba in the universal form, and that’s what Baba wants. How long will you stay limited to the idol? Baba says, I am the universal expanse. Wherever your eyes go, it’s only me. Until we live that vastness, how can we achieve it? Heart-captivating, sin-destroying, ignorance-dispelling, liberation-giving, supremely auspicious.     "Transcript": "Om Sai Ram, today we will shed light on the story of the quarrel between Mausi Bai (Smt. Venu Bai Kaujalgi) and Anna Sahab Chinchankar, as described in the 24th chapter. One day, Baba was sitting on his seat in Dwarkamai. Anna Sahab Chinchankar was pressing Baba’s right hand, while on the other side, Venu Bai Kaujalgi—whom Baba lovingly called \"Mother\" was rubbing Baba’s stomach. She was massaging his stomach with great force, but Baba did not utter a single word of discomfort. Her way of massaging was so powerful that her whole body swayed back and forth, causing his face to come close to Anna Sahab’s face. At that moment, Mausi Bai jokingly said, \"Why, Anna, are you bringing your face close to mine to take a kiss? Listening to this Anna, quick tempered by nature, got disturbed and said, \"I have grown so old, don't I even have that much sense?\" In no time, the joke turned into a quarrel. But just then, Baba said to Anna, \"Why are you getting angry and tell me, what is wrong in kissing mother? Upon hearing Baba’s words, both of them calmed down, and the quarrel ended right there. One day, the same Mausi Bai was vigorously rubbing Baba’s stomach. Seeing this, a devotee present there, out of concern, said, \"Please massage a little gently, Bai, or else Baba’s stomach might burst.\" Upon hearing this, Baba got angry. He struck his satka (stick) on the ground in rage, stood up in anger, and placed one end of the stick against a pillar of Dwarkamai while pressing the other end against his stomach. He then started pulling the pillar toward him. As he moved closer, the stick seemed to pierce his stomach as if it would tear open. But just then, Baba calmed down and sat back on his seat. Friends, what lesson should we take from these two stories? This is what we will reflect on today. Chapter 24, which you just described, is a very humorous chapter. Baba’s sense of humor and his attitude toward wit Baba sometimes displayed very lighthearted moments, and this story is one of them. Mausi Bai’s story has two aspects—one humorous and the other deeply serious when Baba demonstrates his divine play with the satka. so, first we will talk about it's humorous structure Baba had a nature where he sometimes enjoyed humor and encouraged it. This entire chapter is related to that, but even within humor, there is always a deeper meaning. None of Baba’s leelas (divine plays) were merely for amusement. Even in humor, there was wisdom. In this story, Anna Chinchankar—whom Baba used to call the Narada Muni of Kaliyug As he was good at instigating quarrels among people. It seems as if he is paying the price for it in this chapter. So, Anna Saheb is massaging Baba's left hand, which is placed on the railing. And Venubai, also known as Maushi Bai, was massaging Baba's stomach. And they both moved closer, causing their heads nearly to collide with each other. Just then, in a jesting way, Maushi Bai said, \"Anna are you trying to kiss me?\" Anna was pure-hearted person but also short-tempered he reacts instantly. He immediately said, \"Am I such a fallen man? Am I a fool to take your kiss? You are deliberately creating a scene to argue with me!\" At that moment, Baba intervened between them and compelled the quarrel to end With his divine words, he says, \"Oh Anna, why are you holding on to such a small matter? Why are you getting so angry? What’s wrong with kissing a mother?\" That one sentence pierces Anna Chinchankar's heart, and he immediately calms down. However, through this leela (divine play), one thing becomes clear. Even though this incident appears humorous, Baba is imparting a deeper lesson through it. Do you know when a person becomes irritable? It happens when a certain tendency is already hidden within him. If there is an intensity of desire within me, then even a joke made in a lighthearted manner can affect me deeply. Baba is pointing out that inclination in Anna, as he got so angry at Mausi Bai's words, which were merely a joke—it was because that tendency exists within him. Why does a person get so restless? Tell me—if Mausi Bai had said those words to Anna Chinchankar in a jesting manner, I’m not saying that Anna had any lustful thoughts about Mausi Bai, but desires, from time to time, manifest their influence on our consciousness. That is why, in such moments, even lighthearted remarks can hit hard. Baba was pointing this out—if that inclination did not exist within you, you would have taken the joke as a joke and not become so serious about it. So today, Mausi Bai's words struck your heart, but the fault does not lie with her—it is your own vṛtti (inclination) that is to blame for your anger. This is what Baba wanted to convey. A person is affected by such things only when that inclination already exists within them. If he had truly conquered desire, he would have taken the joke as just a joke, in the same lighthearted manner. They wouldn't have become irritated so quickly, as Anna did in that moment. This was the first aspect of humor in the episode. Now, let’s look at the second aspect—Mausi Bai's service. Mausi Bai was massaging Baba’s stomach but she was doing it with such force that it seemed as if she was pressing his stomach and back together. Seeing this, one of the devotees sitting nearby, concerned, said, 'The way you are pressing Baba’s stomach, be careful! What if his intestines burst out?' The moment Baba heard this, he suddenly sprang up, his face turning red with anger And with great force, Baba struck his satka (wooden staff) on the ground. Then, he pressed one end of the satka against his own stomach and the other end against a pillar, pulling the pillar toward himself. It appeared as if he was trying to push the satka into his own body. The devotees watching were horrified—they felt that in just a few moments, Baba’s stomach might burst open. The gap between Baba and the pillar kept narrowing as he kept pressing the satka deeper into his abdomen. Now, the question arises—Was it necessary for Baba to get so angry? To answer it, we must look at two perspectives— one from the devotees' point of view and the other from Baba’s own standpoint. If we see it from Baba’s perspective, we can clearly witness his compassion and grace in this act. Through this act, Baba was conveying a profound message—if a devotee is serving me, no one has the right to criticize or object. I am capable of accepting their service, Baba himself refers to this in Ovi 140 of the Shri Sai Satcharitra: It is not for others to decide whether that service is right or wrong. Ovi 140 clearly explains that Baba is teaching us an important lesson: If someone is serving him—even if that service is not perfect or necessary—he has the strength to endure and accept it. Then why should others object to it? No one has the right to criticize or question that service. Through this, Baba's immense compassion is evident. He was so merciful that when someone served him, he accepted it as pure service, without judging whether it was right or wrong. This is the lesson he wanted to impart to us. This perspective represents Baba’s viewpoint, which reveals his divine character. His actions in this Leela were meant to demonstrate his unconditional acceptance. So, should all devotees learn from this and serve in the same way? from the devotee's point of view, the equation of this leela (divine play) changes significantly. Chapter 43, where there is an ovi (verse) by Hemadpant: \"Parabrahma Sagunamurti, Daive Asta Ushagati, Kharya Kharyachi hovini, Vismruti, Vinodhi Preeti Dhariyeli.\" What does this ovi convey? It says that the manifest form of the Supreme Brahman (Sagun Brahma) is standing before us in the flesh. \"Daive Asta Ushagati\" means \"He is standing by my bedside,\" showing how close my Baba is to me. But the true service (seva)—the real purpose of being near Baba—is spiritual knowledge (Brahma Gyaan). That is why it says, \"Kharya Kharyachi Hovini Vismruti\", meaning we have forgotten the real purpose. We have never truly remained aware of the actual purpose of life in Baba's presence. Instead, \"Vinodhi Preeti Dariyeli\", we spent our entire lives in a lighthearted, playful manner despite being so close to him. Now, this ovi contrasts with the teaching in Chapter 24 Baba has said that he accepts the service offered by devotees however they choose to serve him. On the other hand, this ovi from chapter 43 reflects deep regret: \"We spent all our time in jest in Dwarkamai, in the presence of Baba and we never truly grasped the purpose of life.\" It expresses the sorrow of having been so close to divinity but never realizing its deeper significance. So, from the devotee's point of view, this ovi holds immense importance. The leela (divine play) mentioned in this chapter is from Baba's perspective. Different viewpoints exist, just as in the Ramayana, we see the example of Shabari. Shabari had been yearning for Lord Ram for countless lifetimes. She spent years preparing for his arrival —spreading flowers along the path he might walk But she was worried: \"What if the berries I offer are sour?\" So, she tasted each one before offering it and bifurcated the sweet ones Unknowingly, she was giving Lord Ram half-eaten berries. Yet, Ram accepted them with immense love, just as Baba accepted Mausibai’s service with affection. It his greatness and compassion. But, if we look at this story from devotee's point of view then there are 2 verses from the same chapter which will clarify it. ovi 110 and 111 of the same chapter: \"Saiche hi nishkapata prema, Devuni gheti seva anuttama, Sai accepts even imperfect service (anuttama seva) when given with pure, selfless love. Ki te nijasmaran avishram, ghado ho kshem bhaktasa.\" Let the devotees remain absorbed in Baba's remembrance is the mere goal behind that service. Even if her service is imperfect, at least she are doing it with me in her heart. her love is pure and unwavering. service that was not perfect and He is ready to endure such service for pure love In ovi 111, it is said: \"Aapuli tapascharyati kiti, jine ladhavi sant sangati, What great spiritual efforts have we made to deserve such close association with a saint like Sai Baba? And then: \"Phari Saiche deen vatsal, nishchiti upekshi na bhaktate.\" \"Sai is compassionate toward all devotees and never neglects anyone, regardless of their nature.\" This clarifies Baba’s perspective on such devotees. Now, coming back to your question: Should we take this as a lesson that we can serve Baba however we like? One of Baba’s 11 promises states: \"Jaisa bhav, tyaisa anubhav.\" (\"As is your faith, so shall be your experience.\") If a devotee serves in any manner, Baba does not stop them. In fact, Baba even demonstrated in his leelas that he would go to great lengths to protect a devotee’s faith, as seen in the story of Satka. However, if we compare Mausibai’s service with another devotee’s service from Chapter 35—Balaram Patil Nivaskar Balaram Patil used to sweep the paths Baba walked, ensuring that no thorns or pebbles would hurt Baba’s feet. Now, what we should take from this is up to us. If we keep Balaram Patil Nevaskar’s devotion in mind, we may choose to serve like him, or we may choose to serve like Mausi Bai, massaging Baba’s stomach in devotion. Each devotee must decide for oneself. In the 13th chapter, in the Kshetra-Kshetragna Vibhag Yoga, Sant Dnyaneshwar Maharaj speaks about his devotion to his Guru. He says, Do you know how I serve my Guru, Nivriitinath. If my Guru walks barefoot, I will become his sandals. If the scorching sun troubles him, I will become an umbrella to shield him. If he wishes to sleep, I will become a soft, velvety bed. I will turn into fragrant breezes and wave before him. I will transform into nature itself, solely for my Guru’s service.\" This too is a form of service. So the question arises—what kind of service should we offer? In this chapter, Mausi Bai’s service is indeed excessive—there is no doubt about it. However, from Baba’s perspective, his compassion knows no bounds. The leela (divine play) of the satka (stick) in this chapter reveals this. If we focus on the phrase \"अनुत्तम सेवा\" a new dimension emerges. It seems as if Baba is using this leela to tell us that many devotees come to his court who are not completely pure or sattvic. They come with difficulty, and only manage to hear a few words of divine wisdom. If such people offer service with a slightly tamasic inclination, it is still acceptable— because at least they have come to Baba’s presence. Through this, they get to hear even a few words of knowledge and light. This gives them a chance for transformation So Baba’s message is: do not reject or discourage such people. Another, perspective on the phrase \"अनुत्तम सेवा\" is that some devotees are like lifeless pillars—they are deeply ignorant and lack awareness. In order to awaken them and fill them with consciousness, Baba has to endure great suffering. Only through his pain can he bring light into such beings. so, you are being roadblock in my work is what he is saying to the devotee To pour the light of wisdom into such ignorant devotees, I must endure suffering; to fill a lifeless being with knowledge, devotion, and detachment, I must bear pain. Baba had a devotee named Megha, who was a staunch devotee of Lord Shiva. Another Sai devotee, Nana Saheb Chandorkar, gave Megha a picture of Baba, which Megha worshipped day and night. In this way, Megha worshiped picture at home and Sai Baba in Dwarkamai One day, Megha had a divine vision in which Baba appeared and scattered sacred rice grains over his bed. Baba instructed Megha to draw a Trishul (trident). Megha suddenly woke up and was astonished to see that the rice grains were indeed there, just as they had appeared in his vision. But the door to his room was closed. How could Baba have entered? Megha immediately rushed to Dwarkamai and asked Baba about it, “Baba, you came to my house, but the door was closed!” Baba instructed Megha to go back home and draw the Trishul at his home. The next day, a Ramdas devotee arrived in Shirdi and offered a Shivling to Baba, who then handed it over to Megha. So, dear Sai devotees, Megha was first instructed to draw a Trishul, and the very next day, he received a Shivling. What is the deeper meaning of this? Let’s reflect on it today. Om Sai Ram! Om Sai Ram, 28th chapter of Sai satcharitra depicts a beautiful story about Shivling and Trishul that it goes like this - Megha, one of the ardent devotees of Baba, had an image of Baba given by another Sai devotee, Nana saheb chandorkar and Megha worshiped that picture regularly with discipline. One morning Megha had a vision of Baba instructing him to draw a trishul and bestowing rice grains over his bed and Megha worshiped that picture regularly with discipline. One morning Megha had a vision of Baba instructing him to draw a trishul and bestowing rice grains over his bed and with this megha wakes up and finds rice grains scattered over his bed. Evidently, he ensures Baba's coming But he was in a dilemma upon finding that the door was closed. and on the next days, goes to the mosque to meet Baba and asks, \"Baba, yesterday i had a vision.\"\\ just then Baba says, \" Don't talk about the dream but tell me if you have drawn trishul as i instructed you.\" Over which megha says, \"Actually, Baba, I didn’t understand this—I saw the Akshata, but I couldn’t figure out where you came from because the wada’s door was closed.\" Baba then explained, “I am the master of all. I exist everywhere. I have no fixed form or boundary. I don’t need a door to enter. I can come from anywhere.” Following Baba’s instructions, Megha went home and drew a red Trishul. The next day, a devotee from Pune, a follower of Ramdas Swami, came to Shirdi and offered a Shivling to Baba. Baba accepted it and handed it over to Megha, instructing him to worship it. Megha was overwhelmed with joy. This is how the story goes. So, the question that arises is—Baba first gave a vision and instructed Megha to draw a Trishul. Later, he physically gave him a Shivling. Through this, was Baba trying to convey that Megha should worship the Shivling? Or was he subtly hinting that he himself is Shiva? What exactly is the spiritual message that Baba intended to give? That is what we need to understand Chapter 28, Megha is a shiv devotee and Baba has a unique nature that he grants experiences based on a devotee’s form of worship, strengthening their faith But before we analyze this story, as you just mentioned, the chapter describes the tale of Trishul and Shivling. Now, Megha was already worshipping Baba’s image when he lived in the wada This is clearly mentioned in the scripture. Let me refer to the Ovi (verse) for better clarity. vi number 189, Chapter 28 states: “The mosque holds Baba’s living presence, while the wada contains his image.” At that time, there was only one main wada—Sathe Wada. Most devotees who came to Shirdi for Baba’s darshan stayed there. Megha had placed a large image of Baba in the wada, almost like a life-size portrait, and worshipped it with deep devotion performing aarti and rituals daily, both in the morning and at night. Now, if we observe closely, Baba's image in the wada and Baba sitting live in Dwarkamai —are they the same? Philosophically, they are one. But as an ordinary devotee, I may not comprehend this easily. A natural distinction forms in my mind: \"Here is a picture of Baba, and there, in Dwarkamai, he is physically present.\" This creates duality There is a distinction, right? Over there, Baba is present in a living form, and here, he is in the form of an image. To understand this better—consider that the image of Baba in the wada represents the soul (Atma), while the living Baba in Dwarkamai represents the Supreme (Parabrahma). Baba in Dwarkamai is full of consciousness and universal life energy (Vishwa Prana Shakti). That’s why the phrase \"Brahma-Atmaik Yoga\" is often used —meaning the union of the individual soul (Atma) with the Supreme (Brahma). Indirectly, Baba was revealing a deep truth—the journey of the soul toward the Supreme. So how does this journey take place? This is exactly what Baba’s Leela (divine play) explains further. Baba first tells Megha to draw a Trishul (Trident). What does this symbolize? Trishul represents spiritual effort (Purushartha) It is also a symbol of Shakti (divine energy) —urging Megha to channel all his strength toward spiritual realization. Then, Shivling can be held over it. Now, imagine a vertical Trishul standing upright. If we were to lay it down horizontally and place a Shivling on top of it, what does it form? The symbol of Om (ॐ)! This is profound! Baba was guiding Megha toward the realization that the day one understands the mystery of Omkar (ॐ), the journey from the soul (Atma) to the Supreme (Parabrahma) becomes easy. So, the journey from the soul (Atma) to the Supreme (Parmatma) is only possible through Omkar. And to reach Omkar, one must first make spiritual efforts (Purusharth) to attain Trishul. and when you reach till trishul then master, out of compassion will make trishul sit on it and proving omkar However, the deeper understanding of Omkar will be explored in Chapter 50, where we will try to open its mystery based on the divine light Baba has given. For now, it is important to understand that to travel from the individual soul (Atma) to the Supreme Brahman (Parabrahma), one must fully grasp the depth of Omkar. Until Omkar is fully realized, the journey remains incomplete. When Trishul and Shivling unite, they form Omkar. Wow! And this is the true worship of Shiva, a deeply profound and spiritual form of worship. The essence of this leela. Through this leela, Baba wants to say - praṇavo dhanuḥ śāro hyātmā brahma tallakṣyamucyate the wholesome purpose of this leela is to illuminate the depth of this sholka from mundaka upanishad The essence of this lila is not merely about the Trishul (trident) and the Shivalinga, but rather, it signifies the entire journey of the universe—because the entire cosmos is contained within this physical body (pind). This is the journey from the individual soul (Atma) to the Supreme Soul (Paramatma). This is the journey from an ignorant being burdened by illusion to becoming one with Brahman. The only purpose of Sai Satcharitra is to reveal 'purn bramha swarpchyut, aisa ha jeevatma purvavat, kadhi tari swaswarupat, pavava nischit he dhey' that every soul, which has fallen from its state of complete Brahman consciousness, will eventually return to its original divine state. this union of trishul and shivling is not merely a coincidence, it is omkar and this omkar is the scultor of entire universe",

Many people have a misconception that only those who practice Pranayama (breath control) in yoga can raise their life force. But that is just a preliminary process to stabilize the mind. What Baba is referring to is something much deeper. In the book \"Chidakash Gita\" by Nityananda Maharaj of Ganeshpuri, this spiritual mystery is explained. Nityananda Maharaj rarely spoke, He never had any discourse in front of many people but in the years 1922 to 1924, he shared some spiritual insights, which were recorded by a devotee named Tulsi Amma. In the \"Chidakash Gita,\" he gives an example of a pressure cooker to explain how the life force is raised into the universe. Imagine a pressure cooker with grains and water inside. When the cooker is placed on the fire, the water starts boiling, our mind is like the grains mixed with water impure mind and the fire represents our intellect with discriminating power. that inclines towards good over bad and repents for sins The one who has the strength to keep the mind heated on the fire (of discipline and self-control) is like a pressure cooker. When the cooker is placed on the fire, the water starts boiling, and steam is generated. The steam builds up pressure until it reaches its peak and is released through the whistle. That is Bramharandra the blowing whistle represents the opening of the Brahmarandhra (crown chakra) and the steam generated is the ascending life over universe So, when the conflict between mind and intellect reaches its pinnacle, the life force of ours ascends into the cosmic expanse. Baba says, \"I am raising my life force into the universe for three days.\" This is the Vimaan (aircraft) that he was talking about. The process of raising the life force into the universe involves the constant struggle between the mind and intellect. The mind is always restless, wandering in desires and impurities, a web of illusions, which is why the mind itself is called Maya If you want to purify the mind, then the intellect must work on it with great intensity. And if you have taken up this struggle with the mind, then it is not a struggle of a few moments; it is a lifelong struggle because the mind is mischievous. It keeps creating disturbances 24 hours a day, and the intellect must constantly purify it. This conflict, this friction between the mind and intellect, generates a third power, which is the upward movement of the life force (Prana). This Prana begins to rise upwards, which we call Kundalini. As soon as this energy builds up, it starts pushing upwards, and when it reaches its peak, it emerges from the Brahmrandhra (crown chakra) like a whistle and spreads into the universe. that is real Viman (aircraft), the one Baba is talking about This is a profound statement Baba is making about Kaka Saheb Dixit. One reason is that because of these four things he did not allow them to mingle easily, did not allow to be trapped, he used to work on that. Those who were close to him it was his work to take them towards that which is eternal otherwise this destructible would swallow them. The main reason was this. The direction of sleeping, say Baba used to sleep with head in the north and these two in the east and west, if you see this deeply, he did not allow their heads to meet, he comes in between. He does not allow the heads of Tatya and Mhalsapati to meet, he has come in between. And honestly speaking those who are walking the path of integrity, those who are living in their household and following their householder’s dharma want to be into devotion, those who want to live spirituality, in those households also Baba comes in between. The difference of opinion will always come. Then the question arises why does he come in between? In reality we have this misconception that towards the family members we have lots of love. Love is a very big thing, actually we are miles away from love. The pure love, selfless love towards each other we are miles away from that. We are entrapped in attachment towards each other. Attachment to wife, attachment to children, attachment to home, attachment to family but we have believed that attachment to be love. This is the bitter truth and we have to accept that. Love has not as yet penetrated far into our minds. Without purification of mind the stream of pure love cannot flow within. It is impossible. But we have given this false attachment name of love and we will leave the world this way. This is the bitter truth. So, what Baba used to do is in the house he did not allow heads to meet. What does meeting heads mean? If there is husband and wife and they agree, means head is one, means they agree, the thought process becomes one then the body intelligence will become more intense and will increase further. The lie will spread further, the lie will become denser. Baba used to come between the two heads that means he created clashes between them so that the attachment between them drops and the real love awakens. Related to this there is a statement from Jesus’s teachings I would like to mention that because it is very relevant. Mathew Chapter 10 Verse 34 – He says that I have not come here to spread peace but I have come with a sword. This is what Jesus says. I have not come to establish peace. I have in my hand a sword, a weapon. I will turn a son against his father and a daughter against his mother, a daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law. These are Jesus’s statement. Its not a small thing. Then he says a man’s enemies will be members of his own household There will be no outside enemies his own household members will be his enemies I will take that precaution. I will make them each other’s enemy. Like Jesus’s statement there is a similar verse in Sai Satcharitra. Adhyay 32 Verse 57 – Je je ghade te dev ghadavi, toch utaravi toch chadavi, Toch lade athva ladvi, karta karvi to ek. Which means that whatever happens in our life, happens because of the Lord. He only brings us down and he only pulls us up. He fights and also makes us fight. Please pay attention to this statement - He fights and also makes us fight. He is the doer of every karma means he is the one makes it happen. We should not take it negatively. You have to have a big heart to understand this statement. We have to accept that we do not have love between us. We are trapped in each other’s attachment; we keep serving each other’s interest and spend life. We will call love pure when selfishness drops and will live and die for my wife, the day I will live and die for my child, there will be no self-interest. That is pure love. But here there is give and take. It is business. And the root of this business is attachment not love. Baba is indirectly saying that he wants to drop the attachment between the two and so you two should go against each other and I will only take that precaution. So, when there are such situations in life you should not be afraid, if you understand the deep meaning behind this then attachment will drop and probably true love will take birth. Behind this story this is the depth is what I feel. The essence of this leela In the name of love, wearing the robe of attachment, I am carrying this body on the shoulders of the soul. O Sadguru it is due to your grace, that with your every blow the twist is opening. I am carrying my own corpse on my shoulders and walking. Every moment, wearing the mask of false love, I am unknowingly flirting with death. This attachment and this false love have become the identity of your eternal love.
