    "Transcript": "Om Sairam. Today, we will shed light on the story of Shri Gopal Narayan Amdekar as depicted in the 26th chapter of Sai Satcharitra. Shri Amdekar, a resident of Pune, used to work in the excise department. He was posted to village named jowhar in thane district. Due to some reason he lost his job and became unemployed, leading to a gradual decline in his financial situation. Being a devotee of Sai Baba, whenever he visited Shirdi, he would share his sorrows with Baba. Seven years passed like this, but his circumstances did not improve at all. Then, he thought that if he stayed in Shirdi for a few months and served Baba, his situation would surely improve. With this thought, he went to Shirdi with his family and stayed for two months, but even after doing all this, his financial condition did not change at all. Disappointed, he contemplated suicide one day and decided to jump into a well As he was about to take the plunge, Shri Sagun Meru Naik, a devotee of Baba, called out to him and asked, \"Have you ever read the book of Akkalkot Swami?\" Out of curiosity, Amdekar took the book, opened a few pages randomly, and began to read. He came across the story of a devotee of Swami Samarth who was deeply distressed by adversities and had also decided to end his life. He jumped into a well to commit suicide, but at that very moment, Swami Samarth appeared and rescued him, saying, \"It is not possible to escape from this world without experiencing its joys and sorrows. Suicide will not solve anything.\" Upon reading this story, Amdekar was deeply shaken. He realized that through Sagun Naik, Baba had sent him a message. He abandoned the thought of suicide. Further, in his ancestral devotion to Swami, Baba firmed him. Within a few years, Amdekar mastered the art of astrology, which provided him with a livelihood and brought him prosperity. This story raises two important questions: Firstly, why did Amdekar, a devoted follower of such a powerful Guru like Baba, face such financial hardships? Secondly, in the 29th chapter of Sai Satcharitra, Baba states that one should not seek astrology. Yet, Amdekar himself sustains his life through success in astrology. So, should one seek astrology or not? We will explore these questions in today's episode. Om Sairam. Before we delve into the story itself, let's briefly discuss the significance of the 26th chapter. A distinctive feature of this chapter is that whenever devotees of other gurus would come to Baba, He would reinforce their faith in their respective gurus. Filled with devotional feelings, He would send them back to the path they had originally chosen. This was a unique quality of Baba. For instance, Bhakt Pant, a character in this chapter, had his faith in his guru strengthened by Baba and was sent back to his guru's path. Similarly, the Pitale family, whose guru was Swami Samarth (who is also mentioned in the story), had their devotion to Swami Samarth deepened. And at last, Amdekar his ancestors' devotion, his father's devotion, is very deep towards Swami Samarth. So, Baba's feeling is that this person should go back there and get engaged, and that the ancestral sentiment, the devotion, should always remain alive within him. So, Baba is seen as pushing him towards Swami Samarth with a single-minded determination. This is the uniqueness of the chapter that Baba places devotees to their respective Guru to whom they are devoted The extent of Baba's vast compassion is proven in this chapter. Baba never had such narrow minded sentiment of making disciples whoever came to him So, wherever devotees had their devotion, they were sent back to where they belonged. This is the special characteristic of this chapter. Now, let's come to the story of Ambedkar. Ambedkar worked in the Excise Department of Jawhar This Excise Department, in the British era, was responsible for handling the excise duty on liquor. Now, we all know that when people work in such departments, their dealings with money become very close. Even today, people who work in such departments have a bad reputation, as it is said that they embezzle a lot of money. So, perhaps in that era too, Ambedkar might have made similar mistakes, maybe he misused the money. Then, the British government dismissed him from his job. After losing his job, his financial condition deteriorated drastically. Despite his devotion to Baba, he would often visit Shirdi and plead with Baba to find him a job or improve his financial situation. However, his financial condition continued to worsen. Through this leela (divine play), Baba wanted to convey a message: whenever we face difficulties in life, whether they are financial social, mental or physical we are responsible for it. Our actions are the cause of it, Through this lila, Baba wants to first tell us that if any kind of trouble comes in your life, then it is not without a reason. Your own actions are the reason for it, because without actions, there is no fruit. So, as you sow, so shall you reap. So this is the undeniable truth of the world. So there, Baba is trying to say, through this divine play, that perhaps that person was misusing money, so he lost his job, and then his financial condition kept deteriorating. And he became completely disturbed. So this doesn't mean that because we are Baba's devotees, everything will be fine, and Baba will only do good things for us if we simply worship him. If Baba were to do that, then we could never become truly righteous people. And as long as our morality and our dharma are not intact within us, then the avatar of Sai which has come to pour out the treasure of spirituality would be in vain. Main purpose of Him as a avatar is not come to fulfill our desires. Fulfilling desires is just like a chocolate in the beginning, like Baba says, if I have to give you bitter medicine, I first give you jaggery. So even if our desires are fulfilled to some extent, the sole purpose behind it is to first strengthen our faith in them. And then, using that faith as a foundation, they can guide us towards spirituality. This is Baba's method. So, it doesn't mean that we can do whatever we want in life and then turn to Baba's devotion when we're in trouble, expecting to get away with it. It's not possible. we have to bear the fruits of our actions. But, Sai's power can reduce some of the pain, provide some relief, but the fruits of our karma have to be borne. it's an undeniable truth. When he was completely exhausted and distressed, and when there seemed to be no hope, he thought, \"may be, as i visit shirdi once in a year to have Baba's darshan, my pain has not reached Baba.\" With feeling that if i would stay in shirdi for a long time in front of Baba then he might pity me and help me, he stays there for two months with his family He keeps presenting his troubles before Baba every time he visits, but Baba hasn't granted him relief. Then, when he sees that their prayers seem unanswered, he eventually fall into despair. This leads him to feel a rising sense of hopelessness and thoughts of ending their own life emerge. When that mindset takes hold of them, one day, he decides to isolate himself and end his life. He finds a secluded place, sit on a bullock cart, and contemplate jumping into a well to end his suffering. At that moment, sagun naik appears. He asks him, \"Have you read this holy scripture?\" Ambdekar replies, \"No, I haven’t.\" He hands over the book, and as the ambdekar opens it, Baba's compassion shines through. As soon as he opens the book, he comes across a story that mirrors their own life. It feels as though the story is about him, even though the character in the story is someone else. In the story someone else was suffering due to an illness, unbearable pain, and despair. That person had also considered death as the only way out. But when he tried to jump, the swami saved him and brought him back to safety. and after rescuing him out, Swami Maharaj delivers a lesson to him which has immense importance. I will take the verses as it is to make it clear. swami samarth appears there. rescues the afflicted All the suffering in your life are due to your past actions. They are not random. You need to endure the consequences of your actions, Suicide will not solve anything. Illness, Leprosy, Suffering, and Ailment in your life are due to your past actions. If you do not endure and complete the consequences of your actions then Suicide will not solve anything If your suffering remains unfinished, you will have to take another birth and suffer again from where you tried to curb it committing suicide . Believing you can bypass it this way is a futile thought. And so, bear with it as best as you can but do not commit suicide This is one of the teachings of Swami Samarth. He once told a devotee that in life, do whatever pleases you, but never resort to suicide. Just as murdering another person is considered a heinous crime, taking your own life is equally heinous, if not worse. He even said that if you hear of someone in your neighborhood committed suicide, never shower flowers on such person's body during the final rites. Instead, place a garland of shoes on them because such a person has committed an unpardonable crime. Similarly, here, Baba is explaining to Ambedkar that if today, in a moment of despair, you decide to end your life, your soul will not find peace. Instead, it will turn into a wandering spirit. You’ll roam the world as a ghost for countless years. You will witness the lives of future generations, but you will never be able to interact with them. You’ll see them, but you won’t be able to express your emotions to them. You’ll roam the world as a ghost for countless years. You will witness the lives of future generations, but you will never be able to interact with them. You’ll see them, but you won’t be able to express your emotions to them. You’ll suffer silently for what might be 100, 200, or even 500 years—no one can say for sure. Eventually, when the divine grace of the Almighty intervenes, you might be freed from this torment. But until then, your suffering will continue. This is the grave reality behind suicide and that’s what Baba is trying to make Ambedkar understand. He assures Ambedkar, “I am here. If you have faith in me, then hold onto that faith. Whatever pain and intensity of suffering you’re experiencing, I’ll help ease it. But the burden of enduring it lies on you.” Hearing these words, something stirs deep within Ambedkar's heart, and his thoughts of suicide vanish. Just as Swami Samarth once saved a distressed soul from drowning in a well, here too, Baba rescues Ambedkar, granting him a new lease on life. Not only does Baba save his life, but he also ensures that Ambedkar finds a means of livelihood. and guides him to master astrology, which becomes a source of income for him. Through this, Ambedkar leads a prosperous life, as described in the scriptures. Baba not only gives him new life but also secures his livelihood. Baba then instructs him, “The devotion your father had for Swami Samarth should be just as deep in you. Now that you’ve come here, I am sending you back to your Guru. From this day onward, dedicate yourself entirely and exclusively to him.” This story imparts several lessons: Thoughts of committing suicide—a heinous crime—should never cross anyone’s mind. Devotion to Baba or any divine figure does not absolve us of the consequences of wrong deeds Committing suicide condemns the soul to become a wandering spirit, watching the lives of future generations unfold but unable to interact or find peace for centuries. If we delve into the depth of this teaching, it becomes clear how profound this leela is. Additionally, in Chapter 29 of the Sai Satcharitra, Baba advises against practicing astrology. However, here we see that Ambedkar masters astrology and builds his life upon it. So, whether one should see astrology or not. First of all, the question you raised about Chapter 29, where Baba explicitly says in his divine words - 'do not be taken in by anybody, do not show the horoscope or rely on palmists' and here in 26th chapter Baba didn't advise ambdekar to pursue astrology Ambedkar had an inclination toward astrology, and Baba, seeing his interest, encouraged him indirectly. Baba remained silent, silence itself can sometimes be a form of encouragement. That silence, in a way, can be interpreted as Baba allowing him to pursue astrology. But let us clarify this further because this is a very good question. The question you have raised is very delicate and sensitive. Listen carefully, or else you might miss the point. For example, God forbid, if you were to have an accident, your head is injured, your eye is hurt, and your hand is fractured —head, eye, and hand. But you are conscious, you can speak, and the doctor comes and tells you that out of these three, you can save only two. You will have to lose one—head, eye, or hand. Naturally, you would want to save your head and eye, right? Similarly, if someone is on the verge of committing a heinous act like suicide, the primary goal is to save their life first for the Master. Although his trivial inclinations have been satisfied, at least for now, he has stepped back from suicide and understood the value of life. Take the example of a pregnant woman with complications. If a doctor tells her only the mother or the child can survive, most people would say to save the mother. Baba’s focus was on saving Ambedkar from suicide and helping him realize the value of life, even if that meant letting him pursue something Baba usually disapproved of. So, first, let the head remain safe; later, we can decide which turban to wear (metaphorically). When to remove and discard Jyotish Shastra from his life—Baba knows this better. So, out of compassion, Baba has given him a little leeway. This is how it should be understood. Otherwise, saying that Baba has encouraged Jyotish would be incorrect. This is a very delicate and subtle subject. Baba in the 29th chapter utters, \"Do not depend on the birth chart, do not trust astrology.\" whereas in this chapter he remains silent It is described that ambdekar has propensity towards astrology and therefore He(Baba) remains silent as his life is saved Otherwise, this person would have committed suicide and wandered as a ghost for 100, 150, or 200 years. At least now, he has been saved from that suffering. If his inclination is toward Jyotish, let it be for now. In the future, I, as the Sadguru, will remove the deep-rooted tendencies within him. This is the clarity Baba has. This does not mean that Baba has encouraged astrology. This is a very delicate subject. If we understand its depth properly, it simply means that what Baba is saying in the 29th chapter is absolutely true. This is the truth. If we follow Baba's divine guidance, we should trust our efforts and hard work in life, and know that Baba is with us. This seems very clear, but if we assume that Baba has encouraged astrology, then we will fall into doubt again. I hope this clarifies your question.",

    "Transcript": "In the tenth chapter of \"Sai Satcharitra,\" it is described how Sai Baba used to sleep in Dwarkamai. A devotee once gave him a wooden plank. It was a marvel how such weak rags could bear both the plank's weight and Baba's. The people of Shirdi were curious about how Baba climbed and descended from such a height. Some devotees even kept watch to uncover this mystery. Irritated by this scrutiny, Baba eventually burned the plank in the Dhuni Years later, Baba spoke to Kaka Saheb Dixit about the spiritual significance of sleeping on the plank. that if you are fond of sleep on the plank and if you permit then i will arrange similar sort of plank Baba declined, saying it was not appropriate to leave Malsapati below and sleep above him. so dixit said that he would arrange another plank for Mhalsapati but Baba explained, \"Sleeping on a high plank is no simple task; it is not something just anyone can do.\" This entire account is mentioned in Chapter 45 of the Sai Satcharitra. Friends, today we will explore the spiritual depth hidden behind this extraordinary act of Baba. Om Sai Ram. Baba always performed such acts in solitude, not with the intention of showing them off. However, many people did witness this unique practice. The remarkable aspect of this miracle is how Baba managed to sleep at such a height—12 feet above the ground—on a plank tied with tattered rags. The Satcharitra describes that these rags could not even bear the weight of the plank itself, The question arose in everyone's mind: How did Baba climb and descend from such a height? The Satcharitra further states that for someone like Baba, who could transform into a fly or a mosquito by mere willpower, this act was not difficult. If Baba desired, he could assume such a form, ascend to the plank, and then revert to his normal state to sleep. This was as easy for him as it is for us to walk. The most remarkable feature of this miracle is that Baba, while sleeping on the plank, kept one lamp lit near his feet and another near his head. This seemed to signify that his entire consciousness, from head to toe, was filled with radiant light —something rare in ordinary human lives. If a person were to embody light from the top of their head to the tips of their toes, only then could they achieve such a spiritual elevation to sleep at such a height. The question arises: how does one attain this light? This brings us to the concept of Kundalini energy. Kundalini, as described, rises through the seven chakras. According to the scriptures, a person who practices immense honesty, integrity, and purity of mind may reach the fourth center, However, ascending beyond that to the Vishuddhi (throat) chakra, and then to the Ajna (third eye) chakra, is said to be extremely challenging. Beyond that, ascending from the Ajna chakra to the Sahasrara (crown chakra) is even rarer. Only a yogi of Baba’s caliber, who has transcended all limitations, can reach such spiritual heights. So, Baba's spiritual journey from the Muladhara to the Sahasrara was complete. We clarified this in the previous episode, where Baba went into Mahasamadhi for three days. It was said that he elevated his life force to the Brahmarandhra, meaning his ascending energy had already traversed to the crown of the head. That is why he had become pure consciousness from his feet to his head. The lamp burning at his head and feet symbolizes this state. The torn strips, instead of which Baba could bind with rope if he wished, signify the body-consciousness. Until the body-consciousness deteriorates and turns into shreds, the soul cannot ascend to the sky, the Chidakash. There, it is not the body that reaches the Chidakash, but the soul that finds its place. Once it reaches the sky, it spreads everywhere. The ascension to this height means that the soul has reached the Chidakash. Now, the question arises: how does one reach such heights? The story continues. When Kakasaheb Dixit asks, “Baba, as you’ve mentioned the plank today, should I arrange one again?” Baba replied, “No, it’s not right to leave Mhalsapati below and go up.” He is just an excuse for giving us guidance. It’s not for everyone; not everyone can manage it.” Let me take a verse to explain this better. From Chapter 45, Verse 136:‘ Nahi phadevar shain sope’ kon tiyevar mazvin zope, nain ughade nidra lope - where sleep ends, and the eyes remain permanently open. such a one can sleep on it. When he dozes off, his hand becomes as heavy as stone on my chest. He pointed out that those who have not conquered sleep, who lack control over it, are, in essence, no better than stones. As such there were no restrictions on anybody coming to Masjid but Baba had restricted Haji Siddhique Falke from coming to the Masjid. He was very disappointed with this but he did not give up. When he came to know that Madhavrao Deshpande will be able to help him take Baba’s darshan, he requested Madhavrao to help him take darshan and Madhavrao also respecting his request spoke to Baba about him and asked for his permission to allow him to come to Masjid. Then Baba said, “Oh Shama, Allah has no mercy on him. Then how can he come to this Masjid? Since you are asking, I will give him permission but ask him if he will be able to walk the pathway near the Barvi well properly?” When Madhavrao told this to Haji he said how much ever full of thorns the path maybe I will certainly walk but give me the darshan of his feet. When Madhavrao told Haji’s reply to Baba said, “Will he be able to give me 4 times Rs 40000/- Go and ask him.” Madhavrao told this to Haji. Haji smiled and said what is Rs 40000/- If Baba tells me I will give even Rs 40 lakhs also. Listening to this reply from Haji Baba said to Shama, today there is a thought to slaughter a goat in Masjid. Ask that Haji if he wants flesh, flesh with bones, or testicles of the goat? Haji Siddhique Falke character was not an ordinary character. Many times, while walking the path of spiritually we generally meet two kinds of people. Sometimes one meets on the path of spirituality a person who has thirst for it and other one I say is the one who has spirituality itch. 99% people have spirituality itch to be honest. But there is 1% who has thirst for spirituality. Haji Siddhique Falke had that thirst. Because he believed Baba to be a guide, Sadguru he reaches Shirdi and wishes to take Baba’s darshan and he was chased away for 9 months again and again. He was not allowed to take darshan also. Inspite of this, he stayed there for 9 months. It is clear from this how deep his faith and patience are. Only a true thirsty person will stay with patience inspite of been chased away. From this itself what kind of character he is, is known from his wait of 9 months. 9 months has lot of relevance in the spiritual world. It is said that a child who is in the womb, the pain in the womb is very severe. The heat in the mother’s stomach, the child who is in the faeces urine in the stomach taking shelter there and stays alive, suffers hell there, it is said that the child yearns to get freedom from there, when he will be free from this stench and misery. It is also said he prays incessantly that he comes out from this door of hell and I will be devoted to you all my life and will take your name. It is written and said so. The moment the child comes out he is engulfed by Maya and he again forgets. 9 months has lot of importance. It is said that it takes 9 months for a person to reincarnate. Similarly in the spiritual world Baba wants to say for 9 months haji Siddhique Falke was chased away. Even then he remained in my prayers for 9 months. If we see the Charitra carefully then in Adhyay 9 of the same Charitra there is another leela where a foreigner comes to meet Baba. He sets up a tent and stays separately and he goes for Baba’s darshan and Baba stops him saying you will not come. But he feels insulted, what is this? He is just a fakir and what is this pomp. He is unable to handle this situation and he thinks of leaving, to hell with the Darshan. I will not stay here. I will leave. People go to Baba saying he is disappointed and he is folding up the tent Baba says tell him that he should not go today, he may leave tomorrow. There also Baba says something in his favour. But he feels that if you do not want to give me darshan then why should I obey you. So, he leaves. But the story tells that when he is riding the Tonga while reaching Kopergao he meets with an accident and he fractures his hands and legs and he is admitted to Kopergao hospital. To be very honest, today also when we go to Shirdi if we have to wait for few hours in the queue then we get upset. We wish to take Baba’s darshan as fast as possible and return. There also we want VIP passes. We should get darshan as fast as possible. We are living in this era. Really how wonderful those days must have been. Now I have in hand a real thirsty person and now I must refine him. Baba thinks this and when Shama goes to Baba with his request, Baba’s court is open then why are you tormenting Haji Siddhique Falke. Why you don’t give him darshan? Baba says in Adhyay 11 Verse 95 Shamya tuzya othancha jar, ajun nahi valala tilbhar, Nashta allahchi khudarat tayavar, mi kay karnar tayasi. It means you will not understand these things. In Sufi sect it is said for 12 years if someone sticks to his Guru like his shadow then by the end of 12 years there will be no difference between that Guru and the disciple, both become One. It is so believed. See the importance of 12, understand that in the morning if the Sun is shining, in the morning at 6.30/7.00 you stand in the Sun and the Sun rays fall on you then your shadow will go very far, early morning. But as the time lapses 9, 10, 11, 12, at 12 the Sun is above our head and the shadow comes closer to us and exactly at 12 that shadow merges into us. Similarly, that disciple, that devotee who sticks to the Sadguru like his shadow, who respects his feelings, who understands his inner feelings and lives accordingly, like that shadow he come close and closer, after 12 years that shadow merges into Baba. All the three seem to be the same but they are not. The meaning of flesh is, in your life the pride that you have for all the name, fame and money are you willing to sacrifice? Flesh (meat) means pride of the body, the me ness which is there in every person’s mind, I will do something and show, I am something, can you put this at stake, can you give that to me, I am going to cut that. Are you ready for cutting that? In the first question he is saying that. The flesh with bone is attachment with the body. If for a person the upper cover breaks then the next cover is even subtler, attachment to the body. Attachment to the body means I may not have big dreams but I should be healthy, my family should be healthy and my basic things should always be healthy This attachment towards one’s own body and towards the family, my basic things should not go out of my hands. I want a job so that I can feed my family. This is the attachment to the body. On the superficial level pride of the body is tamo guna. Now this is the basic thing every person expects that my life should be at least this much healthy. I must have at least this much. But Baba is asking are you willing to give me that also. Private organ is even subtler, body intelligence. I will put your existence itself at stake. I want to destroy you are you willing to perish? He has hit his basic existence itself. Are you ready for that? He says Baba anyway I do not want anything; he says if he gets a piece of bread from his alms pot then I will be grateful for that. So, he pointedly tells that I really want nothing I am ready to perish in every way. That is why he is asking for renunciation. With the alms pot you are not the owner you are a beggar and a beggar has no right to demand that he wants to eat this or that. Whatever is received as alms is accepted for sustenance. He is telling that in every way he is ready for this journey. This Adhyay is talking about been erased and a true traveller on the path of spirituality is the one who knows the sweetness of being perished. The one who understands that there is a sweetness in perishing, is the sign of true traveller of spirituality. With these three questions he finds out that he is ready in all aspects, he is really a thirsty person and has not come with the itch of spirituality. I want to destroy even his body intelligence he will perish. I will get results. Baba sees this and, in a way, he is testing him. And when he sees that he is truly ready and he gets up and he takes the alms bowl and water filled pot and throws it breaking it. By doing this leela alms pot is where the food is kept and in the pot water that means he keeps him away from food and water means he made him face towards death because what is the basic food and water due to which survival happens and breaking that means to make him face death. Because till such time he perishes he cannot be made. There he is saying this by breaking it and makes him face death and that death which one likes and finds it sweet. Such a person will not fear because from within such a person knows to perish is to be anew. It is like a drop perishes to become an ocean that perishing is like this. The one who is going to perish knows well what it is to perish, what its sweetness is, my one-point existence will become all pervading existence. It is that kind of destruction. That person knows very well the sweetness in being perished and also knows well the depth of it. Baba breaking both the things shows that now I have put him on the path of perishing, from now onwards he will start liking death and will not be scared of it and then he bits his hand. Hand is the symbol of karma, of doer ship, Baba bits that. There he has bitten baba Siddhique Falke’s doer ship and then he goes to Haji Siddhique Falke. Then his Sattvic ego, and all his life the good deeds he has done and spiritual practices he had done, does he have that sattvic ego. Baba test that and there also Baba hurls abuses like you use your old age, do you read Quran like that, showing off that you went to Mecca all these lines, here he tells him that all the spiritual practices that you did in your life have you got Sattvic ego of that. He is washing off that in those words. That also should not remain. And after saying that he goes and sees that now he is ready in all aspects, now all his pride of body, attachment to the body and the body intelligence are all ready to perish and he is ready to perish. When he sees this then at that moment when the gardener’s wife is carrying mangoes in the basket, Baba purchases everything and sends it to him. Here Mango juice means God’s love, that sweetness. He fills him with love. Initially any devotee begins with love and we have not yet reached to bhakti. Mango Basket means love, pure love but it is not converted to Bhakti. By giving the mango Basket he in Haji Siddhique Falke donates love. After some time, he goes and gives Rs 55/- What is Rs 55/- There is sutra 55 in Nardiya bhakti which is a very important sutra where what real bhakti is, is defined by Narad Mahamuni. In that sutra 55 he says Tatprapya tadevavlokyeti After he gets into the Bhakti he sees his Guru, his God, in every particle. Tadevavlokyeti Such is his bhakti. Then he says tadaiva shrunoti If at all he wants to hear something then he wants to hear his Guru’s greatness only and he does not like anything other than that. Tadaiva bhashyayati if at all any words come out of his mouth then he will only speak about the greatness of his Guru. He does not spend his words on anything else. Only that comes out of his mouth. He wants to talk about that only. Tadaiva chintayati – after receiving bhakti he does not like to meditate on anything other than Sadguru, his father. So first his love goes denser and deeper and then it converts into devotion. Rs 55/- means devotion. Mango basket means love and after becoming an expert in devotion and seeing God in every particle and after sometime when Baba sees that I can reward him with Brahma meals then he calls him for having meals that is Bhrahma meal and we can say that it is the culmination of the journey. It is the destination of the spiritual journey. He thinks of him as eligible for the Brahma meals and making him sit near him saying I will make you the enjoyer of that Brahma which I also enjoy. I will feed you the same food that I eat. My meals are your meals now there is no difference between you and me. In a way this whole thing is a spiritual journey, where this journey begins and where it ends and in a way Haji Siddhique Falke is a subtle spiritual inner channel which reaches to its ultimate. If we see the whole story carefully then we see that many people have spiritual itch but Haji Siddhique Falke has true thirst and this story also tells us that this path is so tough, difficult. It is one thing to listen and understand and another thing to live it. That is why I say again and again that the one who knows the sweetness of perishing is truly thirsty. That is why Lord Krishna in 7th Adhyay of Geeta says in shloka 3 manushyanam sahasreshu kashchid yatati siddhaye yatatam api siddhanam kashchin mam vetti tattvatah Only one in thousand can digest the knowledge, becomes a siddha and amongst such siddhas one such siddha knows me completely as I am. That is why he says that it is not for everyone but if you are truly thirsty then a Sadguru like Baba is still with us. He also says that you take a step forward and I will take thousand steps towards you. His compassion is clear but there is lack of readiness on our part that we can reach him. So this whole thing is spiritual inner journey is what I would say. This leela and the questions and answers in that is actually an inner journey of a spiritual traveller. In this book in Adhyay 35 there is verse 137 – Bhaktigyanvairagyahin, Aisa jo bhakt toh ati din, Tayas Pratham vairagya sthapun, bhaktigyan mag deti. This means that the devotee who is without devotion, knowledge and non-attachment is actually like a beggar, all such devotees are made to sit on the throne of non-attachment, made to wear the crown of non-doer ship and then devotion and knowledge is donated. In this world Guru himself is without non attachment inwardly he is the master of sattvic show off and sweet words. Traditionally these hallow things have come in hand and the same garbage is handed over to the future generations. Only one of many Gurus is true. Karma, devotion and knowledge are priceless if they have non attachment. Without non attachment this karma, devotion and knowledge are only ordinary words. In this leela first Baba carves the devotee, make him a renunciate and then moment to moment gives him the nectar of love, devotion and knowledge. In this world blessed is that Guru who has the capability of perishing his disciple from within and blessed is that disciple in whom the sweetness of perishing has awakened.",

    "Transcript": "Om Sai Ram! In the 51st chapter of Sai Satcharitra, there is a story about Shri Pundlik Rao and the coconut given by Shri Vasudevanand Saraswati, also known as Tembe Swami. When Pundlik Rao went to meet Vasudevanand Swami, the Swami gave him a coconut to offer to Sai Baba. when Pundalik rao headed shirdi to offer coconut he accompanied himself with his 4 friends during the journey they got thirsty and with the intention they halted by the canal. But one of them said, \"It is unhealthy to drink water empty stomach\" someone brought chiwda (flattened rice), but it was too spicy. Someone suggested, \"Mix the coconut with the chiwda, and it will taste better.\" As soon as this was said, the coconut was brought forward. It was immediately broken, mixed with the chiwda, and everyone ate it, drank water, and continued their journey. On the way, Pundlik Rao realized that the coconut mixed into the chiwda had been given by Shri Vasudevanand Swami to be offered to Sai Baba. Now he was worried and filled with regret about what he would present to Sai Baba upon reaching Shirdi. With these thoughts, Pundlik Rao reached Shirdi. When they all went to see Baba, as soon as Baba saw Pundlik Rao, He said, \"give me what my friend has sent for Me.\" Hearing this, Pundlik Rao was utterly embarrassed. He confessed everything to Baba and said he would bring another coconut to offer. But Baba replied, \"Even if you bring thousands of coconuts, none will be like the one given to you. Now don’t regret it unnecessarily. When I had the desire to call you, that very moment the coconut came into your hands, and it broke according to My wish. Don’t burden yourself with unnecessary guilt because whatever good or bad you do, it happens only with My will.\" Friends, two questions arise here. First, why did Baba insist on the same coconut when Pundlik Rao wanted to offer Him another one? What was so special about that coconut? Second, from the first chapter to the fiftieth chapter of Sai Satcharitra, the focus has been on human effort and hard work (purushartha). But suddenly, in the fifty-first chapter, Baba dismisses the concept of effort and says, \"Whatever good or bad you do, it happens only with My will.\" This contradictory is beyond comprehension. These are the points we will shed light on in today’s episode. Pundlik Rao's story is about a devotee from Nanded who travels all the way from Maharashtra to rajmundry, a city of Andhra Pradesh to have darshan of Tembe swami. As swami comes to know that Pundalik rao hails from Nanded and since Nanded is close to shirdi, he gives him a coconut and said, \"Take this to my Baba (Sai Baba) and tell Him that I seek His grace and blessings. May my devotion and love for Him grow stronger day by day. This is my heartfelt wish, and I am entrusting this coconut to you.\" The essence here lies in the sentiment with which the coconut was given. Tembe Swami, despite being a renowned saint on the path of karma (action), revered Sai Baba with deep devotion and humility. The value lies in the sentiment, not in the coconut. The coconut was a medium, a symbolic representation of his devotion, but valuable are the feelings emerging from his heart His intention was that his feelings be conveyed to Baba through the coconut. Pundlik Rao, however, leaves for shirdi after the passage of a month Therefore, the memory of this responsibility loosened up. and compels him to forget it's importance Later as the story tells when hunger struck during the journey, he had some chiwda (flattened rice) but found it too spicy. To counter this, he broke the coconut and mixed it with the chiwda. This satisfied his hunger, but it wasn’t long before he realized his mistake—that the coconut meant for Sai Baba had been used. When Pundlik Rao reached Shirdi and met Baba, the first thing Baba said was, \"Where is the coconut sent by my friend? Pundlik Rao was filled with shame and confessed the entire incident to Baba. He apologized profusely and offered to bring another coconut to replace it. But Baba replied, \"Even if you bring a thousand coconuts, they cannot equal the one sent by my devotee.\" The sentiment and devotion with which it was sent have already reached Baba Indirectly, Baba conveyed to Pundlik Rao that it wasn’t that you ate coconut but you indifferent the faith and sentiment behind it. And therefore even if you bring 1000 of coconuts to offer, they cannot match the one given by my brother.\" so, saints know each others feeling is the depth of this story. and their gaze always rests on the inner intention, not on the external object. Pundalik Rao, completely overwhelmed mentally, was feeling very low. Only then did Baba speak further, asking why he stood before Him with such a heavy heart. Baba said, \"You didn’t intentionally do it. As if You remembered it completely and ate it giving more importance to your hunger than offering. Yes, a mistake happened, but why hold onto unnecessary regret? Taking advantage of this Baba is inscribing a deep spiritual teaching in Pundalik rao saying.\" Do you know why are you regretting too much? because you nurture you ego on doing some good deed that it forces you to regret over such a small mistake.\" The ego you maintain over your virtuous actions is actually the reason behind this regret. If you would not hold onto the ego of your good deeds, you wouldn’t feel this remorse. Those thoughts would not have occurred. You would have been free from ego for both when Baba sees that Pundalik Rao is completely embarrassed and has realized his mistake, He then offers guidance, saying, You didn’t intentionally eat the coconut. It happened by mistake, it slipped your memory, and that mistake occurred unintentionally. So why carry unnecessary regret? To comfort his heavy heart, Baba expresses, “why do people own their meritorious deeds alone and not their sins?.” This is a very sensitive statement, as it is often misunderstood. People often misinterpret this by thinking that Baba is saying you can neither commit good nor bad deeds, as I am the doer you shed your pride as doer but who can except Baba know that which vow apply on whom and when When Baba speaks about 'Zor Tumhi Kadho Laga, Phalachi Kalgi Sarvaswityaaga', which appears in Chapter 19, He emphasizes the concept of Purushartha Unless you do Purushartha, you will not be bestowed with Siddhis by Me. However, as the fifty-first chapter progresses, the idea shifts to the need to relinquish both pride in virtues and sins. Only when both forms of ego are overcome can one reach the peak of humility and true surrender. And 101% this applies to those who have reached the pinnacle of spiritual effort. In the beginning stages of spiritual practice, no true Guru can impart such teachings to a disciple. This understanding must first be internalized. Consider, if i am at the initial stage of spiritual practice and my guru stands in front of me telling me to shed the ego over virtues and sins, it is not possible at all as without virtuous deeds how one can have ego over it. To carry the ego of virtues, i need to execute many good deeds If, hypothetically, I have acted recklessly and with little devotion towards the virtues taught by the scriptures or the Sadguru, then those words do not apply to me from Chapter 51. In the beginning, Baba's words for Purushartha that What is right, what is wrong? What is dharma, what is adharma? What is righteous, what is unrighteous? First of all, I need to gain full knowledge of it, and according to that, with full devotion and patience, I must live my life. And the day when i get exhausted by the effort even if I have spent a long time doing it without achieving ceaseless devotion towards Baba. So at that moment, the Sadguru Himself descends into my life and tells me that Krishna, after today, the ego of virtue, passion, or ignorance will no longer remain in your life. Whatever is happening in your life, the real doer is I. However, those words should come at the right time. They should come through the Sadguru. I cannot adopt those words on my own. And the Sadguru gives those words only when they have seen that despite doing so much, one has not attained siddhi (spiritual accomplishment). One's ego has melted, dissolved. Now, if I instill depth into that egolessness, then it will get fully absorbed in his heart. And if you sit nurturing the ego of the virtue (sattva gun), then, in reality, just as ignorance (tamo gun) is bad, in the same way, even virtuous actions (sat karma) are perilous because the virtuous actions are like chains of gold, while non-virtuous actions are like chains of iron. Both must be discarded as both captives You must reach the peak of that egolessness, where Brahma-knowledge becomes easier. But one must reach that stage to listen and grasp these words Baba is also speaking of these words at Chapter 51—meaning towards the end of the scripture. The chapters before that focus on effort (purusharth). If I haven’t truly fulfilled that effort, if I have not exhausted myself in that effort, if my ego has not melt. So, no Sadguru will implant those words in my life. Additionally, those words should only come at the right time through the Sadguru—today, after this moment, you should no longer harbor that ego. I should not adopt such words prematurely. Currently, if I am in the stage of effort, and if I am in the initial stage of sadhna, then the verse from Chapter 91 that you mentioned zor tumhi kaado laaga, phalachi kaalgi sarvaswatyagaa—which speaks of the immense struggle, And understanding what is right and what is wrong, what is dharma and what is adharma, must be fully followed no doubt. Even after doing so, in the realm of my actions, my efforts, I will not attain God. Because if that happens, my ego will grow so much that there will be no limit to it. My actions cannot lead to God-realization, but the potential to melt that ego increases through my actions. The depth of my devotion towards effort determines the extent to which my ego dissolves. Even though I may not realize it, in my efforts, my ego of doership is gradually melting. Despite years of effort and practice, despite all the sadhna (spiritual practice), siddhi (spiritual accomplishment) still eludes me, my heart is not purified, and I do not attain unwavering devotion to Him. When my heart realizes that despite doing all this, I still remain nowhere, and when I surrender everything, laying down my arms, and bowing my head at the Sadguru’s feet, at that moment, the Sadguru descends. Then, the words from Chapter 51 are imparted to me, and I don’t adopt those words on my own. Instead, they are received as blessings. This subtlety is why I say that after reaching Chapter 51, these words come from Baba. The previous fifty chapters focus on effort. Therefore, before speaking of such things, one must carefully consider if there is a devotee at the initial stage, ensuring they are not misguided. If such caution is maintained, I believe we will carry out a very responsible task. Otherwise, we might lead even sincere individuals onto the wrong path. There is great subtlety involved. And let me refer to the Bhagavad Gita as well. The Bhagavad Gita has eighteen chapters, with the majority focusing on Karma Yoga. They emphasize converting actions into Karma Yoga, transforming actions into virtues. As you go through virtuous deeds, sattvic ego naturally increases. At that point, the Sadguru feels it is the right time to guide towards diminishing that sattvic ego, and at that moment, the teachings of Chapter 51 are given. Hence, in the Bhagavad Gita, from the first to the last, the teachings evolve—from karma, devotion, knowledge—to surrendering all dharmas to seek refuge in the divine alone. Until this clarity is achieved, the spiritual path can become daunting and lead astray. Therefore, at the right time, with the right guidance, we remain firmly on the path, moving forward in the correct direction and Baba will bestow His blessings I believe this is a highly sensitive subject, requiring clear understanding of which teachings apply to us and which do not. If each person internalizes this deeply, I believe they will progress better. Through this leela (divine play), Baba is giving us two lessons. The first is that you can buy thousands of coconuts from the market, but where will you find the sentiment (emotion) that cannot be purchased in the market? That sentiment emerges only as sanskaras (impressions) after a lifetime of burning in the fire of my dhuni (sacred fire). Now, the second and final lesson from this leela: to reach me, you must pass through four \"Pr's. Pr means Prayas (effort), Pr means Prarthana (prayer) Pr means Pratiksha (patience/waiting), and Pr means Prasad (grace or divine blessing). To reach my grace-like prasad, everyone must go through effort, prayer, and patience. The end of doership (ego of actions) is possible only after endless efforts in Karma Yoga. Just as deep sleep comes after physical exhaustion, similarly, samadhi (spiritual absorption) comes after exhaustion of conscience. Even in the nine forms of devotion (navadha bhakti), only after practices like archana (worship), vandana (salutation), and dasyam (servitude) does one reach sakshyam bhakti (complete surrender). Similarly, in the sequence of yoga, yama (restraints), niyama (observances), and asana (postures) come first, and only then do dhyana (meditation) and samadhi follow. In conclusion, my heart says this about the leela: no matter how great a warrior someone is, they reach their destination only by walking the path.     "Title": "एक नर ही नारायण बनकर अवतार लेते है",
    "URL": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GoV5ZVP9cpo",
    "Transcript": "Om Sai Ram A topic arose in my mind, I’ll begin with that \"It Begins in Bhakti, and Culminates in Bhakti\" I will unfold the meaning. There’s a verse we all know: “Yada yada hi dharmasya glanir bhavati bharata…” This shloka declares that whenever Dharma declines and Adharma rises, I manifest myself again and again to restore Dharma. So does that mean only God can incarnate? This is what we've been taught: That whenever unrighteousness prevails in this world, God incarnates again and again to destroy Adharma and reestablish Dharma. Lord Krishna said so \"Abhythanamadharmasya tadatmanam srijamyaham\" But I have a question, for you all: If it is always God who incarnates and restores dharma, then what relevance remains for Advaita philosophy? Does it mean that, through His own maya, He Himself gives rise to adharma, causes turmoil in the world, and when people are utterly helpless, He Himself returns to protect them? Doesn’t this sound shallow? Doesn’t it feel meaningless? And this is exactly what we’ve been taught That God keeps incarnating in different forms, we even have a list of the Dashavatara. Great, ten divine incarnations of Vishnu. But again, we are told: Whenever righteousness falters and Adharma rises, The Lord, repeatedly manifests himself, to destroy Adharma But, I don't believe in this Because if that were so, then it would become a kind of divine tyranny and man would remain just a puppet. Then what need would there be for human effort, for sadhana, for striving? Living the Advaita philosophy would lose all its value. Please understand this carefully. So, what does Advaita mean? That the individual soul and the Supreme are one - there is no difference. The jivatma and the paramatma are one and the same, we all accept this If they are truly one, then when the jivatma attains the Supreme, can that same Individual Soul not return to incarnate? Why must the Supreme Soul return again and again? The reality is, the interpretation that we've made is very superficial that Supreme Soul takes the avatar and comes again and again. No, it's not like that. If an Individual Soul walks sincerely upon the path shown by the Lord, if one follows His footsteps, understands His heart, acts accordingly, and continues, undeterred by obstacles, completing the spiritual journey - then he too attains that same completeness, He and the Divine become one. In reality, if that Individual Soul still retains the sacred resolve that “I must serve,” and with this divine resolve, He dissolved into the Divine. then that same Individual Soul returns to this world - as Sai Baba, as Swami Samarth, as Gajanan Maharaj. That means, when the journey of a jivātma comes to its sacred completion, it becomes eligible to descend again, as an Avatar If it is so, then Advaita has a meaning. If that’s not true, then Advaita is meaningless. Then Individual Soul is just a puppet. \"I will make you dance, and you shall keep dancing.\" I will give liberation, whenever I want to That’s dictatorship! God is not so petty. He is magnanimous—so magnanimous that if He chooses to give, He gives His very own Self, His very own completeness, to His devotee. This is an Avatar. But the concept that has been planted in our minds that it is always the same Divine who keeps incarnating… Well, if that were true, then what glory remains for human upliftment? The very value of human striving has been lost. Then human birth itself is in vain. If the jivātma could not behold its own completeness, if it failed to attain the wholeness it was born for And if that soul could not descend again, bearing its own completeness then honestly, I’d say this whole creation, this whole cosmos, is just a farce. It means we have terribly misunderstood it. And that's why in today's topic I'll prove how it is How the journey begins with devotion, and ends with it. and every Avatar, Be it Sai Baba, Swami Samarth, or Gajanan Maharaj Their journeys began in devotion and ended in devotion. Today, they shine forth as embodiments of devotion. They know the entirety of yoga. They are filled with the deepest of knowledge They know the secret of all karma. They know everything and still - they appear in this world as embodiments of bhakti. Now let me describe this journey: How does an Individual soul reaches Supreme Soul? Let us look at the life of an ordinary person. He begins with simple devotion. He knows nothing of Karma Yoga, Bhakti Yoga, Jnana Yoga, or Raja Yoga He only knows simple, straightforward devotion. As he deepens in devotion, truths begin to reveal themselves The first truth that dawns upon him is this: “All my devotion so far was laced with selfishness.” \"But Selfish devotion leads nowhere..\" \"I must practice selfless devotion.\" This is the first awakening. As his devotion deepens, he understands: “My devotion must be without desire.” Whoever his chosen deity is, whoever he worships with love he now realizes that his devotion must be selfless, without any demands. This is the very first stage - the primary stage. The first insight: “My devotion must be selfless. I must ask for nothing.” “Whatever the Divine gives me, I accept, but I’ll never let go of His devotion.\" “Be it heaven or hell, suffering or comforts - I shall not abandon devotion.\" “Because now I know, only unconditional devotion is true devotion.” \"Desireless devotion is true devotion.\" He reaches that first stage though he hasn’t yet fully achieved it - He is trying. He begins to practice Nishkaam Bhakti And yet, whenever he compares his bhakti to that of Tukaram Maharaj, To Namdev Maharaj, to Jnaneshwar Maharaj he finds himself lacking. A yearning awakens in him: “When will that kind of true devotion awaken in me?” his journey is progressing and deepening. Then he realizes: Without purification of the mind (chitta-shuddhi), you cannot have the devotion of Sant Jnaneshwar or Tukaram. Purity of mind is essential. So, “How do I purify my mind?” And he discovers: By practicing Nishkama Karma Yoga. That alone purifies the inner being. So now he learns the first yoga And the journey began with simple devotion, He realizes: “Unless I live selfless action in my life, my devotion will not deepen.” \"Only then can I aspire to the bhakti of Jnaneshwar Maharaj\" Scriptures say there are three impurities in the being Mal, Vikshep, and Aavaran We are filled with three impurities. The three Supreme Ailments Mal, Vikshep and Aavaran Mal means inner impurity - all the negative tendencies, all-together is Mal. In Chapter 16 of the Sai Satcharitra To overcome these three afflictions, first, mala must be cleansed - through selfless action. If there are three illnesses, then three remedies have also been given So, impurity(Mal) is destroyed through selfless action Second is, Vikshep means restlessness of mind. Not even for a moment is the mind still. Not even for a second does it find peace. Even when one sits to meditate, the mind wanders. I merely perform the outer practice each day But true meditation never happens Because mind is restless, as Vikshep still exists in the mind And until you remove that Vikshep, you cannot truly meditate. To remove vikshep, the answer is Upasana(Spiritual practice) And Upasana means, the ninefold devotion. In Sai Satcharitra’s Chapter 21, a character appears - Anantrao Patankar. He has studied the entire Vedas, absorbed all the Upanishads, understood the scriptures thoroughly. And yet, his mind cannot remain still, even for a moment. He comes to Baba and says: “Baba, I’ve heard that you grant people, samadhi, in an instant. “Despite all my effort, I cannot still my mind even for a second.” Baba narrates to him a strange tale \"What's the big deal in this? He says - there was a merchant. He owned a mare. The mare passed nine stools. The merchant was action-oriented. He rushed, gathered those nine droppings in his garment, clutched them to his heart, and in that moment, his mind became completely still. Anantrao Patankar is bewildered. “What is this story? I came to this man believing him to be a great yogi. I thought he would give me some key, teach me how to meditate - and instead he shares this bizarre tale about a mare and her nine droppings!” Then Anantrao Patankar asks Dada Kirtankar - one of Baba’s oldest devotees \"What did Baba just say? What did I even ask, and what kind of answer did He give? Is this how your Baba usually speaks? He speaks in such profound language\" He gets into trouble by hearing this, Baba increased his trouble, as he narrated him such a tale that he wasn't able to understand Then Dada Kirtankar tells him: “Look, the language of Baba is extremely profound But through years of association with Him, I have come to understand this much - That merchant - he is the seeker ready to pay any price. And the mare - she is the Divine Grace of God. She passed nine droppings - meaning, nine lumps of dung. And he gathered those nine lumps to his chest. That dung symbolizes the nine forms of devotion - Navavidha Bhakti. So, until our mind becomes absorbed in those nine forms of devotion, until they enter our life, This is known as Upasana Upasana means Navavidha Bhakti - nine characteristics of devotion And in this, we practically enter into worship, into Archan Because our body, mind, and wealth - all three are involved. This is called trikarana shuddhi In meditation, all three often do not engage. Something remains held back. So, if true inner purification is needed, then body, mind, and wealth must all be surrendered to the Divine. And this only happens in Navavidha Bhakti. When your mind begins to rest in Navavidha Bhakti, the restlessness of your mind will begin to dissolve. That means the second affliction will be healed. Now this devotee begins to understand Yes, the first defect was Mal, and Mal is removed through selfless action. But, forget performing selfless action in the world, we can’t even practice it at home! Even there, we find ourselves thinking - ‘I do so much for you, can’t you do this little for me?’ At home. How will we ever live selfless action in the outside world? So, these are the three defects, Mal, Vikshep, and Aavaran. Mal is removed through selfless action And look, this is practical spirituality, not theoretical. If there are three diseases, then three yogas are needed as remedies. First, Selfless action to eliminate Mal Upasana or Bhakti Yoga to remove Vikshep And the third is Aavaran, that remains even after mala and vikshepa are gone. “I am not the body, I am the soul”, this knowledge remains covered until the veil is removed. To remove that veil, just one Mahavakya, uttered into the ear by the Sadguru, or even declared in a gathering “You are the Supreme Brahman”, and in that very moment, one becomes Brahman, because Mal and Vikshep have already been eliminated. Baba says in the Sai Satcharita: Even to meditate, true knowledge is required. If the true awareness of the soul has not awakened in the heart, if clarity has not dawned, then how can one meditate on the Supreme? One must first have the true knowledge of that Supreme Form so that meditation can even begin. So, before dhyana, comes jnana complete awareness of the Self. And when does that complete awareness arise? Only after Mal and Vikshep have been removed If Mal and Vikshep are still present, then even if you take millions of births, you will not attain complete awareness. Our problem is this - I speak some bitter truths. Our greatest weakness is: Neither has our Mal been removed, nor our Vikshep, And yet we sit down directly for meditation. Even if we take countless births, we will not attain spiritual realization This is a very serious matter. Let me give an example, Imagine a piece of iron. But I cover the piece of iron, entirely in a thick layer of clay, It is completely covered by clay, And I'm placing a magnet besides it, will it stick? Even if you try to stick the magnet to it, it won’t adhere. Our meditation is like that. The mind is covered in the clay of Mal and Vikshep and we keep trying to meditate, we are trying to stick the magnet, keep trying - but it will not stick. We are deceiving ourselves. But when a Sadguru arrives, and he begins to rub that clay off with nishkama karma and upasana, then even if the magnet is kept far - once cleaned, it will instantly adhere. And that is when true meditation begins. So, unless mala and vikshepa are removed, dhyana is not possible. Now the Aavaran, Aavaran is eliminated, at the very moment when the Mahavakya is addressed, as Mal and Vikshep are already removed. It’s only a matter of the Mahavakya being directly addressed - by the Sadguru, by a spiritualyy eligible person. it pierces straight into his heart, and meditation begins So, that is Aavaran, it is removed through jnana. Now see, when all three are removed, then true Brahman meditation begins 'Kitakisahi bhramar dhyan, thene ti labhe bhramar pan' Even a small insect, if it keeps revolving around the flower long enough, eventually it becomes the flower and flies off in complete transformation. Likewise, a simple jivatma, once mal, vikshep, and aavaran are removed, begins to meditate upon the Supreme - and becomes the Supreme. And understand- Atma-jnana and Tattva-jnana are two distinct things. After self-realization (atma-jnana), comes realization of the essence of all (tattva-jnana) 'adhyātma-jñāna-nityatvaṁ tattva-jñānārtha-darśhanam'- Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 13 Just intellectually understanding “I am the soul”, that is one thing. But to experience “I alone pervade the entire universe” - that is something else entirely. There are two types of realized beings in this world. 99.99% are those who have experienced the Self, and even that is very rare 0.01% are those who have completely known that \"I am not the body; I am the soul\", at an intellectual level, are atma-jnanis. But a tattva-jnani is one who not only realizes the Self, but also experiences that this very Self pervades all creation, and \"I am that\", everywhere, beyond time, space, and causation, their consciousness expands across the universe. That is the 'tattva jnana', the complete knowledge - Purna Jnana Saints like Jnaneshwar Maharaj, Sai Baba, Akkalkot Maharaj - are tattva-jnanis. And in the Sai Satcharita, it is said: Sai Baba is an avatar of tattva-jnana. Which means if Baba sees that spark in someone, If he sees that honestly, sincerity, then Baba says, “I can take you to the very end of the Ultimate Truth.” If this is Baba’s promise, then it proves that avatars are not exclusively God descending again and again. Rather, a jivatma, through the power of their integrity, attains completion and that very jivatma one day returns to this world as an avatar. If this is not the case then the word “Advaita” should never have existed in the scriptures Our problem is that, We are small-hearted people and so, we’ve made even God seem small-hearted. Really, we do not understand His vastness, the magnanimity of His heart. What He wants to give us, Their heart is so vast, our minds cannot comprehend it. So, look a person who had started his journey with simple devotion. Now, through true meditation, has reached the knowledge of the essence And after attaining tattva-jnana, if his heart held the resolve- That the knowledge I received from my Master made me capable of reaching this completeness. Similarly, I want to bestow this knowledge upon others. If such a resolve arises, and they choose to return, then that same person comes back as an Avatar. Because the grace his Guru bestowed upon him, dwells in every vein of his body \"I was once just an ordinary devotee,\" \"but carved, refined and shaped was transformed into an embodiment of the Supreme.\" \"Similarly, unless I bring a few others to that same Supreme state, my own realization feels incomplete.\" If such a vow arises within him and he choose to return That same soul takes birth again as an Avatar. So this idea that the same comes, the same goes No. That’s wrong. But God cannot be so small, And if He is that limited - then He’s not God. So, this is Advaita. Even after gathering such immense knowledge When that soul returns, it will come as a fakir, like Baba. He will come as an embodiment of devotion. Because, all the divine knowledge is within But, He will appear to the world only as devotion incarnate To uplift you all. To transform ordinary seekers into realized beings To make them an Avatari. So, the journey begins with devotion and ends in devotion. Take Sai Baba, Akkalkot Maharaj, or Gajanan Maharaj - They are Avatars of devotion. And yet, they are overflowing with Karma Yoga overflowing with Bhakti Yoga, overflowing with Jnana Yoga, and overflowing with Raja Yoga. Still, they arrive as simple devotees, Do their divine work, and depart from the world. In truth, they are complete Avatars. Because, they are Poorna Avatar. In Chapter 20 of Sai Satcharitra, there is Verse, 'Purnabrahmaswaroopchut, aisa ha jivatama purvavat,' Listen carefully 'Purnabrahmaswaroopchut, aisa ha jivatama purvavat,' 'Kadhitari swaswarupaprat, pavava nishchit he dhyeya.' What does this verse mean? That the soul descended from the Supreme Brahman And the goal is not just to become a soul with knowledge But to return to the state of Complete Brahman (tattva-jnani). Baba has the capacity to give that The real question is - do we have the capacity to receive it? 'Purnabrahmaswaroopchut, aisa ha jivatama purvavat,' 'Kadhitari swaswarupaprat, pavava nishchit he dhyeya.' And that is the aim of life, of the soul. To return to the same Supreme Brahman from which it once descended. That is the only true objective of existence, or else this life is meaningless. If we consider this verse, Then truly, who becomes an Avatar? You think on that And if this isn't the truth, then discard the word 'Advaita' from the scriptures. Because otherwise, it becomes a dictatorship of the Divine \"I myself will send Maya, the Maya creates chaos and unrighteousness, then I'll come, fix it all and depart again.\" Is this a game? Why such drama? God cannot be so petty. He cannot be so shallow. His heart is vast. But we have made Him petty. Because of our limited vision - our narrow view. Today, in just these 20 minutes, we’ve seen the entire journey of spirituality It begins with simple devotion moves to knowledge of the essence. and then returns as an ordinary devotee So, the journey begins with devotion and ends in devotion. If you understand this topic deeply, we will understand the Avatar of Sai Baba, we will understand the purpose of Akkalkot Maharaj’s Avatar, And that of Gajanan Maharaj. But what do we do? We lack clarity. So we cling to famous personalities from each 'branch'. Sudarshan Kriya, that kriya, this kriya - what is all this? We hang on to one branch and stick to it, But Vedanta speaks of roots! We must walk the path of roots. But our problem is, we don’t have the patience To do Nishkama Karma Yoga, Or practice the Nine-fold devotion So, we seek shortcuts. But our mindset is even more flawed. We want to do minimal spiritual effort, yet receive the same result others get from intense striving! It doesn't work like that. Only the one who labors deeply and sincerely, will reach that divine state. Sometimes people stumble due to lack of clarity But once they gain it, they awaken They have that spark. There are many people sitting here - I don’t know in whose heart Baba might ignite that fire today. If even one person’s heart is lit - Then this talk is a success And if not today, then maybe tomorrow, If someone hears this on YouTube and says \"Oh my God—this is how an Avatar descends!\" Yes, this is how it happens A soul becomes the Supreme And then returns as an Avatar Only that is true divinity His heart is truly vast, And if not, then I do not accept him as a God. This is how it goes: The journey begins with simple devotion But, then gradually..... it keeps increasing and one walks into Nishkama Karma Yoga then into Upasana (worship) the veils begin to fall and at some point, they become worthy of meditating upon the Supreme Brahman. Even becoming eligible to meditate on Him is no small feat But that requires every impurity, Mal, Vikshep - to fall Only then does the form of Brahman appear within Only then does true meditation begin. And meditation is not something you do. It happens. It’s not an act - it’s spontaneous. But, atleast you must have the clarity, that even if someone gives us a method Then it is just a practice which we are doing. But, only with purity of mind, can real meditation arise That much clarity is essential. For that, a person needs to be inclined towards his basics. It is like, we are not able to detach from the five sensory pleasures, then how will we meditate? Until these cravings for the five senses drop, Meditation will never happen. It’s impossible. Again, if the iron is covered with mud, still wants to stick to the magnet. It won't stick. You must scrape off the layers of dirt first. Now look, even if we try to stick an iron covered in mud with a magnet. Still it remains detached, because the mud is in between. So, our meditation is like that. But if we fall into the hands of a true Guru and he begins the cleansing - Then, no need to keep the iron piece close to the magnet, even from a distance it goes and sticks. Meditation begins. Then, true meditation begins. Otherwise, we are just deceiving ourselves. And time will pass. 'Vishayi jayasi havyas' Shri Sai Satcharitra Chapter 24 'Vishayi jayasi havyas, Parmarth na dhari tayachi aas' What a beautiful verse! 'Tayavari jo ghalil kaas, Tayacha das parmarth' It is said, 'Tayacha das parmarth' What a word! If our minds are full of thoughts, all the time. \"What to eat, what to wear, how to look, what to do,..\" If you are trapped in all this show and pretence, then where is the space for meditation? And our tendency is, we don’t want to reduce our indulgence at all. Instead, we want more pleasure - day by day. And still expect to meditate! It is impossible. It’s like boarding a train to Kolkata But expecting to arrive in Kashmir. You have boarded a train to Kolkata, But, you want to reach Kashmir. How is that possible? You want to keep indulging endlessly You want to enjoy it completely, and at the same time expect deep meditation. It won’t happen. Or it’ll take lifetimes And even then, in one lifetime, the Master Himself may have to come and correct him forcefully, saying, “Let go of these worldly indulgences.” The poor soul has done so much meditation that now the Master feels, “I must straighten him out, even if it takes some blows,” because the effort hasn’t gone unnoticed - the Master has seen it. Still, when done with clarity and understanding, it is more better. If our spiritual practice is rightly directed, Nothing can stop us from attaining completeness. But if we lack clarity and do it halfway, It’ll be difficult. That’s why today’s topic was: 'Begins with Devotion, Ends in Devotion.' It means, even a perfect Guru like Baba, Knower of all Yogas Still appears to the world as a simple Fakir. like this. And this entire journey is Vedanta. It moves through Mal, Vikshep, and Aavaran. It sheds every flaw. And attains completeness. Then that very soul returns as an Avatar to the world. This is how Avatars come. Sometimes, look - Within a 25-year span, Swami Samarth, Sai Baba, and Shegaon Bhajan Maharaj all arrived together. All were complete manifestations. But after there Era, it’s been over a hundred years. Not even one has come. If it were God’s direct intervention, He’d have sent someone every 50 years. No, it is not like that. So, even th Divine will wait now for a soul to reach the level, to return as an Avatar. Or else, He would have come at definite intervals, every 50 years But has this ever happened. Back then, perhaps 3 or 4 Avatars came together, or else not a single one. What does this mean? That not a single individual soul reached that position to return as an Avatar. How clear is that? Back then, perhaps 3 or 4 reached it together, And so they all descended at once. In the verse, “Yada yada hi dharmasya glanir bhavati bharata…” God says - “O individual soul, attain that state of absolute completeness and you yourself shall reign.\" And this is a service, If you wish to serve others, then go forth. God’s heart is surely vast enough for that. I hope the concept of 'Avatar' is now clear. O Mind-Enchanting One, Remover of Curses and Suffering, Destroyer of Ignorance, Bestower of Liberation, The Supreme Giver of Auspiciousness, Embodiment of Truth, Consciousness, and Bliss, the Sacred Mother of countless embodiments of Sai. the True Form of Sai Himself Victory to the Divine Scripture: Shri Sai Satcharita.",
