But Baba wouldn't even touch that food, and he would wait, saying that Lakshmibai's bhakri (bread) hasn't arrived yet. So, it's the story of a devotee. Baba felt that it was time for Him to leave this body, to conclude this incarnation. So, as he was departing, he decided to give some alms. He gave nine coins. Even today, if we go to the house of Lakshmibai Shinde in Shirdi, we get to see those nine coins, we get to have their sight. When Baba was sitting on the stone in Dwarkamai, facing Laxmibai Shinde, and while giving the nine rupees, first five fell from Baba’s hand, and then four, making it a total of nine rupees. So, it's mentioned in the scriptures that those nine rupees were a symbol of Navavidha Bhakti (nine types of devotion). Now, we all know that Baba bestowed Navavidha Bhakti upon Laxmibai because she had rendered such great service, in the form of meals. See, Baba doesn't need to eat. A person who is enlightened, who has transcended the five elements, doesn't even have a body. So, for such a person, there's no need for food. If he wanted, he could have lived his entire life without food and water and still fulfilled his purpose. But Baba gave a devotee the opportunity to serve. It was a favor to Laxmibai Shinde that Baba waited for food until she arrived. So, for an enlightened being, there's no need for food; the soul doesn't need food; there's no body, so why would He eat? Baba still gave Laxmibai an opportunity to serve, so that she could always prepare meals for him and He could accept them, bringing benefit to her. And what is that benefit? Those nine rupees. So, the most precious thing in life, if anything, is devotion to God, devotion to Baba. And Baba bestowed upon Laxmibai Shinde such a valuable thing as Navavidha Bhakti. Now, we all know that those nine coins symbolize Navavidha Bhakti, but there's another point mentioned in the scripture. Perhaps, I feel, this might not be mentioned in the smaller Hindi texts. I can't cover the entirety of Navavidha Bhakti in one talk; each type of devotion would require its own session. What is Shravan Bhakti (devotion through listening), for example, would take up one whole session. So, I'll cover that later, but for now, let's focus on another aspect: the nine rupees that Baba gave to Laxmibai Shinde, first five and then four. The method of giving first five and then four, not giving all nine rupees at once, is mentioned here. Baba initially placed five rupees in her hand and then four rupees slipped from his hand and into Laxmibai's hand. So, what does it symbolize? In the Eknathi Bhagwat, when Eknath Maharaj describes the characteristics of a true disciple he mentions that there should be nine qualities in the disciple for them to be considered a true disciple of the guru. Only then can they be called a true disciple. So, those nine qualities are described, first five qualities are mentioned and then four more. It means, when describing the qualities of the nine divine virtues that a disciple should possess, the mention of the first five qualities comes first, followed by the mention of the remaining four qualities So, it's clarified in Chapter 42 of the Sai Satcharitra that Baba gave the first five rupees in the same proportion, followed by the remaining four rupees. Look in a literal way even when we go to receive their darshan, it’s a mere symbol. But let’s say, that those coins actually come into your hands one day. Then I'll ask you a question: so what? What does that achieve? Because the true value lies in what the scriptures say. If those coins fall into your hands and you don't possess the light of Navavidha Bhakti, if the nine divine virtues that Baba talks about don't manifest within you, then despite those coins being in your hands, there is no one in this world more impoverished, more beggarly than you. So, if they belong to someone's family, don't assume that they've achieved something grand or attained a high status. Please understand, I'm not against any particular family. I just needed to clarify certain things about where we are stucked. So, you see the coins, you take their darshan, you take a photo, and then what? What does it really accomplish? But what Baba is speaking from His heart about those nine divine virtues, that is the essence of those nine rupees. If this isn't understood, then even if you get those nine coins they are of no value. Look, our problem is that we want to see everything in a materialistic way, but Baba wants to convey something else. That's why I repeatedly mention what Baba says in Chapter 32, that \"What do I want to give you and what are you asking from me? What am I saying and what are you thinking? What have I brought into this world and what are you seeking from me? I have come to distribute gems and pearls, and you stand before me to collect stones with outstretched hands, begging like a beggar. I don't like that.\" Baba has said this several times. Baba carried that agony in his heart throughout his life, that he couldn't find anyone worthy enough to take his treasures. \"I say, bring carts, dig and take away, but there is no one in this universe who is willing to work hard for knowledge. Everyone comes asking, 'Give me, give me.' What do you want? What am I talking about? What are you asking for?\" So, those nine rupees, you might have seen them many times, but now let's take a look at the darshan of those nine divine virtues that Baba is hinting at. What are those nine characteristics that Baba wants to convey? And these are very important qualities, and all nine flaws are present within us. First of all, let me clarify this, and that's why Baba is talking about those nine divine virtues. These are qualities that should be within a disciple. First and foremost, ‘Amaani’, the first divine virtue, means humility. There should be no desire for respect and honor, not even in dreams, ‘Amaani’. If there is even a slight thought in your mind or heart, \"When I go there, people will look at me with great respect, they will respect me, I will be greatly respected when I go, someone will open the car door for me, someone will spread a carpet for me,\" if there are such petty thoughts, then we cannot be Baba's devotees. So, the first divine virtue is humility, Do not desire respect and honour, because the desire for respect always leads to disrespect; it will come eventually. When you receive respect and enjoy it, flaunt it, revel in it. \"This is rubbish\", If your heart responds like this to respect, then disrespect won't hurt you, won't cause you pain, because you rejected respect from the start, so any disrespect won't affect you either, So, the seed of disrespect lies within respect. So, if you want to avoid disgrace, avoid respect. So, the first divine virtue is humility, and Baba says, if you bring this quality within you, I will be satisfied, I will be contented. so, this is my food that you can change yourself. This is the purpose of my life. So, the first divine virtue Baba wants to see in a disciple is humility, modesty. There should be no desire of respect and honor but if you crave for respect or on getting it you felt good Feeling good means it's a signal when disrespected you will end yourself attempting suicide therefore if someone is flattering you then you should address it as rubbish and should remain unaffected by it If you have respect disrespect won't hurt you, won't cause you pain, because you rejected respect from the start, so any disrespect won't affect you either, it's a simple thing. But if you receive respect and enjoy it, then when you face disrespect, your heart will ache. So, the seed of disrespect lies within respect. The second quality is ‘Daksh., which means being ever alert, absolutely vigilant, no room for laziness, ever alert 24/7. Knowing what needs to be done, how it needs to be done, always lively, knowing whom to give top priority to. There are three tasks, and only one can be done because you don’t have much time, so you have to choose every moment, if this work is the most important, then I'll finish it first. If you don't have the quality of giving priority, then you don't have efficiency in your life because time is the same for everyone; everyone has 24 hours, did anyone get 36 hours from God? So, time cannot be extended, nor can it be reduced, but we can change what we choose, \"No, this work is more important for me at this time, so I'll finish this first,\" that's Daksh, alertness. It means having such clarity that you know which decision to make at which time, which will be beneficial for you. So, that ever alertness, that efficiency is the second quality. First was Amaani, and the second is Daksh. And the third quality is ‘Nirmatsar’, which means being free from envy or jealousy. Even if you have to die for it, never harbor hatred or envy towards anyone, never make anyone your enemy, because if you hold resentment towards someone in your mind, before harming them, it harms us. Never hold enmity, never foster animosity towards anyone, and on the contrary, if you realize that someone harbors ill feelings towards you, then as soon as possible, surrender to them and clear the air. Don't harbor hatred towards others, and if you realize that someone harbors animosity towards you, then even if you have to surrender them, surrender, but remove that animosity from their heart. Baba is talking about the third quality, ‘Nirmatsar’. The third coin that Baba expects from us. The whole world thinks that Baba has given us nine coins, but if we look deeply, Baba is actually saying that this third quality is what I want to see in you. I want to see humility in you, I want to see alertness in you, and I want to see you free from envy and jealousy. Don't allow negative emotions to enter your life. Never let the feeling of envy enter your life, no matter who the person is, no matter how wrong they have done to you. Yes, you can distance yourself from someone with love, but you cannot harbor hatred or envy towards them. That was the third quality. First was humility, alertness, and third is freedom from envy and jealousy. The fourth quality is being ‘Nirmam’, which means being free from attachment. A disciple should be free from attachment, detached from all forms of desires, whether it's for home, jewellery, cars, office, millions of rupees, or family. If the master has bestowed you with all these things because of your Karmas, if you have a big factory, luxurious cars, high status, immense wealth, or a large family, then live among everyone, give love to everyone, respect everyone, and provide comfort to everyone, but don't expect anything in return from others, from your family. That's what being ‘Nirmam’ is all about. The power to cut off attachments. What people think, that cutting off attachments means leaving your home, it is a very third-rate mentality. It doesn't mean leaving your home, abandoning millions of wealth; it means even while having all these things, you are untouched by them, your mind doesn't dwell on them, you completely know that they are impermanent, one day either I'll leave them or they'll leave me. This clarity is completely ingrained in that person, that's why they are nirmam. Nirmam means someone in whose life there is no attachment left, not to children, not to mother, not to father, not to spouse, not even to one's own body. But they live among everyone, fulfill their responsibilities, provide the best education to their children, make them responsible citizens, but even while doing all this, they remain detached, not attached to them. That's what being nirmam is all about. The fifth quality is ‘Gurusevapar’, which means living life solely for serving the guru. This life is solely for serving my guru, and my guru has complete authority over it. Whatever he says, I just have to follow that, that's the true service, knowing the guru's will, living accordingly, that's Gurusevapar. Gurusevapar doesn't mean bowing down and groveling at someone's feet. That's very easy to do, people mistake flattery for service. Now, if there are ten disciples, the one who flatters the most is considered the greatest disciple of all, no. Baba is not talking about such a person, he's a fake guru and a fake disciple. If a person doesn't have the capability to make out whether the disciple is worthy or not, then how can he be a Guru? If someone is just flattering, then they are considered good, but if they don't flatter, then they are worthless. The relationship between a guru and disciple nowadays is like this. In a true guru-disciple relationship, the guru doesn't even need to say anything with their mouth; the disciple understands and starts doing the work accordingly. That's true service, that's real service, where there's no need to speak with words. Nowadays, in the Samadhi Mandir, it's like, \"decorate it like this, decorate it like that, spend lakhs of rupees for festivals, adorn Baba with gold, adorn Baba with a diamond crown.\" Is this what service is, is this what Baba wants? Just once, try to see from Baba's perspective, just once ask Baba, \"Do you really want a crown of gold?\" He'll pick it up and throw it away, saying, Baba came as an ascetic and came to give asceticism, but we’ve turned him into a wealthy person, no one can be more despicable than us. He came as ascetic, he wanted to give asceticism, but we turned him into god of wealth. Alright, those who have given it must have had good intentions, because giving is also a big thing. There's another aspect to it as well, I don't deny that, but I'm speaking from Baba's perspective, that Baba should be asked once what he truly wants, whether he really wants that thing. Only one thing he will say, आपून नही रे बापू किस मे These are his words from the 25th chapter. In all these matters, I won't be trapped, you'll be. You can't trap me. For you, it will be a crown of diamonds, for you, it will be a golden throne. For me, there is nothing more precious than heaps of soil. This will be the answer. To elaborate this topic Among the beloved devotees of Baba, there was rao bahadur sathe ce a Brahmin named Megha, hailing from a family in Gujarat. Megha, with a heart so pure, approached him seeking employment and serving him. Witnessing the divine qualities in Raav Bahadur Saathe, and perceiving his righteousness, Megha regarded him as a guru in his heart. He considered Raav Bahadur Saathe equivalent to a guru and served him with complete honesty. Now look at raav bahadur sathe's purity of mind. it appears to him as if megha is a genuine diamond, fearing he(megha) might wander. He wonders what he could offer in return. He sees himself as a flickering lamp, while there sits a saint in Shirdi, shining like the sun. Why not send him to his doorstep? Says to Megha, \"Megha, since you possess such a pure heart, listen to me. you consider him whom I regard as gurus, then go directly to their refuge. You will find such people now. Go and search for them! What characters they were, what people they were, truly remarkable individual's. The man knows that he completely regards me as his guru, and he is fully devoted to me, completely. He is merely bowing in front of an ordinary lamp. I want him to bow in front of the sun. uch purity, such truthfulness, is impossible to find in today's age. And this applies to me as well. Doesn't waste his/hers words even for a moment, doesn't speak without reason, doesn't engage in gossip, doesn't spend my time praising myself, doesn't waste time in talking unnecessarily, doesn't indulge in gossiping about people or talking about other's affairs Someone who always refrains from unnecessary chatter always seems to speak with great value, as if every word that comes out of their mouth costs a million. They carefully choose their words, while speaking , never wasting their words needlessly. The one who speaks the truth and speaks for the benefit of others. Where to speak and where to stay silent, Such a person rarely faces deception in life. Always remember one thing in life, speak only where there is respect for words, otherwise silently leave from there and move on. Quietly put your words in your bag and move on, because there is not a single person there who appreciates your diamonds, who understands your heart, or who understands your words. आत्मा को भक्ति के परम सत्य तक पहुँचा देती है।\n\n🌾 क्या बाबा उस रोटी को ग्रहण कर रहे थे — या उस रोटी में छिपे भाव, त्याग और समर्पण को?\n🌺 क्या लक्ष्मीबाई की सेवा साईं बाबा को किसी दिव्य स्तर पर छू जाती थी?\n🕉️ और क्या उसी के माध्यम से बाबा ने भक्ति के नौ मार्गों की ओर संकेत किया — जो आत्मा को मोक्ष की ओर ले जाते हैं?\n\nइस अध्याय में सूखी रोटी, खीर, दूध, चीनी और अंततः अग्नि — ये सब केवल भोजन के प्रतीक नहीं हैं, बल्कि गहरे आत्मिक संकेत हैं।\n\n✨ साईं बाबा किसी वस्तु को उसके रूप में नहीं, बल्कि उसमें छुपे गुण, भावना और चेतना को स्वीकार करते हैं।\n\nयह वीडियो एक ऐसी सूक्ष्म आध्यात्मिक यात्रा को सामने लाता है, जहाँ बाबा एक सरल घटना में आत्मा की तमोगुण से सत्त्वगुण तक की यात्रा को प्रकट करते हैं।\nक्या यह केवल भोजन की लीला है — या आत्मा के परिष्कार की एक अद्भुत प्रक्रिया?\n\n🌸 बाबा द्वारा लक्ष्मीबाई को दिया गया विशेष प्रेम, क्या यह संकेत नहीं कि जब समर्पण पूर्ण हो, तो स्वयं साईं उस भक्ति का उत्तर बन जाते हैं?\n\n🙏 यह वीडियो उन साधकों के लिए है, जो साईं बाबा की लीलाओं को केवल घटनाएँ     "Transcript": "Let us take up today's topic stories of two devotees One is a devotee attracted to miracles, and the other is drawn purely to devotion. Both stories are found in Chapter 49 of the Sai Satcharita. One is the story of Hari Kanhoba and the other of Kaka Saheb Dixit. One of them is Hari Kanoba, a man fascinated by miracles Having heard from many that Baba performs incredible wonders in Shirdi, he wonders- \"Are these miracles truly real?\" Motivated by this curiosity, he decides to visit Shirdi In contrast stands Kaka Saheb Dixit- a devotee who seeks nothing but pure devotion. This is Chapter 49, which highlights the contrast between these two Now, let us reflect on Hari Kanoba’s story \"Do miracles really happen in Shirdi? Does Sai Baba truly perform miracles?\" This intense curiosity begins to grow deeply in his mind, and one day, with this curiosity he comes to Shirdi. \"Let’s see - do miracles really happen?\" Baba also senses that this man has come just to see a miracle. So, He thinks, “Why not show him one?” Wearing a golden-threaded turban, dressed in fine clothes and a pair of expensive shoes, he arrives in Shirdi You see, when life flows smoothly, that's when the mind begins to indulge in such thoughts \"Let me go see if miracles really happen.\" But when life throws difficulties our way, our mind doesn’t have the luxury to chase such whims. In times of trouble, the only thought is - \"How do I get out of this?\" When the Master keeps someone well - surrounded by comfort and ease - such thoughts begin to trouble the person. They start wondering, “Do miracles really happen?” Hari Kanhoba had everything - wealth, status, luxury. So this playful curiosity bloomed: “Let’s go to Shirdi and see some miracles.\" Even Baba says, “You have no trouble in your life, and that’s why you want to see miracles. So, let Me put you in a little difficulty for a while.” Now look - people think that in this story, Baba showed a miracle. No Baba didn’t show Hari Kanhoba any miracle. But what Baba did was, placed him in a little sorrow and discomfort, for a while. The slippers/shoes he was so deeply attached to - Baba took them away from him. His slippers were stolen. And yes, it is Baba who steals them. I’ll say it just like that because Baba has to show him a miracle now. He took away his precious slippers Even when he removes his slippers, he’s so careful looking for a corner where no one’s eyes will reach, a spot where his slippers will remain safe. But Baba’s eyes do reach there, don't they? Baba’s gaze reaches places no human eye can. But he forgot that the greatest ‘thief’ of all is Baba Himself who once stole butter as Krishna and now chooses to steal illusions as Sai. So, Baba \"steals\" those beloved slippers After having darshan, eating prasad, and observing the crowd bowing down in devotion - he starts thinking, “Maybe miracles do happen here.” But I didn’t experience it. Thinking so, he goes to the spot where he left his slippers to put them back on - he sees, they’re gone. Now, even though he is physically present in Shirdi, his mind is completely elsewhere. Even while having darshan, his thoughts are swirling around the missing slippers. He’s invited to partake in the meal. But even while eating, his mind is towards the slippers “The slippers… they’re gone! Such expensive slippers! Such fine craftsmanship!” and so on. So to bring some clarity, let’s refer to a verse about Hari Kanhoba - Chapter 49, verse 69. 'Jauniya santanchya dara, Pahu aadarile chamatkara, tav jod padatranacha kora, aala ki ghara gharpoch.' And what was Baba doing? Now Baba performs a miracle. He tells a young boy, “Here, take this stick, tie both slippers to it, and walk right between the rows where people are sitting down for their meal. Keep chanting a slogan: ‘Hari ka beta, Jari ka pheta…’ And if someone says, ‘My name is Hari, and those slippers are mine,’ then return them to him.\" So the boy walks around, chanting again and again: ‘Hari ka beta, Jari ka pheta… ' And when Hari sees this, he is stunned “My God! These slippers of mine… they’ve walked all the way to the very place where I’m sitting This is the miracle I had left them in some corner, now they have reached the place where I'm having my meal brought by a child, Baba is saying, ‘Jod padatranacha kora, aala ki ghara gharpoch.’ walked all the way to the place where he was sitting ‘Natari shullak paytan, gelyane kaay mothi nagavan, Pari tadarth manachi vanvan, te sapadlyavin rahina.’ Was it really necessary to create such a scene over a pair of simple slippers? It’s just footwear - if lost, let it go. But no, his entire attention was stuck to those slippers. So, Baba returned them - He did this miracle, making a point. This Leela teaches us something powerful: A person’s mind clings to such petty things only when they are surrounded by comfort and luxury If you place a person in hardship or discomfort, their thoughts no longer run in such directions. Their entire focus shifts to, “Lord, how do I get through this suffering?” It’s like when a speck of dust enters the eye Until it’s removed, you can’t focus on anything else In the same way, when God places a few problems in life, The mind begins to focus, Remembrance deepens, and contemplation begins. But when life is too comfortable, We tend to forget. “Dukh mein sumiran sab kare, sukh mein kare na koye, jo sukh mein sumiran kare, dukh kahe ko hoye.” -Kabir Ji When in sorrow, everyone remembers the Lord. What if they do the same, when in joy? In joy, no one does But if one remembers the Lord even in joy, What sorrow could ever come their way? Kabir ji is clear - Remembering God in sorrow is easy But remembering Him in comfort - that is rare. Even that comfort starts to feel insignificant., and your heart stays connected to the Divine, Then know - you are under His special grace. And there’s one more verse worth reflecting on - Verse 76. Now Baba is speaking to all of us through this… ‘Vishaybhogarth aharnishi, amhi jamlo saipashi, Just like that man was desperate for his slippers, in the same way, we all are desperate for sensory pleasures. ‘Vishaybhogarth aharnishi, amhi jamlo saipashi, Ya amhate dengihi taisi, parmarthiyasi parmarth.’ And for us, Baba then shows such miracles - if someone came just to see a miracle, He showed them exactly that. Our intention in coming to Baba is often to fulfil our desires for sound, touch, form, taste, and smell - the five sense pleasures. So, Baba gives to us just the way we desire for \"Enjoy all five senses, exhaust your life in pleasures, and one day, leave this world empty-handed.” So, as we are gathered to enjoy the sensory pleasures, Then Baba says, that, \"I will give you these worldly pleasures\" Look, when the slippers were stolen, and later returned - the man felt it was a huge miracle. But through this small Leela, Baba is revealing a much deeper truth. What do slippers really symbolize? What is the significance of stealing the slippers? Comforts were taken away, the man was pushed in discomfort The slippers represent comforts. Why do we leave slippers/shoes outside the temple? It’s a message from God: “If you wish to enter into devotion, leave your comforts behind. You cannot carry worldly comforts into devotion and expect your mind to be still.” Only when you leave those behind at the door, can you truly step inside and connect with Me. Just like they say - Two swords cannot stay in one sheath. In the same way, You cannot have both indulgence and inner discipline (Yoga) together. If you seek spiritual growth, you must drop indulgence And if you want indulgence, forget spiritual growth They don't go hand-in-hand You have to sacrifice one of them If you want seek spiritual growth, you must drop indulgence. And if you want indulgence, forget spiritual growth Baba says: “If you truly want My Darshan, you must be ready to sacrifice your comforts You must be strong enough to let go of them.” Only then will you be able to reach me. You cannot reach Me while holding tightly to worldly pleasures. Even in this small story, a profound truth is hidden. ‘Jaha ram waha nahi kaam, ‘Jaha ram waha nahi kaam, jaha kaam waha nahi ram, Tulsi kabhu hot nahi, ravi rajni ek thaam.’ Just as night and day cannot exist together, Similarly, God and indulgence cannot stay in the same heart. ‘Rahiman uljhan aan padi, tedhe dou kaam, Seedhese jag na mile, tedhe mile na ram.’ The mind is torn between two paths If you walk the straight path, you lose worldly pleasures, But you gain Ram If you walk the crooked path, you may gain pleasures, but lose God You must choose one - Either indulge in luxury and desires, or seek God. ‘Rahiman uljhan aan padi, tedhe dou kaam, Seedhese jag na mile, tedhe mile na ram.’ Either you gain the world, or God. You cannot have both. This leela, ‘Hari ka beta, Jari ka pheta’, also holds this deep lesson. He came seeking a miracle - so Baba gave him a miracle. But in this same chapter, there is another Leela - That of Kaka Saheb Dixit. A deep longing awakens in his heart “I must go to Shirdi and have Baba’s Darshan!” An intense longing arose within him… One day, due to some election work, Kaka Saheb Dixit came to Ahmednagar. And once he reached Ahmednagar, he thought, “Shirdi is nearby, let me go and have Baba's darshan.” It was his first darshan of Baba, and the longing was powerful. This deep desire had been stirred by none other than his close friend, Nana Saheb Chandorkar, who had repeatedly told him about Baba. He had planted that seed of devotion: “Please, at least once, take darshan of our Guru. Even the limp in your leg… If Baba wills, it will be healed.” To this, Kaka Saheb replied, “No, that’s not necessary. This entire body is already crippled— Though I may appear physically whole, the real disability is within - my mind is filled with impurities. If your Guru truly has power, then I will ask Him to heal the lameness of my mind. Let my body’s lameness remain.” With such pure intention, he sets out for Baba’s darshan Now look… on one side we saw Hari Kanhoba—longing for miracles. On the other side, here is Kaka Saheb Dixit whose only wish is for the purification of his inner being. He tells Baba: “I have no other request but this.” Now ask yourself - what should our prayer be? Should we be like Hari Kanhoba - craving miracle after miracle, always seeking wonders? Just look around… Today, on social media, every person has a channel, and what are they all doing? Miracle… miracle… miracle… And both the speaker and the listener, I must say, are part of Hari Kanhoba's camp. Only miracles…miracles But in this very same chapter, we’re told about the example of Kaka Saheb Dixit. As he reached Ahmednagar, for the election work he stayed for some time, and coincidentally, there was a horse fair in the town - if someone has to buy one Kaka Saheb Mirikar and few more people, met him there, who had come to see the horses And then, he met Madhavrao Deshpande - Shyama Who had come to Ahmednagar to visit his ailing father-in-law. And thus, the meeting happened Baba’s closest devotee Shyama - of whom it is said: 'Aadhi na gheta Nandi che darshan, Shankar hoil kaay prasanna' If Baba is Shankar, Shyama is Nandi You cannot reach Shankar without Nandi’s Darshan So, such a person- Shyama came to Ahmednagar… Now see what the story is saying, When there is a true, pure longing in your heart, with which you leave to seek Baba's Darshan, like Kaka Saheb Dixit had Baba says, “You don’t even need to reach Shirdi I Myself will come to you on the way.” In the form of Shyama, in the form of a photo, a picture arrives there which had come for some restoration work. So, the repaired photo was kept there, covered for a long time And right in front of Kaka Saheb Dixit, Baba’s photo is revealed. Tears begin to stream from his eyes… This Leela tells us: If your longing is pure, if you truly want the inner crippled-ness to be healed then you don’t need to walk to Baba. He will walk to you. Provided, your intentions are pure. So, Baba himself walked from Shirdi to Ahmednagar What is this Leela telling us? People often ask: “But now Baba is no longer in the body… What do we do?” If your intention is like Kaka Saheb Dixit, You don’t need His physical body No need. But, your inner purity, devotion, and worthiness should be of that high level then you can connect with Baba directly. You don’t need a physical Guru. Now look, the kind of inner disability Kaka Saheb Dixit was going through Kabir Ji has a couplet for it: ‘Dil ka marham na mila, ‘Dil ka marham na mila, jo mila so garji’ In this world, most people who turn to Baba’s devotion do so for their own desires. But the one who truly says, \"My mind is filled with filth, lust, vices, and ignorance - Baba, please remove it from me,\"- that person rarely comes to Shirdi. Even Baba used to say, \"My treasure is overflowing - take as much as you want!\" But not a single person comes for it. Kabir also says the same, ‘Dil ka marham na mila, jo mila so garji, Kahe Kabir aasman phata, kaha tak sive darji’ So, this selfish kind of devotion - again and again, again and again eventually breaks open the sky of ignorance. And then even the Sadguru needs time to repair it. Look at the contrast between Kaka Saheb Dixit and the “Hari ka beta, Zari ka pheta” devotee. One came to Shirdi just to see a miracle, The other came to cleanse the impurities of his own mind. Baba says - \"Those who come with such pure intention don’t even need to come all the way to Shirdi. I Myself will come to them.\" Truly, devotees like Kaka Saheb Dixit are rare perhaps countable on fingers Where Baba rushes to meet His devotee In the form of an image, a person, or in some other. Now the choice is yours Do you want to become like Kaka Saheb Dixit and draw Baba toward you, Or be like Hari Kanhoba, running after miracles all your life and die stuck in that cycle? That is your decision. If you found today’s topic meaningful, Then please - for life remember this one character: Kaka Saheb Dixit. 'Rahude payacha langdepana' 'Nahi maj tyachi vivanchana' \"I don’t care if my leg limps If your Guru is truly powerful, then ask Him to remove the lameness of my mind.\" If we too can say this Then, we don’t need to reach Baba. Baba Himself will come and reside in our hearts, And starts working on us from within. And I say this from personal experience So, instead of Hari Kanhoba, Become like Kaka Saheb Dixit. So there's no benefit because the thirst is quenched with the water inside the pot. But it will surprise you to know that we all want to quench our thirst from the pot, not from the water. You will be greatly surprised to know that we are all those crazy ones who, in the pursuit of quenching their thirst from the clay pot, are taking birth and dying in every life, taking birth again, dying again, but still engaged in the same task - trying to quench their thirst from the clay pot. Does the clay pot ever quench the thirst? No, this world, the impermanence of this world, the pleasures of this world, the joys of this world, the enjoyments of this world, they are all like the clay pot. And we want to quench our thirst from the clay pot, but the thirst doesn't quench; it flares up the thirst. Such is the clay pot. So how can the clay pot quench the thirst? Thirst is quenched by water. None of the joys of this world can quench your thirst; they will only inflame it. If you receive a salary of ten thousand, you won't be happy; you'll want fifteen thousand. If the master gives you a girl in your lap, you won't be happy; you'll want a boy. So, this clay pot of the world, it inflames the thirst. Thirst is never quenched, it is inflamed, and we, no matter how many pleasures of this world we have, we want to be content with them, but we never will be. Complete peace, complete contentment, complete joy. Our hands will never touch it because we want to quench our thirst from the clay pot. We have no idea about the water inside the clay pot. Water is the soul, water is spirituality, water is the path to salvation. The water inside the clay pot is the path shown by the guru. That is water. If one drinks that water, then the thirst of many lifetimes will be quenched. But if one only tries to quench their thirst from the clay pot without touching the water, then one may have taken births, may have died many times, but that clay pot never quenched their thirst rather surged it. This world, home, household responsibilities, family, children, joys, festivities, weddings, all these things, no matter what significance they hold, are like clay pots. They are clay pots, and they do not quench the thirst; rather, they inflame it. No matter how many trivial desires of the world are fulfilled, the thirst is not quenched; instead, the thirst flares up. Today, there are so many of us sitting here. Who among us can raise their hand and say that my thirst has been quenched, that there is no lingering thirst in my heart, that there are no unfulfilled desires? If someone raises their hand, I will depart form this spiritual discourse. Raise one hand, for I have no remaining desires. We are all thirsty, and this thirst is not of today; we have carried this thirst through many lifetimes. and reason for this thirst is that we are trying to quench the thirst with clay pot, with household responsibilities, world, people they want to quench this thirst, but it doesn't quench; instead, it flares up and intensifies, leading to attachment. How to quench the clay pot's thirst? Thirst is quenched by water. If Sadguru, out of grace, gives you that water to drink, the water of devotion, the water of knowledge, if he were to give you the nectar to drink, then the thirst of many lifetimes would be quenched in a moment. Otherwise, this thirst does not quench. Do You remember that story of 48th chapter, Sapatnekar? In that chapter sapatnekar's wife sees vision that she goes to well to fill the water And the well's name is Lakkadsha. She goes there to fetch water. Then a fakir comes and says, \"Hey, why are you laboring in vain? Let me fill your pitcher with pure water.\" She runs away from there, afraid that why would this man fill water for her? Today's world is so dangerous that if you go selflessly to help someone, they become afraid, questioning your motives. They wonder, \"Why is this person helping me?\" What selfish interest could he have in it? He would run away. That was exactly what happened to Mrs Sapatnekar. She runs away, thinking, \"Why does this man want to fill my pitcher in the end?\" And Baba says, \"I fill your pitcher with pure water. You are drinking water from Lakkadsha, this world is Lakkadsha. Lakkadsha or Fakkadsha Give it whatever name you want. Those who are drinking water from the well of this world, they have been drinking from birth. They enjoy small pleasures, indulge in minor luxuries, but their thirst is never quenched. So, Baba says, how much longer will these people be ashamed of lifting water from the well, again and again? Come, once, come to my court. I have water with me. Drink it once and see, the thirst of countless lifetimes will be extinguished.\" In Chapter 48, there's this story of Mrs. Sapatnekar who goes to fetch water from the well named Lakkadsha. If I give you that water just once, the thirst of countless lifetimes will be quenched.\" So, here, it's about that water. How can the clay pot quench the thirst? It can only be quenched with water. The more external pleasures you renounce,if the will to eat, drink, roam, wander, and enjoy falls away, then the inner world will surely improve, only then the inner world will only improve. Both these things don't go hand in hand. Enjoying the pleasures of the world and the bliss of the soul. These two cannot be attained together. If one wants to enjoy the world, then the spiritual journey won't be possible. And if Baba is desired, then the indulgence of the world must be forsaken. That is true devotion.”\n\nA good thought is not just a fleeting idea; it is a divine spark that must manifest in action to bear fruit. Likewise, pausing for five minutes before committing a wrong action can awaken the conscience and change the course of life.\n\nThis Leela reminds us that God constantly blesses us with sacred thoughts, and acting upon them without delay is the path of a true seeker.\n\n#saileelarahasya #saisatcharitra #goodthoughts #gooddeeds #saiwisdom #spiritualpath #devotion #saiquotes #lifechanging …...more\n...more\nShow less",

Each verse illuminates the depths. Today, I will take this song in its entirety so that I can convey to you all what I want to say, what I want to give you all. It will be very clear, understandable. This song is being sung about Baba's deep layers, which we have not yet touched, where we have not yet reached. We, just by obtaining a drop of it, consider ourselves great. We have just touched a drop, and Baba is saying, the entire ocean is remaining to be known. The entire ocean, and what we have touched is just a drop. Now understanding the entire ocean remains, right now we've just touched a drop. So, Baba has placed me among you all to deliver this message, and if indeed you wish to understand the depth of the ocean, then one must dive into the heart and soul of Baba- Sai Satcharitra, the depth of each of its leelas, and to learn the lesson hidden within those leelas, to grasp his advice, must be imbibed within hearts, understand, and it's not just about understanding, but molding one's life according to it. Then the ocean Baba is talking about, that conquering the entire ocean is still pending. You, having merely attained a drop, sit feeling blessed, then the entire sea is yet to be conquered, the entire ocean is still pending. In reality, we don't even realize the essence of this, that we've only touched a drop, just a droplet, and it's from that droplet that we have become so intoxicated that we aren't even aware of the ocean. And everyone is admiring the drop. Feeling proud that I've found Baba. And Baba in return is saying, 'You've only touched a drop. You've touched a droplet, and you're feeling proud that you've known me, you've found me. But the entire ocean is still ahead.’ See, I always say one thing, my words might seem bitter to you, but it is reality, whether you like it or not, you will have to listen, but the one who is honest, who has the true devotion to Baba, will understand this depth, will increase the thirst to drink the ocean within themselves, and one day will drink the entire ocean. And the one who just by obtaining a drop, is satisfied then he has no connection with the ocean, then there's nothing to do with the ocean. Look, these are the lyrics of the song, 'Shirdi is within you, if you look inside your heart,' you repeatedly run towards Shirdi, the inclination you have towards Shirdi, see, I'm not against Shirdi, what is this song saying, please ponder a bit on it. Initially, as many times as possible, one should go to Shirdi, everyone should go. In the initial stage, for few years, as much time as you can give to Shirdi, you should give, and one should go with the feeling of devotion, not with the feeling of leisure, not with the desire to fulfill one's own selfish devotion, but with the feeling of knowing Baba's heart, one should go repeatedly. But if it's been 2-3 years, 4 years, now Baba says, 'Hey, stop, how many times will you come and look at these walls, look at my idol? I am the same. Everyone can see with physical eyes, but if you don't have the strength to explore my heart if you don't have the inclination to see the beats of my heart, if your curiosity to know me is not awakened, then you will never be able to know that ocean. You will consider the drop as the ocean, and one day you will depart from this world. Birth was precious, but will be exchanged for a mere penny. If you believe in birth, they say there are 84 lakhs species and humans are superior among all and if you could not attain my ocean, then I gave you a precious birth. You didn't have the curiosity to attain my ocean, nor did you have the thirst. Show me once the thirst to drink that ocean, if I don't enable you to absorb that ocean within you, then change my name. So, this is that song, 'Shirdi is within you, if you look inside your heart.' Why get stuck in such activities? Firstly, you commit a sin, and then you boast about it, saying that we directly go for darshan. My recognition is with this villager of Shirdi.” Baba says one thing in Sai Satcharitra, chapter 14, please listen carefully to this saying. “In this world, someone belongs to someone, but here, no one is truly mine; What does this signify? Baba is saying, \"I have discarded all the worldly titles and distinctions. This is my right hand, this is my left hand, my elder brother is there for me; whenever trouble comes, my elder brother will stand by me. This MLA is my identity, this MP is my identity, this politician is my identity.\" What is this? Is this the mark of a Sai devotee? Why do you need such people when Baba is alive? Baba says, \"I have no one in the world. There is only Allah here.\" We should also be able to say that there is only Sai, and no one except him. The day your surrenderance becomes so pure, on that day you'll be worthy of being called a Sai devotee. Right now, he knows me, she knows me. This is special to me, that is special to me. These are the descendants, these are Baba’s descendants, today we were sitting at their house. Whom do we call descendants? Today I will tell you the meaning of descendants. Please listen carefully. Once Jesus, just like you all are sitting here, there are devotees sitting in front and Jesus was telling something about the supreme soul. Satsang is going on, satsang is happening in a room, a person comes cutting through the crowd of satsang to Jesus and says, 'Rabbi’, ‘Rabbi,' meaning Sadguru, O Rabbi, your mother and some people of your family have come.' Listen carefully. What are they saying to Jesus that your mother and some people of your family have come outside to meet you” Listen to Jesus’s answer and please listen carefully, who are the real descendants. Jesus says, \"My descendants are not my mother, my brother, or my sister. My wife or my child are not my descendants. My descendant is the one who knows the heart of the Sadguru, the will of the Sadguru, and acts accordingly. That is my descendant.\" So it is necessary to clean up some things and not get stuck in useless discussions. You spend your valuable time going to Shirdi, so firstly read three or four chapters. Until then, don't even enter the samadhi mandir. What kind of feeling will arise in you without reading the chapters of Sai Satcharitra, tell me. You enter the samadhi mandir carrying trash? If you don't read the Sai Satcharitra, before entering in. But if you immerse in the three chapters of Sai Satcharitra, then a great emotion will arise in you, and when you enter the samadhi mandir holding that emotion, the meeting that will take place will be wonderful. Just go running, running, running, running, and stand in front of the statue. So, ‘Shirdi is inside you’ and make an effort to see Shirdi with your subtle eyes. It’s enough of seeing Shirdi, samadhi mandir, dwarkamai, gurusthan with your gross vision, now try to see Shirdi with your subtle eyes. I have a video, I request you all, if you really want to see subtle Shirdi with subtle eyes, Baba is distributing chocolates, it's just the beginning phase. It goes on for a while, then it stops later. Dealing with so much fuss over it. Such is your experience? Indeed, this is the experience we share. Today, a feeling arose in me and Baba has done this. If you are truly beginners, then such leela is appreciable But if you've spent 5-6 years in devotion to Baba, and still, if you describe such experiences, then it really makes one question your intelligence. I feel sorry for your thinking. Is this an experience? Is this what you call an experience? the day when Baba's heart begins to open, to understand Baba's will, that's what you call an experience. Everything else is just trash. According to your mind, whatever is happening is all trash. If Baba's will begins to unfold in your heart, then consider it the father of experiences, the greatest experience of all in the world. And besides that, whatever is happening according to your mind, is garbage. So, don't be proud of it, don't go around boasting to four people, please. It's just trivial talk. I'm saying again, for those who are in a very early stage, it's okay, such acts are appreciable. But if you've spent three or four years in devotion to Baba, and if you're still stuck in the same phase, thinking \"I wished for this food and it came into my hands,\" Experience is when the day comes in devotion to Baba when you forget hunger and thirst, and that day you don't even realize that you haven't eaten food. That's what you call an experience. This is a true experience: that I was so engrossed in devotion to Baba today, so deeply absorbed, that neither hunger struck nor thirst woke up. When you've reached the doorstep, why not look inside the house? Now come inside a little too, Baba is saying, come and see inside my heart, see what my will is, what I desire from you You spent lifetimes persuading yourself, but now, at least understand my will a little, feel the beating of my heart, see a bit of it too. Just once, make a little entry inside. This path should be adorned with petals of faith and it says this spiritual path is not a straightforward one, it's strewn with thorns, troubles, yet those who have unwavering faith it takes adorning this path with the petals of such faith. Every time, things would happen according to my mind is not necessary. In the initial stage, Baba descends to our level and works according to our minds so that our faith becomes slightly stronger. But later, throughout our life, He works against our will. Only then our ego and body consciousness is destroyed or else it will sustain If everything happened according to my mind, then my body intellect wouldn't be wiped out even after millions of lifetimes. So, He works against our minds, not just for a month, two months, or even years but for lifetimes. If He is working against us, then how our faith will remain intact during that time? Please tell me. The one whose faith is so firmly rooted that today, when I desire something and Baba fulfills it for me, with such hollow faith, then how will I stand before them tomorrow when I face trials? Then in just four moments, you'll run away from there, thinking, \"That's it, This guy is going to kill me.\" But he's already there to kill. Why have we come under the guidance of the Sadguru? To be erased. Whoever is afraid, consider them dead. We have come under His guidance to be dissolved. If Baba doesn't erase, then Maya will erase eventually, will you remain in this world until eternity? One day, Maya will erase you. Whether in your 50s, 70s, 80s, or 90s. And if your life is long, then in a hundred years. Maya will indeed erase you one day. So why not die in the hands of Baba instead of Maya? Because when we die in the hands of Maya, we are bound to be reborn. But when we die in the sacred hands of Baba, we become the hero of the universe. One attains immortality. You become person untouched by death. This is the path that needs to be adorned with petals of faith. So, the petals of faith should be strong. I always say that if I experience moments of heaven at the feet of others, at the court of others, still I don't want to take a step there. Please pay attention to these words. If Baba, I experience moments of heaven at the feet of others, then I don't want to take a step there, and if I experience moments of hell at your feet, Baba, then I don't want to leave your shelter. This is called faith. He tested you a little, and you started running. 'Oh man, this guy is going to hit me.' Yes, he's already there to hit. I'll tell you an incident. Perhaps you're from the North, so you might not have heard the name. There's a village called Gondavale in the Satara district of Maharashtra. There was a saint there, Gondavalekar Maharaj. One incident from his life is that from a very young age, he had a curiosity to attain God. And at a very young age, around 15 or 16 years old, he left home to pursue the Guru So, another person tells them that there is a saint in such-and-such village named tukamai, and if you take shelter with him, your work will be done. So, he goes to his court, searching and searching, until he finally arrive. And as soon as they see each other, Tukamai, the Guru says to the child, \"Oh, you've come today.\" 'so come, today I will finish you off.\" The first line is, \"You've come today, you've come to me today, so come, I'll finish you off.\" So, what reply does the child give? \"I've come to be erased by your hands. Please erase me.\" So, this is the relationship between a Sadguru and a disciple. He are yearning to erase you, and if you are yearning to be erased, then the relationship will flourish. Otherwise, what kind of relationship is it? It's like saying that the train is running towards Kolkata, while the compartments are heading towards Kashmir. It's simply not possible. Wherever the engine goes, these compartments will also have to be attached to the engine and go in the same direction. They want to erase us, and we want to die in their hands. Because to die is to become one with existence, The one who is dying is perishable, and the one about to remain is immortal. It means an indivisible life, which death cannot touch. It's the soul, it's the essence of the divine. So, the meaning of the second stanza was that this is a path that needs to be adorned with the blossoms of faith. one has to awaken themselves and awaken others too. 'Master, you have brought me till here and have been directing me the destination. I could actually see the gap between.' I you've found my destination. So, when I look at others from where I stand, I see them on steps downward. Thus, I have to pull them up to my level, and I also have to complete my own remaining journey. Having lived in the world, try stepping away from it. Having spent so much time in the world, who knows how many lifetimes you've taken, how many times you've seen this world, how many times you've experienced the same pleasures. And how many times have you left your loved ones behind, because of attachment, crying, having to bid farewell to this world? Who knows how many times. This is what this world is. Besides this, what else is there in the world? Either your loved ones will leave you before you, or you will leave them. Apart from these two, what else is there? And both forms entail sorrow. Sorrow exists whether you have to leave your loved ones or if they leave you. Having lived in the world and then stepping away from it, you'll find that He stands close, bringing you closer to yourself. Shirdi is within you. Look inside your heart. This is the last stanza and very important saying - The one whom you seek you should know one's identity. As you are in search of Baba so Baba's identity should be known. Understanding Baba's form, His heart, and His will is crucial. It's said to be as vast as the ocean The recognition of whom you seek is essential, but every effort is fulfilled by the faith of the traveler. But the recognition of His true essence will only come through faith. You must maintain unwavering faith and patience. Only then will Baba open his heart before you and reveal his true form. That is why there are people who worship Krishna, There are people who worship Shivji, there are people who worship Brahma, there are people who worship 33 crores Gods and Goddesses in that Sadguru also comes but about them it is said Gurur Brahma Gurur Vishnu, Gurur Devo Maheshwara, Guru Sakshat Parabrahma, tasmai Shree Guruve namah. Why has Guru been given so much importance? Guru has been given so much importance because this human body that we have Guru who brings it to its destination that is why his greatness is much more than all the three and he is said to be parabrahma. The stage that he has reached to, he also brings us to that stage, the completeness that he has attained to, he fills us also with that completeness. That is why the status of Sadguru is very very high. It is very high If we say that Saibaba is our Sadguru then the what it means is what is Sadguru’s will. It is very important to know that. Sadguru’s will is Sadguru. Sadguru’s body is not Sadguru. If we do not understand Sadguru’s will and if we say that Saibaba is my Sadguru then we are making some mistake. We only keep saying Sadguru Sainath Maharaj ki jai. But in reality, we do not know even an iota of Sadguru’s will. And if we do not know His will then how is he, our Sadguru? Now I had asked how many people believe Baba to be Sadguru then everyone’s hands were raised. Now I ask another question how many people know Baba’s will completely. Now raise your hands. See, this is the difference. Not a single hand is raised. That means you cannot say with confidence that you know Sai’s will. We only believe Sai to be Guru. We don’t know it. And if we do not know His will then how is he, our Sadguru. Then on what basis is he, our Sadguru. We are miles away from His will. We don’t have the capacity to understand his feelings. We don’t have that capability. Then how does he become our Sadguru? It means due to our sentiments we keep calling him Sadguru. That is our sentiment. Actually, if you tell Baba that I believe you to be Sadguru do you consider me to be your disciple. It has to be two-way relationship. If I call him my Sadguru Then Baba also has to say in return that ne is my disciple. Will Baba say that he is my disciple. For 99.99% people Baba will not say. The reason for that is we do not know His will. Without knowing His will we consider him to be our Sadguru. There is no clarity with Baba. This is a big mockery. We just cheer with our mouth Sachidanand Sadguru Sainath Maharaj ki jai. Just once ask your conscience is he really your Sadguru. Do you really understand his mind, will and sentiments? And do you respect that? We become sentimental and impose our emotions on him. And we have a weapon in our hand Jaki Bhavana jaisi Prabhu murth tin taise. 'jaya mani jaisa bhav taya taisa anubhav' This is a one-way relationship. You have been telling Baba for lifetimes that you are my Sadguru but Sadguru does not say that he is my disciple. It is a one way relationship. Now I will come to that story. Sai Satcharitra tells this thing and Baba has hidden this Leela in the book. Now I will open it in front of you. You will understand why I said these things. That in fact we call Sadguru Sadguru but we do not consider him to be Sadguru and we do not know His will. That is why inspite of talking about it he is not actually our Sadguru. I speak bitterly It is bitter and hurts but there is truth in it. Each one of us has to accept it. When I will open up the Leela from Sai Satcharitra Adhyay 32 then you will understand that we really only speaking that Baba is our Sadguru but actually we do not know His will. We only talk that he is our Sadguru. Now I come to Adhyay 32. It is a small Leela. Baba along with his three classmates go out in search of Brahma Gyan (Knowledge of the universe). And all the four have been described as being Scholar. They were very knowledgeable, they had deep knowledge of the Shastras and with all the knowledge of the Shastras and Vedas, Vedant with all that light they go in search of Brahma Gyan. Baba is also one of them. Baba is doing this Leela. In reality Baba need not go in search of Brahma Gyan, he is Brahmand Nayak (Ruler of the Universe) but many times in Sai Charitra he has brought himself down so that he can give us some advice, so he can teach us. First Classmate of Baba says Ekda amhi chaughe jan vachuni pothi puran karu lagalo brahma nirupan Gyan sampanna houni. All the four us after acquiring knowledge, talking about Brahma we go seeking Brahma Gyan. From amongst them one says Udharadatmanaam, he giteche gheuni vachan, ayukta sarvthaiv paravlambana, aise pravachan ek kari. One of them says Udharadatmanaam. Bhagvat Gita says that every person must work out his own salvation. One should not be dependent on others. One amongst them is saying One should take efforts and one should attain Brahma Gyan by one’s own efforts. This is what first person says. The second one says Taya pratutar kari anya, man Swadhin tochi danya, The second one says the one who can control his mind the one who has controlled his mind he is the Blessed One in this world asave sankalp vikalp shunya kahi n apna vin And he says that a person should escape from the sankalp vikalp, alright, what is this sankalp vikalp? Many people might be wondering what these alternatives of resolutions are. There are occasions in life where one stands at a crossroad, not knowing whether to take this path or that, what seems right initially, later, after some time, doesn't seem right, so these alternatives of resolutions that fluctuate, that are unstable within the mind. So, the one who eliminates that instability forever, has clarity forever. Now, whatever one sees in life, one sees with complete clarity. Never does one fall prey to the dilemmas of resolutions. So, the one who gains control over their mind, the one whose alternatives of resolutions are eradicated, is the rightful heir to the knowledge of the universe. This is what the second is saying. first said that we have to seek Bramhagyan on our own without being dependent on others and the third says that - anitya sarva prakar nitya ek nirvikar; The world is impermanent, not eternal, transient Such discrimination between the eternal and impermanent, the knowledge of which leads to the understanding that this world is impermanent, and only the Supreme Being is eternal The one who possesses that knowledge, that discrimination. Meaning, he is on the path of knowledge So they say, only the one who is the possessor of that knowledge is the rightful heir to the wisdom of the universe. Now, see, all three of them are speaking the truth. No one here is inferior. And the fourth one, what does Baba say? The fourth one doesn't like the knowledge from books. He says, perform respectful conduct, one's conduct in life should be pure. It doesn't matter what we read and acquire, what matters is how we live, Our conduct matters. Our conduct should be prescribed, Not prohibited Prescribed conduct means the conduct that the Vedas have given, the Upanishads have given, that is considered correct, pure, and holy. about Baba it says,'the fourth did not approve of bookish learning but believed in conducting oneself in conformity with the shastras and offering oneself totally at the Guru's feet' and Baba says,\"these body, speech, five vital airs, mind ,intellect all should be surrendered at the feet of Guru by us\" What Baba feels is that no matter how much theoretical knowledge you gain, memorize, or understand, nothing will come of it. The conduct of a person should be pure, first and foremost, and secondly, one should surrender to the feet of the Guru. One should find refuge in the true Guru, only then will one attain Brahmagyan. Now, these are Baba's words. So in this way all four set out in search of Brahmagyan When they set out in search of Brahmagyan, the forest they were traversing through was so dense, the jungle so thick, that not even a ray of sunlight could penetrate through to them. So, Baba is associating the world with that forest there. This world is also a forest, an impassable forest, where not even a ray of sunlight reaches us. So, Baba is saying, just as if you pass through a dense jungle and if the density is so much, the whole jungle, then not even a single ray of sunlight can reach us, similarly, this world is also a dense jungle, and here too, that ray of knowledge, that ray of wisdom, that ray of eternity, does not reach our hearts. But still all four with their respective feelings embarks on search and while roaming they meet a Banjara (gypsy) Bajara asks for their destination to them all four feel that being a wanderer he himself has no abode so why to tell him so the one who himself is not stable what help he can provide us? so they deny to tell him and follow their path including Baba wandering into the labyrinth of that forest they again reach back to the same where that wanderer was standing This means all four are unsettled but the wanderer is settled therefore they again retreat back to the wanderer so he says,\"Now you all must have understood if you still don't want to tell then don't but its afternoon and sun is overhead heating and you all must have starving and thirsty. I have a bread eat it with the chutney and then you may go after drinking little water so three of them feels that firstly we have left with very grave feeling and this wanderer is blacking us again and again so they again scorning his request and move forward but Baba remains there Baba feels that what will he gain on feeling our hunger and thirst so he should be obeyed. Baba told him to give him the bread. so the wanderer takes him and gives him quarterly bread and quench his thirst No sooner did Baba eat the bread given by the wanderer than as per the book Gurudev appears Now my question is to the people who have read Sai satcharitra has any person like a rushi muni appeared there? wasDid that gypsy leave from there and did some other guru appear in the place of the gypsy? Baba did not have any Guru earlier because it is clearly written that we four also set out in search of Brahmagyan on our own, but Baba's feeling was that if one gets the refuge of the Guru, then it would be the best. So now the question is that he told the Banjara to eat this Chatkur Roti, meaning eat this roti and dry chutney, I have nothing other than that, so as soon as Baba accepts his orders, he eats the roti and drinks the water and that Banjara himself becomes the Sadguru. This is the depth of this leela. Till they did not listen to the Banjara, they kept doing as they pleased, kept wandering from place to place, till then he was an ordinary Banjara, but as soon as he accepted his orders, the Banjara said eat the roti and drink this water and as he accepted his wish, followed his orders and that Banjara himself became the Sadguru in that very moment. So what does this story tell us that today we all go running to Shirdi, book a room, take a bath, wear the best clothes and run around to have Baba's darshan at Samadhi Bandir, but today i ask you the question that whoes darsham do you take Sadguru or a Banjara? If His wish is not know to us, What are their expectations from us? if we don't have leisure time and we keep calling out to Baba from our own emotions, then we have reduced the infinite cosmic master, the eternal blissful true guru, to a mere wanderer. And if we understand His will, comprehend His intent, and live our lives according to that intent, then we turn an ordinary wanderer into the infinite cosmic master, the true guru, Sai Nath Maharaj. Thus, we are the ones who make Him a wanderer, and we are also the ones who make Him the eternal blissful true guru. This play is so important that I asked my first question: How many people here consider Baba as a true guru? Everyone raised their hands. My second question was: How many people know Baba's will? Not a single hand was raised. So, this means that for 101% for us, Sai Baba sitting in the Shirdi Samadhi Temple is a wanderer, not a true guru, because we do not know what His will is. I am speaking very harshly, but if you do not listen today, you will waste your birth doing your own will, imposing your emotions on Him, and will spoil your life. In reality, if we know Baba's will, then He is indeed the true guru. We are eligible to say that Baba is our true guru. But if we do not will understand His teachings, His knowledge, His spiritual existence, if we do not know His feelings from us, what He expects from us, then how can He be our true guru? He would still be a wanderer because, in this play, He has shown that by respecting His will and following His orders, the wanderer becomes a true guru. because in Sai satcharitra it is mentioned guru appears, as Baba followed His advice to eat the roti and drink water, the guru appeared. A question should arise how did He appear? Was it a sage or a hermit type of person who suddenly appeared next to the wanderer? It's simple: as long as we are doing our own will, He is a wanderer But as soon as we follow His orders, He becomes the Sadguru. So, see, we are running in a blind race. We chant \"Satchidananda Sadguru Sainath Maharaj ki Jai\" loudly, but honestly, if we place our hand on our heart and ask ourselves if we truly know His will, if He is truly our Sadguru, the answer will be no. I am here among you to reveal this aspect of Baba. If we call Baba our true guru, we must have the power to know His heart without Him speaking, to know His will. And if that power is not there, then it is very unfortunate to say that He is not a true guru for us; He is just a mere wanderer. This is very painful. We just chant His glory but we don't know His heart, His yearning, His will, His order How is He our Sadguru? But in reality He is a Master of all universe but as we don't know His will thus we have made such a great glory as ordinary wanderer It's our foolishness and stupidity that we have brought such a glory to a level of wanderer If we truly want to know His will and follow His commands, there is no other way but through the Sai Satcharitra. If we can understand the Sai Satcharitra, if we can comprehend each of His Leelas, if we can grasp what message and teachings He wants to convey behind each Leelas, and what light He wants to bestow upon us, then He is our true guru. But if the light of the Sai Satcharitra is not in our lives, then please stop saying that He is our true guru. It's complete nonsense, rubbish, a false claim. Although we are not doing it knowingly, we are making this mistake unknowingly, but it is still a mistake. We are committing the sin of calling a wanderer our true guru. He will be our true guru when we understand His will, His feelings. I always give an example: Suppose there is a husband and wife. They have spent 40 years under one roof together. But if the wife cannot understand the husband's heart without him speaking, and the husband cannot understand the wife's heart without her speaking, what value does that relationship have? It is hollow. Similarly, our relationship with Baba is equally hollow because we lack the yearning of a true disciple to understand Baba's heart without Him speaking. So how can Baba be our true guru? Then the conversation is over. Let me show you a scene; please watch it to understand that our feelings have no value. We need to change according to His feelings; that is true spirituality. Bringing Him down to our level by holding His collar is no great achievement. He easily comes down to our level. But greatness lies in Him remaining at His height while we, understanding His heart and will, reach up to Him. The greatness lies in that, not in dragging Him down to our level by holding His collar. But inspite of that, he thinks within that I am a Muslim, inspite of that the way he used to worship his Guru, he worshiped me in the same way. He saw his Guru in me his devotion to his Guru is so very great that even religion did not matter. His heart is so very huge it does not matter to him that I am a Muslim and he worshipped me as he worshipped his Guru and applied sandalwood, then not only me even Harihar Brahman would bow down his head, I am only an ordinary Fakir. It means that this leela tells us that our devotion has to be so high that if we believe Baba to be our Guru, we may stand in Church or we may stand in Gurudwara, we may stand in some shrine we should have the same faith as much as we have in Baba. This Leela teaches us this. This is the greatness of religion; this is what baba has given to the world. His devotion to his Guru is so very superior that not only me even Harihar Brahma has to bow his head before him. It means that religion did not come in the way. The wall of religion also needs to be broken, that also is a block, it is a wall and a very huge wall. Without this completeness is not possible. It is not possible at all. If anyone can take samadhi while in body for three days like me then there will be no difference between him and me. Now the fourth category. We spoke of three categories Head, neck and forehead. He is beyond all lineage, caste, clan and religions, and whose essence, the true form, the original form, is the light of the soul, which has always been complete, that is Sai, was, is, and will remain. Because he is an eternal element, and then as stated in a verse further it becomes clearer that how an anonymous person got the name Sai. The meaning of a Sufi name is that a Sufi is a person who treats all religions equally, loves everyone equally. Such a person is called a Sufi. I desire to distribute diamonds and pearls, Baba is saying my desire is to distribute diamonds and pearls, but unfortunately, your nature is to ask for stones and rocks.
